<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Jesus</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">

<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>

<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Central figure of Christianity (c. 4 BC â 30 or 33 AD)</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Christ", "Jesus Christ", "Jesus the Christ", and "Jesus of Nazareth" redirect here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Christ_(disambiguation)" title="Christ (disambiguation)">Christ (disambiguation)</a>, <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Jesus_(disambiguation)" title="Jesus (disambiguation)">Jesus (disambiguation)</a>, <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Jesus_Christ_(disambiguation)" title="Jesus Christ (disambiguation)">Jesus Christ (disambiguation)</a>, and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Jesus_of_Nazareth_(disambiguation)" title="Jesus of Nazareth (disambiguation)">Jesus of Nazareth (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="padding-bottom:0;"><a href="/wiki/Religious_perspectives_on_Jesus" title="Religious perspectives on Jesus">Perspectives on Jesus</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">

<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="padding-bottom:0;"><a href="/wiki/Depiction_of_Jesus" title="Depiction of Jesus">Jesus in culture</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Life_of_Christ_in_art" title="Life of Christ in art">Life in art</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Jesuism" title="Jesuism">Jesuism</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below plainlist" style="padding-top:0.1em;font-weight:bold;line-height:1.5em;">
<ul><li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P_christianity.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/16px-P_christianity.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/24px-P_christianity.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/32px-P_christianity.svg.png 2x" width="16"/></a>Â <a href="/wiki/Portal:Christianity" title="Portal:Christianity">Christianity portal</a></li>
<li><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="215" data-file-width="206" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/15px-Allah-green.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/23px-Allah-green.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/31px-Allah-green.svg.png 2x" width="15"/>Â <a href="/wiki/Portal:Islam" title="Portal:Islam">Islam portal</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Jesus" title="Template:Jesus"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Jesus" title="Template talk:Jesus"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Jesus&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Jesus</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[d]</a></sup> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â4 BC</span>Â â  AD 30 or 33), also referred to as <b>Jesus Christ</b> or <b>Jesus of Nazareth</b> (among other <a href="/wiki/Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament" title="Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament">names and titles</a>), was a first-century <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jewish</a> preacher and religious leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVermes198120,_26,_27,_29_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVermes198120,_26,_27,_29-14">[10]</a></sup> He is the central figure of <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's largest religion</a>. Most <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> believe he is the <a href="/wiki/Incarnation_(Christianity)" title="Incarnation (Christianity)">incarnation</a> of <a href="/wiki/God_the_Son" title="God the Son">God the Son</a> and the awaited <a href="/wiki/Messiah#Christianity" title="Messiah">messiah</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Christ_(title)" title="Christ (title)">Christ</a>) prophesied in the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a>.
</p><p>Virtually all modern scholars of antiquity agree that <a href="/wiki/Historicity_of_Jesus" title="Historicity of Jesus">Jesus existed historically</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exist_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-exist-22">[e]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Quest_for_the_historical_Jesus" title="Quest for the historical Jesus">Research into the historical Jesus</a> has yielded some uncertainty on the <a href="/wiki/Historical_reliability_of_the_Gospels" title="Historical reliability of the Gospels">historical reliability of the Gospels</a> and on how closely the Jesus portrayed in the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> reflects the <a href="/wiki/Historical_Jesus" title="Historical Jesus">historical Jesus</a>, as the only detailed records of Jesus' life are contained in the <a href="/wiki/Gospel" title="Gospel">Gospels</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPowell1998168â73_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPowell1998168â73-23">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[f]</a></sup> Jesus was a <a href="/wiki/Galilean" title="Galilean">Galilean</a> Jew who <a href="/wiki/Circumcision_of_Jesus" title="Circumcision of Jesus">underwent circumcision</a>, was <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Jesus" title="Baptism of Jesus">baptized</a> by <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a>, and began <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Jesus" title="Ministry of Jesus">his own ministry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVermes198120,_26,_27,_29_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVermes198120,_26,_27,_29-14">[10]</a></sup> His <a href="/wiki/Oral_gospel_traditions" title="Oral gospel traditions">teachings were initially conserved by oral transmission</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dunn2013_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dunn2013-27">[21]</a></sup> and he himself was often referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Rabbi" title="Rabbi">rabbi</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ISBEO_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-ISBEO-28">[22]</a></sup> Jesus debated with fellow Jews on how to best follow <a href="/wiki/God_in_Christianity" title="God in Christianity">God</a>, engaged in healings, taught in <a href="/wiki/Parables_of_Jesus" title="Parables of Jesus">parables</a> and gathered followers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevine20064_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevine20064-29">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[24]</a></sup> He was arrested and tried by the <a href="/wiki/Sanhedrin" title="Sanhedrin">Jewish authorities</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199311_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199311-31">[25]</a></sup> turned over to the Roman government, and <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">crucified</a> on the order of <a href="/wiki/Pontius_Pilate" title="Pontius Pilate">Pontius Pilate</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Roman_governor" title="Roman governor">Roman prefect</a> of Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevine20064_29-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevine20064-29">[23]</a></sup> After his death, his followers believed he <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus" title="Resurrection of Jesus">rose from the dead</a>, and the community they formed eventually became the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Church" title="Early Church">early Christian Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199311,_14_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199311,_14-32">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian" title="Christian">Christian</a> doctrines include the beliefs that Jesus was conceived by the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit_in_Christianity" title="Holy Spirit in Christianity">Holy Spirit</a>, was <a href="/wiki/Virgin_birth_of_Jesus" title="Virgin birth of Jesus">born of a virgin</a> named <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">Mary</a>, performed <a href="/wiki/Miracles_of_Jesus" title="Miracles of Jesus">miracles</a>, founded the Christian Church, died by <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion" title="Crucifixion">crucifixion</a> as a sacrifice to achieve <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atonement_in_Christianity" title="Atonement in Christianity">atonement for sin</a>, rose from the dead, and <a href="/wiki/Ascension_of_Jesus" title="Ascension of Jesus">ascended</a> into <a href="/wiki/Heaven_in_Christianity" title="Heaven in Christianity">Heaven</a>, from where he <a href="/wiki/Second_Coming" title="Second Coming">will return</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrudem1994568â603_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrudem1994568â603-33">[27]</a></sup> Commonly, <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Christianity" title="Jesus in Christianity">Christians believe Jesus</a> enables people to be reconciled to God. The <a href="/wiki/Nicene_Creed" title="Nicene Creed">Nicene Creed</a> asserts that Jesus will <a href="/wiki/Last_Judgment" title="Last Judgment">judge the living and the dead</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[28]</a></sup> either <a href="/wiki/Intermediate_state" title="Intermediate state">before</a> or <a href="/wiki/Christian_mortalism" title="Christian mortalism">after</a> their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_the_dead#Christianity" title="Resurrection of the dead">bodily resurrection</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oxford_Companion_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Companion-35">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[31]</a></sup> an event tied to the <a href="/wiki/Second_Coming" title="Second Coming">Second Coming</a> of Jesus in <a href="/wiki/Christian_eschatology" title="Christian eschatology">Christian eschatology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[32]</a></sup> The great majority of Christians worship Jesus as the incarnation of <a href="/wiki/God_the_Son" title="God the Son">God the Son</a>, the second of three <a href="/wiki/Prosopon" title="Prosopon">persons</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Trinity" title="Trinity">Trinity</a>. However, there is a small minority of <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">Christian denominations</a> that <a href="/wiki/Nontrinitarianism" title="Nontrinitarianism">reject trinitarianism</a>, wholly or partly, as non-scriptural. The <a href="/wiki/Nativity_of_Jesus" title="Nativity of Jesus">birth of Jesus</a> is celebrated annually on 25 December as <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Christmas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[g]</a></sup> His crucifixion is honored on <a href="/wiki/Good_Friday" title="Good Friday">Good Friday</a> and his resurrection on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Easter_Sunday" title="Easter Sunday">Easter Sunday</a>. The world's most widely used <a href="/wiki/Calendar_era" title="Calendar era">calendar era</a>âin which the current year is <a href="/wiki/Anno_Domini" title="Anno Domini">AD</a> 2022 (or 2022 <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>)âis based on the approximate <a href="/wiki/Date_of_birth_of_Jesus" title="Date of birth of Jesus">birthdate of Jesus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AD_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-AD-40">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jesus is also revered in other religions. <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Islam" title="Jesus in Islam">In Islam</a>, Jesus (often referred to by his Quranic name <span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn"><i><a href="/wiki/Isa_(name)" title="Isa (name)">Ê¿ÄªsÄ</a></i></i></span>) is considered the penultimate <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prophets_in_Islam" title="Prophets in Islam">prophet</a> of <a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">God</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Messiah#Islam" title="Messiah">messiah</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uscsite_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-uscsite-43">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CEI_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-CEI-44">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siddiqui_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-Siddiqui-45">[38]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a> believe Jesus was born of the virgin <a href="/wiki/Mary_in_Islam" title="Mary in Islam">Mary</a> (another figure revered in Islam), but was neither God nor a son of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[40]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> states that Jesus never claimed to be divine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morgan_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Morgan-48">[41]</a></sup> Most Muslims do not believe that he <a href="/wiki/Islamic_views_on_Jesus%27_death" title="Islamic views on Jesus' death">was killed or crucified</a>, but that God <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entering_Heaven_alive" title="Entering Heaven alive">raised him into Heaven while he was still alive</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[42]</a></sup> In contrast, <a href="/wiki/Judaism%27s_view_of_Jesus" title="Judaism's view of Jesus">Judaism rejects the belief</a> that Jesus was the awaited messiah, arguing that he did not fulfill <a href="/wiki/Messiah_in_Judaism" title="Messiah in Judaism">messianic prophecies</a>, and was neither divine nor resurrected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JE1906_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-JE1906-50">[43]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-23"><a href="#Early_Christianity"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Early Christianity</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-24"><a href="#Historical_views"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Historical views</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-25"><a href="#Judea_and_Galilee_in_the_1st_century"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Judea and Galilee in the 1st century</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-26"><a href="#Sources"><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span> <span class="toctext">Sources</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-27"><a href="#Chronology"><span class="tocnumber">4.3</span> <span class="toctext">Chronology</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-28"><a href="#Historicity_of_events"><span class="tocnumber">4.4</span> <span class="toctext">Historicity of events</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-29"><a href="#Family"><span class="tocnumber">4.4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Family</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-30"><a href="#Baptism"><span class="tocnumber">4.4.2</span> <span class="toctext">Baptism</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-31"><a href="#Ministry_in_Galilee"><span class="tocnumber">4.4.3</span> <span class="toctext">Ministry in Galilee</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-32"><a href="#Role"><span class="tocnumber">4.4.4</span> <span class="toctext">Role</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-33"><a href="#Passover_and_crucifixion_in_Jerusalem"><span class="tocnumber">4.4.5</span> <span class="toctext">Passover and crucifixion in Jerusalem</span></a></li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_name_of_Jesus">The name of Jesus</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Jesus_(name)" title="Jesus (name)">Jesus (name)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holy_Name_of_Jesus" title="Holy Name of Jesus">Holy Name of Jesus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament" title="Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament">Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Names_of_God_in_Christianity" title="Names of God in Christianity">Names of God in Christianity</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JesusYeshua2.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="348" data-file-width="819" decoding="async" height="93" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/JesusYeshua2.svg/220px-JesusYeshua2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/JesusYeshua2.svg/330px-JesusYeshua2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/JesusYeshua2.svg/440px-JesusYeshua2.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JesusYeshua2.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Counter-clockwise from top-right: <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aramaic" title="Aramaic">Aramaic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> transcriptions of the name <i>Jesus</i></div></div></div>
<h3><span id="Naming_convention.2C_various_names"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Naming_convention,_various_names">Naming convention, various names</span></h3>
<p>A typical <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jew" title="Jew">Jew</a> in Jesus' time <a href="/wiki/Jewish_name" title="Jewish name">had only one name</a>, sometimes <a href="/wiki/Patronymic" title="Patronymic">followed by the phrase "son of [father's name]"</a>, or the individual's hometown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup> Thus, in the New Testament, Jesus is commonly referred to as "Jesus of <a href="/wiki/Nazareth" title="Nazareth">Nazareth</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[h]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[46]</a></sup> Jesus' neighbors in Nazareth refer to him as "the carpenter, the son of <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">Mary</a> and brother of <a href="/wiki/James,_brother_of_Jesus" title="James, brother of Jesus">James</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joses,_brother_of_James_the_younger" title="Joses, brother of James the younger">Joses</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jude,_brother_of_Jesus" title="Jude, brother of Jesus">Judas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Simon,_brother_of_Jesus" title="Simon, brother of Jesus">Simon</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[48]</a></sup> "the carpenter's son",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[50]</a></sup> or "<a href="/wiki/Saint_Joseph" title="Saint Joseph">Joseph</a>'s son".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[52]</a></sup> In the Gospel of John, the disciple <a href="/wiki/Philip_the_Apostle" title="Philip the Apostle">Philip</a> refers to him as "Jesus son of Joseph from Nazareth".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>The name <i>Yeshua</i> appears to have been in use in Judea at the time of the birth of Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[55]</a></sup> The 1st-century works of historian <a href="/wiki/Josephus" title="Josephus">Flavius Josephus</a>, who wrote in <a href="/wiki/Koine_Greek" title="Koine Greek">Koine Greek</a>, the same language as that of the New Testament,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[56]</a></sup> refer to at least twenty different people with the name Jesus (i.e. á¼¸Î·ÏÎ¿á¿¦Ï).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEddyBoyd2007129_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEddyBoyd2007129-65">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Gospel of Matthew</a> states that an <a href="/wiki/Angel" title="Angel">angel</a> appeared to Jesus' adoptive father, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Joseph" title="Saint Joseph">Joseph</a>, to tell Joseph about his future son and to name him Jesus because "he will save his people from their sins":
</p>
<blockquote><p>But after he had considered this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, "Joseph son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary home as your wife, because what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit. She will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins."
<span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+1%3A20%E2%80%9321&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">Matthew 1:20â21</a></span></p></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_linguistic_analysis">Modern linguistic analysis</span></h4>
<p>The English name <i>Jesus</i> is derived from the Latin <i>Iesus</i>, itself a <a href="/wiki/Transliteration" title="Transliteration">transliteration</a> of the Greek <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">á¼¸Î·ÏÎ¿á¿¦Ï</span></span> (<i><span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><i lang="grc-Latn">IÄsoÃ»s</i></span></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CE_name_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-CE_name-66">[58]</a></sup> The Greek form is probably a rendering of the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aramaic" title="Aramaic">Aramaic</a> name <span title="Hebrew-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="he">××©××¢</span></span> (<i><a href="/wiki/Yeshua" title="Yeshua">YÄÅ¡Å«aÊ¿</a></i><span style="visibility:hidden; color:transparent; padding-left:2px">â</span>), a shorter variant of the earlier Hebrew name <span title="Hebrew-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="he">××××©×¢</span></span> (<i><a href="/wiki/Joshua_(name)" title="Joshua (name)">YÉhÅÅ¡Å«aÊ¿</a></i>, English: "Joshua").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>The modern linguistic analysis of the name <i>Yehoshua</i> is "<a href="/wiki/Yahweh" title="Yahweh">Yahweh</a> is lordly".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAyali-Darshan2018_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAyali-Darshan2018-68">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>Joshua (<i>Yehoshua</i>) was also the name of <a href="/wiki/Joshua" title="Joshua">Moses's successor</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[61]</a></sup> and of a <a href="/wiki/Joshua_the_High_Priest" title="Joshua the High Priest">Jewish high priest</a> in the Hebrew Bible,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[62]</a></sup> both of whom are represented in the <a href="/wiki/Septuagint" title="Septuagint">Septuagint</a> (a Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible) as <i><span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><i lang="grc-Latn">IÄsoÃ»s</i></span></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Traditional_Christian_analysis">Traditional Christian analysis</span></h4>
<p>The name <i>YÉhÅÅ¡Å«aÊ¿</i> likely means "<a href="/wiki/Yahweh" title="Yahweh">Yah</a> saves".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>The etymology of Jesus' name in the context of the New Testament is generally given as "<a href="/wiki/Yahweh" title="Yahweh">Yahweh</a> is salvation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrance200753_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrance200753-73">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Jesus_as_the_Christ">Jesus as the Christ</span></h3>
<p>Since the early period of <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, Christians have commonly referred to Jesus as "Jesus Christ".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoninger1999212_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoninger1999212-74">[66]</a></sup> "Jesus Christ" is the name that the author of the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_John" title="Gospel of John">Gospel of John</a> claims Jesus gave to himself during his <a href="/wiki/Farewell_Discourse" title="Farewell Discourse">high priestly prayer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[67]</a></sup> The word <i><a href="/wiki/Christ_(title)" title="Christ (title)">Christ</a></i> was a <a href="/wiki/Threefold_office" title="Threefold office">title or office</a> ("the Christ"), not a given name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPannenberg196830â31_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPannenberg196830â31-76">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[69]</a></sup> It derives from the Greek <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%A7%CF%81%CE%B9%CF%83%CF%84%CF%8C%CF%82" title="wikt:Î§ÏÎ¹ÏÏÏÏ">Î§ÏÎ¹ÏÏÏÏ</a></span></span> (<i>Christos</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CE_name_66-1"><a href="#cite_note-CE_name-66">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[70]</a></sup> a translation of the Hebrew <i><a href="/wiki/Messiah_in_Judaism" title="Messiah in Judaism">mashiakh</a></i> (<span title="Hebrew-language text"><span lang="he"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D7%9E%D6%B8%D7%A9%D6%B4%D7%81%D7%99%D7%97%D6%B7" title="wikt:×Ö¸×©Ö´×××Ö·">××©××</a></span></span>) meaning "<a href="/wiki/Anointing" title="Anointing">anointed</a>", and is usually transliterated into English as "<a href="/wiki/Messiah" title="Messiah">messiah</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVine1940274â75_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVine1940274â75-80">[72]</a></sup> In biblical Judaism, <a href="/wiki/Holy_anointing_oil" title="Holy anointing oil">sacred oil</a> was used to anoint certain exceptionally holy people and objects as part of their religious investiture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>Christians of the time designated Jesus as "the Christ" because they believed him to be the messiah, whose arrival is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesus_and_messianic_prophecy" title="Jesus and messianic prophecy">prophesied</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> and Old Testament. In postbiblical usage, <i>Christ</i> became viewed as a name â one part of "Jesus Christ". <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/etymon" title="wikt:etymon">Etymons</a> of the term <i><a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christian</a></i> (meaning a follower of Christ) have been in use since the 1st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMillsBullard1998[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidgoq0VWw9rGICpgPA142_142]_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMillsBullard1998[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidgoq0VWw9rGICpgPA142_142]-82">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life_and_teachings_in_the_New_Testament">Life and teachings in the New Testament</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile nowraplinks"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle" style="background: #efefef">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Christianity" title="Category:Christianity">a series</a> on</td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle" style="background: #efefef"><a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><div style="display:inline-block;border-style: solid;padding: 3px;border-color: transparent;border-width: 0px;background-color: transparent;color: black;margin: 3px;"><a href="/wiki/Christian_cross" title="Principal symbol of Christianity"><img alt="Principal symbol of Christianity" data-file-height="564" data-file-width="404" decoding="async" height="70" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Christian_cross.svg/50px-Christian_cross.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Christian_cross.svg/75px-Christian_cross.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Christian_cross.svg/100px-Christian_cross.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></a></div></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">

<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="border-top:#0000b4 2px solid;font-size:105%;"><div class="sidebar-list-title-c">Issues</div></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">

<li><a href="/wiki/Council_of_Jerusalem" title="Council of Jerusalem">Council of Jerusalem</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Expounding_of_the_Law" title="Expounding of the Law">Expounding of the Law</a></li>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below" style="border-top:#0000b4 1px solid">
<div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="693" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Star_of_David.svg/14px-Star_of_David.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Star_of_David.svg/21px-Star_of_David.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Star_of_David.svg/28px-Star_of_David.svg.png 2x" width="14"/>Â <a href="/wiki/Portal:Judaism" title="Portal:Judaism">Judaism portal</a></li><li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P_christianity.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/16px-P_christianity.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/24px-P_christianity.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/32px-P_christianity.svg.png 2x" width="16"/></a>Â <a href="/wiki/Portal:Christianity" title="Portal:Christianity">Christianity portal</a></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Jewish_Christianity" title="Template:Jewish Christianity"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Jewish_Christianity" title="Template talk:Jewish Christianity"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Jewish_Christianity&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Life_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament" title="Life of Jesus in the New Testament">Life of Jesus in the New Testament</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Gospel" title="Gospel">Gospel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gospel_harmony" title="Gospel harmony">Gospel harmony</a>, <a href="/wiki/Historical_reliability_of_the_Gospels" title="Historical reliability of the Gospels">Historical reliability of the Gospels</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_consistency_of_the_New_Testament" title="Internal consistency of the New Testament">Internal consistency of the New Testament</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/New_Testament_places_associated_with_Jesus" title="New Testament places associated with Jesus">New Testament places associated with Jesus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament" title="Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament">Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P._Chester_Beatty_I,_folio_13-14,_recto.jpg"><img alt="A four-page papyrus manuscript, which is torn in many places" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="287" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/P._Chester_Beatty_I%2C_folio_13-14%2C_recto.jpg/260px-P._Chester_Beatty_I%2C_folio_13-14%2C_recto.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/P._Chester_Beatty_I%2C_folio_13-14%2C_recto.jpg/390px-P._Chester_Beatty_I%2C_folio_13-14%2C_recto.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/P._Chester_Beatty_I%2C_folio_13-14%2C_recto.jpg/520px-P._Chester_Beatty_I%2C_folio_13-14%2C_recto.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:P._Chester_Beatty_I,_folio_13-14,_recto.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 3rd-century Greek <a href="/wiki/Papyrus" title="Papyrus">papyrus</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke" title="Gospel of Luke">Gospel of Luke</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Canonical_gospels">Canonical gospels</span></h3>
<p>The four <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canonical_gospel" title="Canonical gospel">canonical gospels</a> (<a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Matthew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Mark" title="Gospel of Mark">Mark</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke" title="Gospel of Luke">Luke</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_John" title="Gospel of John">John</a>) are the foremost sources for the life and message of Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-1"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup> But other parts of the New Testament also include references to key episodes in his life, such as the <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a> in <a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_to_the_Corinthians" title="First Epistle to the Corinthians">1 Corinthians</a> <a href="/wiki/1_Corinthians_11" title="1 Corinthians 11">11</a>:23â26.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009441â42_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009441â42-84">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fahlbusch52_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fahlbusch52-85">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003465â77_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003465â77-86">[78]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[79]</a></sup> refers to Jesus' early ministry and its anticipation by <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bruce1988_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bruce1988-88">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERausch200377_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERausch200377-89">[81]</a></sup> Acts 1:1â11<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[82]</a></sup> says more about the Ascension of Jesus<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[83]</a></sup> than the canonical gospels do.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003521â30_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003521â30-92">[84]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Pauline_epistles#Authenticity" title="Pauline epistles">undisputed Pauline letters</a>, which were written earlier than the Gospels, Jesus' words or instructions are cited several times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[i]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">early Christian</a> groups had separate descriptions of Jesus' life and teachings that are not in the New Testament. These include the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Thomas" title="Gospel of Thomas">Gospel of Thomas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Peter" title="Gospel of Peter">Gospel of Peter</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Judas" title="Gospel of Judas">Gospel of Judas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Apocryphon_of_James" title="Apocryphon of James">Apocryphon of James</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_Testament_apocrypha" title="New Testament apocrypha">many other apocryphal writings</a>. Most scholars conclude that these were written much later and are less reliable accounts than the canonical gospels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown1997835â40_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown1997835â40-97">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeener200956_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeener200956-99">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>The canonical gospels are four accounts, each by a different author. The authors of the Gospels are all anonymous, attributed by tradition to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Four_evangelists" title="Four evangelists">four evangelists</a>, each with close ties to Jesus:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup> Mark by <a href="/wiki/John_Mark" title="John Mark">John Mark</a>, an associate of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Peter</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-May_Metzger_Mark_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-May_Metzger_Mark-101">[92]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Matthew_the_Apostle" title="Matthew the Apostle">Matthew</a> by one of Jesus' disciples;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Luke_the_Evangelist" title="Luke the Evangelist">Luke</a> by a companion of <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">Paul</a> mentioned in a few epistles;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup> and John by another of Jesus' disciples,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup> the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beloved_disciple" title="Beloved disciple">beloved disciple</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005John,_St._102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005John,_St.-102">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>One important aspect of the study of the Gospels is the <a href="/wiki/Literary_genre" title="Literary genre">literary genre</a> under which they fall. Genre "is a key convention guiding both the composition and the interpretation of writings".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[94]</a></sup> Whether the gospel authors set out to write novels, myths, histories, or biographies has a tremendous impact on how they ought to be interpreted. Some recent studies suggest that the genre of the Gospels ought to be situated within the realm of ancient <a href="/wiki/Biography" title="Biography">biography</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[97]</a></sup> Although not without critics,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[98]</a></sup> the position that the Gospels are a type of ancient biography is the consensus among scholars today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>Concerning the accuracy of the accounts, viewpoints run the gamut from considering them <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inerrancy" title="Inerrancy">inerrant</a> descriptions of Jesus' life,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrudem199490â91_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrudem199490â91-110">[101]</a></sup> to doubting whether they are historically reliable on a number of points,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders19933_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders19933-111">[102]</a></sup> to considering them to provide very little historical information about his life beyond the basics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009117â25_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009117â25-112">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman199922â23_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman199922â23-113">[104]</a></sup> According to a broad scholarly consensus, the <a href="/wiki/Synoptic_Gospels" title="Synoptic Gospels">Synoptic Gospels</a> (the first threeâMatthew, Mark, and Luke) are the most reliable sources of information about Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199371_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199371-114">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199817â62_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199817â62-115">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-2"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Marcan_priority" title="Marcan priority">Marcan priority</a>, the first to be written was the Gospel of Mark (written AD 60â75), followed by the Gospel of Matthew (AD 65â85), the Gospel of Luke (AD 65â95), and the Gospel of John (AD 75â100).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[107]</a></sup> Most scholars agree that the authors of Matthew and Luke used Mark as a source for their gospels. Since Matthew and Luke also share some content not found in Mark, many scholars assume that they used another source (commonly called the "<a href="/wiki/Q_source" title="Q source">Q source</a>") in addition to Mark.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELicona2010210â21_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELicona2010210â21-117">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>Matthew, Mark, and Luke are known as the Synoptic Gospels, from the Greek ÏÏÎ½ (<i>syn</i> "together") and á½ÏÎ¹Ï (<i>opsis</i> "view"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Synoptic_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-Synoptic-118">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Synoptic2_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-Synoptic2-119">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[111]</a></sup> because they are similar in content, narrative arrangement, language and paragraph structure, and one can easily set them next to each other and synoptically compare what is in them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Synoptic_118-1"><a href="#cite_note-Synoptic-118">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Synoptic2_119-1"><a href="#cite_note-Synoptic2-119">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[112]</a></sup> Scholars generally agree that it is impossible to find any direct literary relationship between the Synoptic Gospels and the Gospel of John.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moloney3_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-Moloney3-122">[113]</a></sup> While the flow of some events (such as Jesus' baptism, <a href="/wiki/Transfiguration_of_Jesus" title="Transfiguration of Jesus">transfiguration</a>, crucifixion and interactions with his <a href="/wiki/Apostles_in_the_New_Testament" title="Apostles in the New Testament">apostles</a>) are shared among the Synoptic Gospels, incidents such as the transfiguration do not appear in John, which also differs on other matters, such as the <a href="/wiki/Cleansing_of_the_Temple" title="Cleansing of the Temple">Cleansing of the Temple</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="font-size: 100%">

<th>Jesus in the Synoptic Gospels</th>
<th>Jesus in the Gospel of John
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>Begins with Jesus' baptism or birth to a virgin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Begins with <a href="/wiki/Creation_myth" title="Creation myth">creation</a>, with no birth story.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus' baptism by John the Baptist is mentioned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus' baptism presupposed but not mentioned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus teaches mostly in parables and aphorisms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-8"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus teaches mostly in long, involved discourses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-9"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus teaches primarily about the Kingdom of God, little about himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-10"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus teaches primarily and extensively about himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-11"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Mentions Jesus speaking up for the poor and oppressed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-12"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Does not mention much, if anything, about Jesus speaking up for the poor and oppressed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-13"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus exorcises demons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup></td>
<td>No mention of Jesus exorcising demons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus does not ritually wash his hands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup></td>
<td>Not clear whether Jesus and his disciples refrained from washing their hands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus' disciples do not fast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup></td>
<td>No mention of disciples not fasting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus' disciples pick grain on the Sabbath.</td>
<td>No mention of Jesus' disciples picking grain on the Sabbath.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus is transfigured.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus' transfiguration is not mentioned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>One episode of Jesus' attendance at Passover festival is mentioned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-numPassover_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-numPassover-125">[116]</a></sup></td>
<td>Three or four episodes of Jesus' attendance at Passover festival are mentioned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-numPassover_125-1"><a href="#cite_note-numPassover-125">[116]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Cleansing of the Temple occurs late in Jesus' ministry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-14"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Cleansing of the Temple is early in Jesus' ministry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-15"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus ushers in a new covenant with a last supper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-16"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus washes the disciples' feet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-17"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus prays to be spared his death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-18"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus shows no weakness in the face of death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-19"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus is identified/betrayed with a kiss.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-20"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus announces his identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-21"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Jesus is said to be arrested by Jewish leaders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-22"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus is said to be arrested by Roman and Temple guards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-23"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Simon of Cyrene helps Jesus carry his cross.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-24"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus carries his cross alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-25"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Temple curtain tears at Jesus' death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-26"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Jesus' side is pierced with a lance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-27"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Many women visit Jesus' tomb.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-28"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup></td>
<td>Only Mary Magdalene visits Jesus' tomb.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-29"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The Synoptics emphasize different aspects of Jesus. In Mark, Jesus is the <a href="/wiki/Son_of_God_(Christianity)" title="Son of God (Christianity)">Son of God</a> whose mighty works demonstrate the presence of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/God%27s_Kingdom" title="God's Kingdom">God's Kingdom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-May_Metzger_Mark_101-1"><a href="#cite_note-May_Metzger_Mark-101">[92]</a></sup> He is a tireless wonder worker, the servant of both God and man.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ThompsonPortraits_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-ThompsonPortraits-126">[117]</a></sup> This short gospel records few of Jesus' words or teachings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-May_Metzger_Mark_101-2"><a href="#cite_note-May_Metzger_Mark-101">[92]</a></sup> The Gospel of Matthew emphasizes that Jesus is the fulfillment of God's will as revealed in the Old Testament, and the Lord of the Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-May_Metzger_Matthew_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-May_Metzger_Matthew-127">[118]</a></sup> He is the "<a href="/wiki/Davidic_line" title="Davidic line">Son of David</a>", a "king", and the messiah.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ThompsonPortraits_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-ThompsonPortraits-126">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcGrath20064â6_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcGrath20064â6-128">[119]</a></sup> Luke presents Jesus as the divine-human savior who shows compassion to the needy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-May_Metzger_Luke_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-May_Metzger_Luke-129">[120]</a></sup> He is the friend of sinners and outcasts, come to seek and save the lost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ThompsonPortraits_126-2"><a href="#cite_note-ThompsonPortraits-126">[117]</a></sup> This gospel includes well-known parables, such as the <a href="/wiki/Parable_of_the_Good_Samaritan" title="Parable of the Good Samaritan">Good Samaritan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Parable_of_the_Prodigal_Son" title="Parable of the Prodigal Son">Prodigal Son</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-May_Metzger_Luke_129-1"><a href="#cite_note-May_Metzger_Luke-129">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/John_1:1" title="John 1:1">prologue to the Gospel of John</a> identifies Jesus as an incarnation of the divine Word (<a href="/wiki/Logos_(Christianity)" title="Logos (Christianity)">Logos</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MayMetzgerJohn_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-MayMetzgerJohn-130">[121]</a></sup> As the Word, Jesus was eternally present with God, active in all creation, and the source of humanity's moral and spiritual nature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MayMetzgerJohn_130-1"><a href="#cite_note-MayMetzgerJohn-130">[121]</a></sup> Jesus is not only greater than any past human prophet but greater than any prophet could be. He not only speaks God's Word; he is God's Word.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10-131">[122]</a></sup> In the Gospel of John, Jesus reveals his divine role publicly. Here he is the Bread of Life, the Light of the World, the True Vine and more.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ThompsonPortraits_126-3"><a href="#cite_note-ThompsonPortraits-126">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>In general, the authors of the New Testament showed little interest in an absolute chronology of Jesus or in synchronizing the episodes of his life with the secular history of the age.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahner2004730â31_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahner2004730â31-132">[123]</a></sup> As stated in <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/John#21:25" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/John">John 21:25</a>, the Gospels do not claim to provide an exhaustive list of the events in Jesus' life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[124]</a></sup> The accounts were primarily written as theological documents in the context of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">early Christianity</a>, with timelines as a secondary consideration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wiarda75_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wiarda75-134">[125]</a></sup> In this respect, it is noteworthy that the Gospels devote about one third of their text to the last week of Jesus' life in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, referred to as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Passion_(Christianity)" title="Passion (Christianity)">the Passion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turner613_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-Turner613-135">[126]</a></sup> The Gospels do not provide enough details to satisfy the demands of modern historians regarding exact dates, but it is possible to draw from them a general picture of Jesus' life story.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders19933_111-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders19933-111">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahner2004730â31_132-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahner2004730â31-132">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wiarda75_134-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wiarda75-134">[125]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Genealogy_and_nativity">Genealogy and nativity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Genealogy_of_Jesus" title="Genealogy of Jesus">Genealogy of Jesus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nativity_of_Jesus" title="Nativity of Jesus">Nativity of Jesus</a></div>
<p>Jesus was Jewish,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVermes198120,_26,_27,_29_14-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVermes198120,_26,_27,_29-14">[10]</a></sup> born to <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">Mary</a>, wife of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Joseph" title="Saint Joseph">Joseph</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[127]</a></sup> The Gospels of Matthew and Luke offer two accounts of his <a href="/wiki/Genealogy_of_Jesus" title="Genealogy of Jesus">genealogy</a>. Matthew traces Jesus' ancestry to <a href="/wiki/Abraham" title="Abraham">Abraham</a> through <a href="/wiki/David" title="David">David</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199380â91_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199380â91-138">[129]</a></sup> Luke traces Jesus' ancestry through <a href="/wiki/Adam" title="Adam">Adam</a> to God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown1978[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidML1mnUBwmhcCpgPA163_163]_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown1978[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidML1mnUBwmhcCpgPA163_163]-140">[131]</a></sup> The lists are identical between Abraham and David, but differ radically from that point. Matthew has 27 generations from David to Joseph, whereas Luke has 42, with almost no overlap between the names on the two lists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[j]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[132]</a></sup> Various theories have been put forward to explain why the two genealogies are so different.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[k]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gerard_van_Honthorst_-_Adoration_of_the_Shepherds_(1622).jpg"><img alt="A Nativity scene; men and animals surround Mary and newborn Jesus, who are covered in light" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1690" data-file-width="2057" decoding="async" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Gerard_van_Honthorst_-_Adoration_of_the_Shepherds_%281622%29.jpg/220px-Gerard_van_Honthorst_-_Adoration_of_the_Shepherds_%281622%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Gerard_van_Honthorst_-_Adoration_of_the_Shepherds_%281622%29.jpg/330px-Gerard_van_Honthorst_-_Adoration_of_the_Shepherds_%281622%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Gerard_van_Honthorst_-_Adoration_of_the_Shepherds_%281622%29.jpg/440px-Gerard_van_Honthorst_-_Adoration_of_the_Shepherds_%281622%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gerard_van_Honthorst_-_Adoration_of_the_Shepherds_(1622).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Adoration of the Shepherds</i> by <a href="/wiki/Gerard_van_Honthorst" title="Gerard van Honthorst">Gerard van Honthorst</a>, 1622</div></div></div>
<p>Matthew and Luke each describe Jesus' birth, especially that Jesus was born to a virgin named Mary in <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem">Bethlehem</a> in fulfillment of prophecy. Luke's account emphasizes events before the <a href="/wiki/Nativity_of_Jesus" title="Nativity of Jesus">birth of Jesus</a> and centers on Mary, while Matthew's mostly covers those after the birth and centers on Joseph.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMillsBullard1998556_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMillsBullard1998556-144">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marsh37_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-marsh37-145">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris199226_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris199226-146">[135]</a></sup> Both accounts state that Jesus was born to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Joseph" title="Saint Joseph">Joseph</a> and Mary, his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Betrothed" title="Betrothed">betrothed</a>, in Bethlehem, and both support the doctrine of the <a href="/wiki/Virgin_birth_of_Jesus" title="Virgin birth of Jesus">virgin birth of Jesus</a>, according to which Jesus was miraculously conceived by the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit" title="Holy Spirit">Holy Spirit</a> in Mary's womb when she was still a virgin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jeffrey_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jeffrey-147">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley200730â37_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley200730â37-148">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[138]</a></sup> At the same time, there is evidence, at least in the Lukan <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>, that Jesus was thought to have had, like many figures in antiquity, a dual paternity, since there it is stated he descended from the seed or loins of David.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[139]</a></sup> By taking him as his own, Joseph will give him the necessary Davidic descent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bellini-circumcision-NG1455-fm.jpg"><img alt="74.9 x 102.2 cm" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2217" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Bellini-circumcision-NG1455-fm.jpg/220px-Bellini-circumcision-NG1455-fm.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Bellini-circumcision-NG1455-fm.jpg/330px-Bellini-circumcision-NG1455-fm.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Bellini-circumcision-NG1455-fm.jpg/440px-Bellini-circumcision-NG1455-fm.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bellini-circumcision-NG1455-fm.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The Circumcision</i> by <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Bellini" title="Giovanni Bellini">Giovanni Bellini</a>, ~1500. The work depicts the <a href="/wiki/Circumcision_of_Jesus" title="Circumcision of Jesus">circumcision of Jesus</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In Matthew, Joseph is troubled because Mary, his betrothed, is pregnant,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[141]</a></sup> but in the first of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Joseph%27s_dream" title="St. Joseph's dream">Joseph's four dreams</a> an angel assures him not to be afraid to take Mary as his wife, because her child was conceived by the Holy Spirit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Talbert_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-Talbert-153">[142]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Matthew_2:1" title="Matthew 2:1">Matthew 2:1</a>â<a href="/wiki/Matthew_2:12" title="Matthew 2:12">12</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Magi" title="Biblical Magi">wise men</a> or <a href="/wiki/Magi" title="Magi">Magi</a> from the East bring gifts to the young Jesus as the <a href="/wiki/Jesus,_King_of_the_Jews" title="Jesus, King of the Jews">King of the Jews</a>. They find him in a house in Bethlehem. Jesus is now a child and not an infant. Matthew focuses on an event after the Luke Nativity where Jesus was an infant. In Matthew <a href="/wiki/Herod_the_Great" title="Herod the Great">Herod the Great</a> hears of Jesus' birth and, wanting him killed, <a href="/wiki/Massacre_of_the_Innocents" title="Massacre of the Innocents">orders the murders of male infants</a> in Bethlehem under age of 2. But an angel warns Joseph in his second dream, and the family <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flight_to_Egypt" title="Flight to Egypt">flees to Egypt</a>âlater to return and settle in <a href="/wiki/Nazareth" title="Nazareth">Nazareth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Talbert_153-1"><a href="#cite_note-Talbert-153">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985272â85_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985272â85-154">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[144]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Luke 1:31â38, Mary learns from the angel <a href="/wiki/Gabriel" title="Gabriel">Gabriel</a> that she will conceive and bear a child called Jesus through the action of the Holy Spirit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marsh37_145-1"><a href="#cite_note-marsh37-145">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jeffrey_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jeffrey-147">[136]</a></sup> When Mary is due to give birth, she and Joseph travel from Nazareth to Joseph's ancestral home in Bethlehem to register in the census ordered by <a href="/wiki/Augustus" title="Augustus">Caesar Augustus</a>. While there Mary gives birth to Jesus, and as they have found no room in the inn, she places the newborn in a <a href="/wiki/Manger" title="Manger">manger</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[145]</a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Annunciation_to_the_shepherds" title="Annunciation to the shepherds">angel announces the birth to a group of shepherds</a>, who go to Bethlehem to see Jesus, and subsequently spread the news abroad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[146]</a></sup> Luke 2:21 tells how Joseph and Mary <a href="/wiki/Circumcision_of_Jesus" title="Circumcision of Jesus">have their baby circumcised on the eighth day after birth</a>, and name him Jesus, as Gabriel had commanded Mary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/Presentation_of_Jesus_at_the_Temple" title="Presentation of Jesus at the Temple">presentation of Jesus at the Temple</a>, Joseph, Mary and Jesus return to Nazareth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marsh37_145-2"><a href="#cite_note-marsh37-145">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jeffrey_147-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jeffrey-147">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Early_life.2C_family.2C_and_profession"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life,_family,_and_profession">Early life, family, and profession</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Christ_Child" title="Christ Child">Christ Child</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Return_of_the_family_of_Jesus_to_Nazareth" title="Return of the family of Jesus to Nazareth">Return of the family of Jesus to Nazareth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Unknown_years_of_Jesus" title="Unknown years of Jesus">Unknown years of Jesus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Brothers_of_Jesus" title="Brothers of Jesus">Brothers of Jesus</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:William_Holman_Hunt_-_The_Finding_of_the_Saviour_in_the_Temple_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg"><img alt="Mary and Joseph find Jesus in the Temple" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5429" data-file-width="8859" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/William_Holman_Hunt_-_The_Finding_of_the_Saviour_in_the_Temple_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/260px-William_Holman_Hunt_-_The_Finding_of_the_Saviour_in_the_Temple_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/William_Holman_Hunt_-_The_Finding_of_the_Saviour_in_the_Temple_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/390px-William_Holman_Hunt_-_The_Finding_of_the_Saviour_in_the_Temple_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/William_Holman_Hunt_-_The_Finding_of_the_Saviour_in_the_Temple_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/520px-William_Holman_Hunt_-_The_Finding_of_the_Saviour_in_the_Temple_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:William_Holman_Hunt_-_The_Finding_of_the_Saviour_in_the_Temple_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Finding_of_the_Saviour_in_the_Temple" title="The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple">The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple</a></i>, by <a href="/wiki/William_Holman_Hunt" title="William Holman Hunt">William Holman Hunt</a>, 1860</div></div></div>
<p>Jesus' childhood home is identified in the Gospels of Luke and Matthew as the town of Nazareth in <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a>, where he lived with his family. Although Joseph appears in descriptions of Jesus' childhood, no mention is made of him thereafter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[148]</a></sup> His other family membersâhis mother, Mary, <a href="/wiki/Brothers_of_Jesus" title="Brothers of Jesus">his brothers</a> <a href="/wiki/James,_brother_of_Jesus" title="James, brother of Jesus">James</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joses,_brother_of_Jesus" title="Joses, brother of Jesus">Joses (or Joseph)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jude,_brother_of_Jesus" title="Jude, brother of Jesus">Judas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Simon,_brother_of_Jesus" title="Simon, brother of Jesus">Simon</a> and his unnamed sistersâare mentioned in the Gospels and other sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aslan2013_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-Aslan2013-160">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Gospel of Mark reports that Jesus comes into conflict with his neighbors and family.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72-161">[150]</a></sup> Jesus' mother and brothers come to get him<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[151]</a></sup> because people are saying that <a href="/wiki/Mental_health_of_Jesus" title="Mental health of Jesus">he is crazy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[152]</a></sup> Jesus responds that his followers are his true family. In John, Mary follows Jesus to his crucifixion, and he expresses concern over her well-being.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jesus is called a ÏÎ­ÎºÏÏÎ½ (<i><a href="/wiki/Tekt%C5%8Dn" title="TektÅn">tektÅn</a></i>) in <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/Mark#6:3" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/Mark">Mark 6:3</a>, traditionally understood as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carpenter" title="Carpenter">carpenter</a> but it could cover makers of objects in various materials, including builders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[154]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDickson200868â69_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDickson200868â69-166">[155]</a></sup> The Gospels indicate that Jesus could read, paraphrase, and debate scripture, but this does not necessarily mean that he received formal scribal training.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-literacy_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-literacy-167">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>When Jesus is presented as a baby in the temple per Jewish Law, a man named <a href="/wiki/Simeon_(Gospel_of_Luke)" title="Simeon (Gospel of Luke)">Simeon</a> says to Mary and Joseph that Jesus "shall stand as a sign of contradiction, while a sword will pierce your own soul. Then the secret thoughts of many will come to light."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[157]</a></sup> Several years later, when Jesus goes missing on a visit to <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, his parents <a href="/wiki/Finding_in_the_Temple" title="Finding in the Temple">find him in the temple</a> sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking questions, and the people are amazed at his understanding and answers; Mary scolds Jesus for going missing, to which Jesus replies that he must "be in his father's house".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Baptism_and_temptation">Baptism and temptation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Jesus" title="Baptism of Jesus">Baptism of Jesus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Temptation_of_Christ" title="Temptation of Christ">Temptation of Christ</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:El_bautismo_de_Jes%C3%BAs,_por_Jos%C3%A9_Ferraz_de_Almeida_J%C3%BAnior.jpg"><img alt="Jesus is baptised by John.
