The Holy Spirit in the form of a dove is overhead." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1890" data-file-width="1222" decoding="async" height="278" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/El_bautismo_de_Jes%C3%BAs%2C_por_Jos%C3%A9_Ferraz_de_Almeida_J%C3%BAnior.jpg/180px-El_bautismo_de_Jes%C3%BAs%2C_por_Jos%C3%A9_Ferraz_de_Almeida_J%C3%BAnior.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/El_bautismo_de_Jes%C3%BAs%2C_por_Jos%C3%A9_Ferraz_de_Almeida_J%C3%BAnior.jpg/270px-El_bautismo_de_Jes%C3%BAs%2C_por_Jos%C3%A9_Ferraz_de_Almeida_J%C3%BAnior.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/El_bautismo_de_Jes%C3%BAs%2C_por_Jos%C3%A9_Ferraz_de_Almeida_J%C3%BAnior.jpg/360px-El_bautismo_de_Jes%C3%BAs%2C_por_Jos%C3%A9_Ferraz_de_Almeida_J%C3%BAnior.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:El_bautismo_de_Jes%C3%BAs,_por_Jos%C3%A9_Ferraz_de_Almeida_J%C3%BAnior.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Jesus" title="Baptism of Jesus">The Baptism of Christ</a> by <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a></i>, by <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Ferraz_de_Almeida_J%C3%BAnior" title="JosÃ© Ferraz de Almeida JÃºnior">JosÃ© Ferraz de Almeida JÃºnior</a>, 1895</div></div></div>
<p>The Synoptic accounts of Jesus' baptism are all preceded by information about <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009224â29_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009224â29-170">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009141â43_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009141â43-171">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcGrath200616â22_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcGrath200616â22-172">[161]</a></sup> They show John preaching penance and repentance for the remission of sins and encouraging the giving of <a href="/wiki/Alms" title="Alms">alms</a> to the poor<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[162]</a></sup> as he baptizes people in the area of the <a href="/wiki/Jordan_River" title="Jordan River">Jordan River</a> around <a href="/wiki/Perea" title="Perea">Perea</a> and foretells<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[163]</a></sup> the arrival of someone "more powerful" than he.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EerRoger_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-EerRoger-175">[164]</a></sup> Later, Jesus identifies John as "the Elijah who was to come",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[165]</a></sup> the prophet who was expected to arrive before the "great and terrible day of the Lord".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[166]</a></sup> Likewise, <a href="/wiki/Luke_the_Evangelist" title="Luke the Evangelist">Luke</a> says that John had the spirit and power of <a href="/wiki/Elijah" title="Elijah">Elijah</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Mark" title="Gospel of Mark">Gospel of Mark</a>, John the Baptist baptizes Jesus, and as he comes out of the water he sees the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit" title="Holy Spirit">Holy Spirit</a> descending to him like a dove and he hears a voice from heaven declaring him to be God's Son.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[168]</a></sup> This is one of two events described in the Gospels where a voice from Heaven calls Jesus "Son", the other being the <a href="/wiki/Transfiguration_of_Jesus" title="Transfiguration of Jesus">Transfiguration</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELee200421â30_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee200421â30-180">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nobbs_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nobbs-181">[170]</a></sup> The spirit then drives him into the wilderness where he is tempted by <a href="/wiki/Satan" title="Satan">Satan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[171]</a></sup> Jesus then begins his ministry after John's arrest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[172]</a></sup> Jesus' baptism in the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Gospel of Matthew</a> is similar. Here, before Jesus' baptism, John protests, saying, "I need to be baptized by you."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[173]</a></sup> Jesus instructs him to carry on with the baptism "to fulfill all righteousness".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[174]</a></sup> Matthew also details the <a href="/wiki/Temptation_of_Christ" title="Temptation of Christ">three temptations</a> that Satan offers Jesus in the wilderness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[175]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke" title="Gospel of Luke">Gospel of Luke</a>, the Holy Spirit descends as a dove after everyone has been baptized and Jesus is praying.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[176]</a></sup> John implicitly recognizes Jesus from prison after sending his followers to ask about him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[177]</a></sup> Jesus' baptism and temptation serve as preparation for his public ministry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Gospel of John leaves out Jesus' baptism and temptation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ-190">[179]</a></sup> Here, John the Baptist testifies that he saw the Spirit descend on Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoringCraddock2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidN0tLXRIiIe0CpgPA292_292]_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoringCraddock2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidN0tLXRIiIe0CpgPA292_292]-192">[181]</a></sup> John publicly proclaims Jesus as the sacrificial <a href="/wiki/Lamb_of_God" title="Lamb of God">Lamb of God</a>, and some of John's followers become disciples of Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199817â62_115-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199817â62-115">[106]</a></sup> In this Gospel, John denies that he is Elijah.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[182]</a></sup> Before John is imprisoned, Jesus leads his followers to baptize disciples as well,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[183]</a></sup> and they baptize more people than John.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[184]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_ministry"><span class="anchor" id="Ministry"></span> Public ministry</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Jesus" title="Ministry of Jesus">Ministry of Jesus</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bloch-SermonOnTheMount.jpg"><img alt="Jesus sits atop a mount, preaching to a crowd" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1545" data-file-width="1377" decoding="async" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Bloch-SermonOnTheMount.jpg/180px-Bloch-SermonOnTheMount.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Bloch-SermonOnTheMount.jpg/270px-Bloch-SermonOnTheMount.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Bloch-SermonOnTheMount.jpg/360px-Bloch-SermonOnTheMount.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bloch-SermonOnTheMount.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Sermon on the Mount</i>, by <a href="/wiki/Carl_Bloch" title="Carl Bloch">Carl Bloch</a>, 1877, depicts <a href="/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Mount" title="Sermon on the Mount">Jesus' important discourse</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Synoptics depict two distinct geographical settings in Jesus' ministry. The first takes place north of <a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a>, where Jesus conducts a successful ministry, and the second shows Jesus rejected and killed when he travels to <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ISBEO_28-1"><a href="#cite_note-ISBEO-28">[22]</a></sup> Often referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Rabbi" title="Rabbi">rabbi</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ISBEO_28-2"><a href="#cite_note-ISBEO-28">[22]</a></sup> Jesus preaches his message orally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dunn2013_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dunn2013-27">[21]</a></sup> Notably, Jesus forbids those who recognize him as the messiah to speak of it, including people he heals and demons he exorcises (see <a href="/wiki/Messianic_Secret" title="Messianic Secret">Messianic Secret</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985285â96_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985285â96-196">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>John depicts Jesus' ministry as largely taking place in and around Jerusalem, rather than in Galilee; and Jesus' divine identity is openly proclaimed and immediately recognized.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10_131-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10-131">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>Scholars divide the ministry of Jesus into several stages. The Galilean ministry begins when Jesus returns to Galilee from the <a href="/wiki/Judaean_Desert" title="Judaean Desert">Judaean Desert</a> after rebuffing the temptation of <a href="/wiki/Satan" title="Satan">Satan</a>. Jesus preaches around Galilee, and in <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/Matthew#4:18" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/Matthew">Matthew 4:18â20</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_disciples_of_Jesus" title="First disciples of Jesus">his first disciples</a>, who will eventually form the core of the early Church, encounter him and begin to travel with him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcGrath200616â22_172-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcGrath200616â22-172">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERedford2007117â30_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERedford2007117â30-197">[186]</a></sup> This period includes the <a href="/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Mount" title="Sermon on the Mount">Sermon on the Mount</a>, one of Jesus' major discourses,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERedford2007117â30_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERedford2007117â30-197">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[187]</a></sup> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Calming_the_storm" title="Calming the storm">calming of the storm</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Feeding_the_multitude" title="Feeding the multitude">feeding of the 5,000</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jesus_walking_on_water" title="Jesus walking on water">walking on water</a> and a number of other miracles and <a href="/wiki/Parables_of_Jesus" title="Parables of Jesus">parables</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERedford2007143â60_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERedford2007143â60-199">[188]</a></sup> It ends with the <a href="/wiki/Confession_of_Peter" title="Confession of Peter">Confession of Peter</a> and the Transfiguration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[189]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barton132_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-Barton132-201">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>As Jesus travels towards Jerusalem, in the <a href="/wiki/Perea" title="Perea">Perean</a> ministry, he returns to the area where he was baptized, about a third of the way down from the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Jordan_River" title="Jordan River">Jordan River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007137_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007137-203">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERedford2007211â29_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERedford2007211â29-204">[193]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Jesus#Final_ministry_in_Jerusalem" title="Ministry of Jesus">final ministry in Jerusalem</a> begins with Jesus' <a href="/wiki/Triumphal_entry_into_Jerusalem" title="Triumphal entry into Jerusalem">triumphal entry</a> into the city on <a href="/wiki/Palm_Sunday" title="Palm Sunday">Palm Sunday</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70-205">[194]</a></sup> In the Synoptic Gospels, during that week Jesus <a href="/wiki/Cleansing_of_the_Temple" title="Cleansing of the Temple">drives the money changers</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">Second Temple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bargain_of_Judas" title="Bargain of Judas">Judas bargains to betray</a> him. This period culminates in the <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Farewell_Discourse" title="Farewell Discourse">Farewell Discourse</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009224â29_170-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009224â29-170">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70_205-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70-205">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERedford2007257â74_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERedford2007257â74-206">[195]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Disciples_and_followers">Disciples and followers</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brooklyn_Museum_-_The_Exhortation_to_the_Apostles_(Recommandation_aux_ap%C3%B4tres)_-_James_Tissot.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1128" data-file-width="1507" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Brooklyn_Museum_-_The_Exhortation_to_the_Apostles_%28Recommandation_aux_ap%C3%B4tres%29_-_James_Tissot.jpg/220px-Brooklyn_Museum_-_The_Exhortation_to_the_Apostles_%28Recommandation_aux_ap%C3%B4tres%29_-_James_Tissot.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Brooklyn_Museum_-_The_Exhortation_to_the_Apostles_%28Recommandation_aux_ap%C3%B4tres%29_-_James_Tissot.jpg/330px-Brooklyn_Museum_-_The_Exhortation_to_the_Apostles_%28Recommandation_aux_ap%C3%B4tres%29_-_James_Tissot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Brooklyn_Museum_-_The_Exhortation_to_the_Apostles_%28Recommandation_aux_ap%C3%B4tres%29_-_James_Tissot.jpg/440px-Brooklyn_Museum_-_The_Exhortation_to_the_Apostles_%28Recommandation_aux_ap%C3%B4tres%29_-_James_Tissot.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Brooklyn_Museum_-_The_Exhortation_to_the_Apostles_(Recommandation_aux_ap%C3%B4tres)_-_James_Tissot.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The Exhortation to the Apostles</i>, by <a href="/wiki/James_Tissot" title="James Tissot">James Tissot</a>, portrays Jesus talking to his 12 disciples</div></div></div>
<p>Near the beginning of his ministry, Jesus <a href="/wiki/Commissioning_of_the_Twelve_Apostles" title="Commissioning of the Twelve Apostles">appoints twelve apostles</a>. In Matthew and Mark, despite Jesus only briefly requesting that they join him, Jesus' first four apostles, who were fishermen, are described as immediately consenting, and abandoning their nets and boats to do so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[196]</a></sup> In John, Jesus' first two apostles were disciples of John the Baptist. The Baptist sees Jesus and calls him the <a href="/wiki/Lamb_of_God" title="Lamb of God">Lamb of God</a>; the two hear this and follow Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown198825â27_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown198825â27-208">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoringCraddock2004292â93_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoringCraddock2004292â93-209">[198]</a></sup> In addition to the Twelve Apostles, the opening of the passage of the <a href="/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Plain" title="Sermon on the Plain">Sermon on the Plain</a> identifies a much larger group of people as disciples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[199]</a></sup> Also, in <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/Luke#10:1" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/Luke">Luke 10:1â16</a> Jesus sends <a href="/wiki/Seventy_disciples" title="Seventy disciples">70 or 72 of his followers</a> in pairs to prepare towns for his prospective visit. They are instructed to accept hospitality, heal the sick and spread the word that the <a href="/wiki/Kingship_and_kingdom_of_God" title="Kingship and kingdom of God">Kingdom of God</a> is coming.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Mark, the disciples are notably obtuse. They fail to understand Jesus' miracles,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[201]</a></sup> his parables,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[202]</a></sup> or what "rising from the dead" means.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[203]</a></sup> When Jesus is later arrested, they desert him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985285â96_196-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985285â96-196">[185]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Teachings_and_miracles"><span class="anchor" id="Teachings_and_preachings"></span> Teachings and miracles</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Mount" title="Sermon on the Mount">Sermon on the Mount</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parables_of_Jesus" title="Parables of Jesus">Parables of Jesus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Miracles_of_Jesus" title="Miracles of Jesus">Miracles of Jesus</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Plain" title="Sermon on the Plain">Sermon on the Plain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Five_Discourses_of_Matthew" title="Five Discourses of Matthew">Five Discourses of Matthew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Farewell_Discourse" title="Farewell Discourse">Farewell Discourse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olivet_Discourse" title="Olivet Discourse">Olivet Discourse</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bread_of_Life_Discourse" title="Bread of Life Discourse">Bread of Life Discourse</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hoffman-ChristAndTheRichYoungRuler.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3412" data-file-width="4324" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Hoffman-ChristAndTheRichYoungRuler.jpg/220px-Hoffman-ChristAndTheRichYoungRuler.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Hoffman-ChristAndTheRichYoungRuler.jpg/330px-Hoffman-ChristAndTheRichYoungRuler.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Hoffman-ChristAndTheRichYoungRuler.jpg/440px-Hoffman-ChristAndTheRichYoungRuler.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hoffman-ChristAndTheRichYoungRuler.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Jesus_and_the_rich_young_man" title="Jesus and the rich young man">Jesus and the rich young man</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Heinrich_Hofmann_(painter)" title="Heinrich Hofmann (painter)">Heinrich Hofmann</a>, 1889</div></div></div>
<p>In the Synoptics, Jesus teaches extensively, often in <a href="/wiki/Parable" title="Parable">parables</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998316â46_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998316â46-215">[204]</a></sup> about the Kingdom of God (or, in Matthew, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Heaven_(Gospel_of_Matthew)" title="Kingdom of Heaven (Gospel of Matthew)">Kingdom of Heaven</a>). The Kingdom is described as both imminent<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[205]</a></sup> and already present in the ministry of Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[206]</a></sup> Jesus promises inclusion in the Kingdom for those who accept his message.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[207]</a></sup> He talks of the "<a href="/wiki/Son_of_man" title="Son of man">Son of Man</a>", an <a href="/wiki/Apocalypse" title="Apocalypse">apocalyptic</a> figure who will come to gather the chosen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-3"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jesus calls people to repent their sins and to devote themselves completely to God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-4"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup> He tells his followers to adhere to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_law" title="Jewish law">Jewish law</a>, although he is perceived by some to have broken the law himself, for example regarding the <a href="/wiki/Sabbath" title="Sabbath">Sabbath</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-5"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup> When asked what the greatest commandment is, Jesus replies: "You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your mind ... And a second is like it: 'You shall love your neighbor as yourself.<span style="padding-right:.15em;">'</span>"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[208]</a></sup> Other ethical teachings of Jesus include <a href="/wiki/Matthew_5:44" title="Matthew 5:44">loving your enemies</a>, refraining from hatred and lust, <a href="/wiki/Turning_the_other_cheek" title="Turning the other cheek">turning the other cheek</a>, and forgiving people who have sinned against you.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>John's Gospel presents the teachings of Jesus not merely as his own preaching, but as divine <a href="/wiki/Revelation" title="Revelation">revelation</a>. John the Baptist, for example, states in <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/John#3:34" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/John">John 3:34</a>: "He whom God has sent speaks the words of God, for he gives the Spirit without measure." In <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/John#7:16" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/John">John 7:16</a> Jesus says, "My teaching is not mine but his who sent me." He asserts the same thing in <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/John#14:10" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/John">John 14:10</a>: "Do you not believe that I am in the Father and the Father is in me? The words that I say to you I do not speak on my own; but the Father who dwells in me does his works."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated98_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated98-222">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[212]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pompeo_Batoni_003.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3519" data-file-width="2531" decoding="async" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Pompeo_Batoni_003.jpg/180px-Pompeo_Batoni_003.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Pompeo_Batoni_003.jpg/270px-Pompeo_Batoni_003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Pompeo_Batoni_003.jpg/360px-Pompeo_Batoni_003.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pompeo_Batoni_003.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The Return of the Prodigal Son</i> by Pompeo Batoni depicts the <a href="/wiki/Parable_of_the_Prodigal_Son" title="Parable of the Prodigal Son">Parable of the Prodigal Son</a>. Jesus told many <a href="/wiki/Parables_of_Jesus" title="Parables of Jesus">parables</a> during his ministry.</div></div></div>
<p>Approximately 30 parables form about one third of Jesus' recorded teachings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated98_222-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated98-222">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[213]</a></sup> The parables appear within longer sermons and at other places in the narrative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[214]</a></sup> They often contain symbolism, and usually relate the physical world to the <a href="/wiki/Spirituality" title="Spirituality">spiritual</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[216]</a></sup> Common themes in these tales include the kindness and generosity of God and the perils of transgression.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[217]</a></sup> Some of his parables, such as the <a href="/wiki/Parable_of_the_Prodigal_Son" title="Parable of the Prodigal Son">Prodigal Son</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[218]</a></sup> are relatively simple, while others, such as the <a href="/wiki/Parable_of_the_Growing_Seed" title="Parable of the Growing Seed">Growing Seed</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[219]</a></sup> are sophisticated, profound and abstruse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[220]</a></sup> When asked by his disciples why he speaks in parables to the people, Jesus replies that the chosen disciples have been given to "know the secrets of the kingdom of heaven", unlike the rest of their people, "For the one who has will be given more and he will have in abundance. But the one who does not have will be deprived even more", going on to say that the majority of their generation have grown "dull hearts" and thus are unable to understand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[221]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Christ_cleans_leper_man.jpg"><img alt="Jesus, his head surrounded by a halo, puts his hands on a leper, thereby healing him" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="985" data-file-width="689" decoding="async" height="257" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Christ_cleans_leper_man.jpg/180px-Christ_cleans_leper_man.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Christ_cleans_leper_man.jpg/270px-Christ_cleans_leper_man.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Christ_cleans_leper_man.jpg/360px-Christ_cleans_leper_man.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Christ_cleans_leper_man.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Jesus_cleansing_a_leper" title="Jesus cleansing a leper">Jesus cleansing a leper</a>, medieval <a href="/wiki/Mosaic" title="Mosaic">mosaic</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Monreale_Cathedral" title="Monreale Cathedral">Monreale Cathedral</a>, late 12th to mid-13th centuries</div></div></div>
<p>In the gospel accounts, Jesus devotes a large portion of his ministry performing <a href="/wiki/Miracle" title="Miracle">miracles</a>, especially healings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreenMcKnightMarshall1992299_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreenMcKnightMarshall1992299-233">[222]</a></sup> The miracles can be classified into two main categories: healing miracles and nature miracles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwelftree1999350_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwelftree1999350-234">[223]</a></sup> The healing miracles include cures for physical ailments, <a href="/wiki/Exorcism" title="Exorcism">exorcisms</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-8"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998298_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998298-235">[224]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Miracles_of_Jesus#Resurrection_of_the_dead" title="Miracles of Jesus">resurrections of the dead</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreenMcKnightMarshall1992300_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreenMcKnightMarshall1992300-236">[225]</a></sup> The nature miracles show Jesus' power over nature, and include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turning_water_into_wine" title="Turning water into wine">turning water into wine</a>, walking on water, and calming a storm, among others. Jesus states that his miracles are from a divine source. When his opponents suddenly accuse him of performing exorcisms by the power of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beelzebul" title="Beelzebul">Beelzebul</a>, the prince of demons, Jesus counters that he performs them by the "Spirit of God" (<a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/Matthew#12:28" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/Matthew">Matthew 12:28</a>) or "finger of God", arguing that all logic suggests that Satan would not let his demons assist the Children of God because it would divide Satan's house and bring his kingdom to desolation; furthermore, he asks his opponents that if he exorcises by <a href="/wiki/Beelzebub" title="Beelzebub">Beel'zebub</a>, "by whom do your sons cast them out?"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica2_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica2-238">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[228]</a></sup> In <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/Matthew#12:28" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/Matthew">Matthew 12:31â32</a>, he goes on to say that while all manner of sin, "even insults against God" or "insults against the son of man", shall be forgiven, whoever insults goodness (or "The <a href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit" title="Holy Spirit">Holy Spirit</a>") shall never be forgiven; they carry the guilt of their sin forever.
</p><p>In John, Jesus' miracles are described as "signs", performed to prove his mission and divinity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sign_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sign-240">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman2009[httpsarchiveorgdetailsjesusinterrupted00ehrm_0page84_84]_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman2009[httpsarchiveorgdetailsjesusinterrupted00ehrm_0page84_84]-241">[230]</a></sup> In the Synoptics, when asked by some teachers of the Law and some Pharisees to give miraculous signs to prove his authority, Jesus refuses,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sign_240-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sign-240">[229]</a></sup> saying that no sign shall come to corrupt and evil people except the sign of the prophet <a href="/wiki/Jonah" title="Jonah">Jonah</a>. Also, in the Synoptic Gospels, the crowds regularly respond to Jesus' miracles with awe and press on him to heal their sick. In John's Gospel, Jesus is presented as unpressured by the crowds, who often respond to his miracles with trust and faith.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwelftree1999236_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwelftree1999236-242">[231]</a></sup> One characteristic shared among all miracles of Jesus in the gospel accounts is that he performed them freely and never requested or accepted any form of payment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[232]</a></sup> The gospel episodes that include descriptions of the miracles of Jesus also often include teachings, and the miracles themselves involve an element of teaching.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WPent212_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-WPent212-244">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwelftree199995_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwelftree199995-245">[234]</a></sup> Many of the miracles teach the importance of faith. In the <a href="/wiki/Cleansing_ten_lepers" title="Cleansing ten lepers">cleansing of ten lepers</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Daughter_of_Jairus" title="Daughter of Jairus">raising of Jairus's daughter</a>, for instance, the beneficiaries are told that their healing was due to their faith.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonahueHarrington2002182_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonahueHarrington2002182-246">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[236]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Proclamation_as_Christ_and_Transfiguration">Proclamation as Christ and Transfiguration</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Confession_of_Peter" title="Confession of Peter">Confession of Peter</a> and <a href="/wiki/Transfiguration_of_Jesus" title="Transfiguration of Jesus">Transfiguration of Jesus</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Transfigurationbloch.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="912" data-file-width="734" decoding="async" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Transfigurationbloch.jpg/180px-Transfigurationbloch.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Transfigurationbloch.jpg/270px-Transfigurationbloch.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Transfigurationbloch.jpg/360px-Transfigurationbloch.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Transfigurationbloch.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Transfiguration_of_Jesus" title="Transfiguration of Jesus">Transfiguration of Jesus</a>, depicted by <a href="/wiki/Carl_Bloch" title="Carl Bloch">Carl Bloch</a>, 19th century</div></div></div>
<p>At about the middle of each of the three Synoptic Gospels are two significant events: the Confession of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Peter</a> and the Transfiguration of Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barton132_201-1"><a href="#cite_note-Barton132-201">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KingsburyMark_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-KingsburyMark-248">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELee200421â30_180-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee200421â30-180">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nobbs_181-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nobbs-181">[170]</a></sup> These two events are not mentioned in the Gospel of John.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005John,_Gospel_of_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005John,_Gospel_of-249">[238]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his Confession, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Peter</a> tells Jesus, "You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Karris_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-Karris-250">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonahueHarrington2002336_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonahueHarrington2002336-252">[241]</a></sup> Jesus affirms that Peter's confession is divinely revealed truth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OneTeacher_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-OneTeacher-253">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPannenberg196853â54_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPannenberg196853â54-254">[243]</a></sup> After the confession, Jesus tells his disciples about his upcoming death and resurrection.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Transfiguration,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELee200421â30_180-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee200421â30-180">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nobbs_181-2"><a href="#cite_note-Nobbs-181">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barton132_201-2"><a href="#cite_note-Barton132-201">[190]</a></sup> Jesus takes Peter and two other apostles up an unnamed mountain, where "he was transfigured before them, and his face shone like the sun, and his clothes became dazzling white."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELee200472â76_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee200472â76-257">[246]</a></sup> A bright cloud appears around them, and a voice from the cloud says, "This is my Son, the Beloved; with him I am well pleased; listen to him."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELee200421â30_180-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee200421â30-180">[169]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Passion_Week">Passion Week</span></h3>
<p>The description of the last week of the life of Jesus (often called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Passion_Week" title="Passion Week">Passion Week</a>) occupies about one third of the narrative in the canonical gospels,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turner613_135-1"><a href="#cite_note-Turner613-135">[126]</a></sup> starting with Jesus' <a href="/wiki/Triumphal_entry_into_Jerusalem" title="Triumphal entry into Jerusalem">triumphal entry into Jerusalem</a> and ending with his Crucifixion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009224â29_170-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009224â29-170">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70_205-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70-205">[194]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Activities_in_Jerusalem">Activities in Jerusalem</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_-_L%27entr%C3%A9e_du_Christ_%C3%A0_J%C3%A9rusalem_-_cadre.jpg"><img alt="Jesus, riding a donkey colt, rides towards Jerusalem. A large crowd greets him outside the walls." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1422" data-file-width="2191" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_-_L%27entr%C3%A9e_du_Christ_%C3%A0_J%C3%A9rusalem_-_cadre.jpg/260px-G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_-_L%27entr%C3%A9e_du_Christ_%C3%A0_J%C3%A9rusalem_-_cadre.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_-_L%27entr%C3%A9e_du_Christ_%C3%A0_J%C3%A9rusalem_-_cadre.jpg/390px-G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_-_L%27entr%C3%A9e_du_Christ_%C3%A0_J%C3%A9rusalem_-_cadre.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_-_L%27entr%C3%A9e_du_Christ_%C3%A0_J%C3%A9rusalem_-_cadre.jpg/520px-G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_-_L%27entr%C3%A9e_du_Christ_%C3%A0_J%C3%A9rusalem_-_cadre.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_-_L%27entr%C3%A9e_du_Christ_%C3%A0_J%C3%A9rusalem_-_cadre.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A painting of Jesus' <a href="/wiki/Triumphal_entry_into_Jerusalem" title="Triumphal entry into Jerusalem">final entry into Jerusalem</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me" title="Jean-LÃ©on GÃ©rÃ´me">Jean-LÃ©on GÃ©rÃ´me</a>, 1897</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Triumphal_entry_into_Jerusalem" title="Triumphal entry into Jerusalem">Triumphal entry into Jerusalem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cleansing_of_the_Temple" title="Cleansing of the Temple">Cleansing of the Temple</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bargain_of_Judas" title="Bargain of Judas">Bargain of Judas</a></div>
<p>In the Synoptics, the last week in Jerusalem is the conclusion of the journey through Perea and <a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a> that Jesus began in Galilee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70_205-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70-205">[194]</a></sup> Jesus rides a young donkey into Jerusalem, reflecting the tale of <a href="/wiki/The_Messiah%27s_Donkey" title="The Messiah's Donkey">the Messiah's Donkey</a>, an oracle from the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Zechariah" title="Book of Zechariah">Book of Zechariah</a> in which the Jews' humble king enters Jerusalem this way.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-May_Metzger_Mark_101-3"><a href="#cite_note-May_Metzger_Mark-101">[92]</a></sup> People along the way lay cloaks and small branches of trees (known as palm fronds) in front of him and sing part of Psalms 118:25-26.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoringCraddock2004256â58_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoringCraddock2004256â58-261">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMajernÃ­kPonessaManhardt2005133â34_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMajernÃ­kPonessaManhardt2005133â34-262">[251]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003381â95_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003381â95-263">[252]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jesus next expels the money changers from the <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">Second Temple</a>, accusing them of turning it into a den of thieves through their commercial activities. He then prophecies about the coming destruction, including false prophets, wars, earthquakes, celestial disorders, persecution of the faithful, the appearance of an "abomination of desolation", and unendurable tribulations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[253]</a></sup> The mysterious "Son of Man", he says, will dispatch angels to gather the faithful from all parts of the earth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[254]</a></sup> Jesus warns that these wonders will occur in the lifetimes of the hearers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985285â96_196-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985285â96-196">[185]</a></sup> In John, the Cleansing of the Temple occurs at the beginning of Jesus' ministry instead of at the end.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[256]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10_131-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10-131">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jesus comes into conflict with the Jewish elders, such as when they <a href="/wiki/Authority_of_Jesus_questioned" title="Authority of Jesus questioned">question his authority</a> and when he <a href="/wiki/Woes_of_the_Pharisees" title="Woes of the Pharisees">criticizes them and calls them hypocrites</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoringCraddock2004256â58_261-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoringCraddock2004256â58-261">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003381â95_263-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003381â95-263">[252]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Judas_Iscariot" title="Judas Iscariot">Judas Iscariot</a>, one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelve_apostles" title="Twelve apostles">twelve apostles</a>, secretly strikes a bargain with the Jewish elders, agreeing to betray Jesus to them for <a href="/wiki/Thirty_pieces_of_silver" title="Thirty pieces of silver">30 silver coins</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lockyer106_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lockyer106-268">[257]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Gospel of John recounts of two other feasts in which Jesus taught in Jerusalem before the Passion Week.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[259]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72_161-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72-161">[150]</a></sup> In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bethany_(biblical_village)" title="Bethany (biblical village)">Bethany</a>, a village near Jerusalem, Jesus <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raising_of_Lazarus" title="Raising of Lazarus">raises Lazarus from the dead</a>. This potent sign<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10_131-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10-131">[122]</a></sup> increases the tension with authorities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70_205-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70-205">[194]</a></sup> who conspire to kill him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72_161-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72-161">[150]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mary_of_Bethany" title="Mary of Bethany">Mary of Bethany</a> anoints Jesus' feet, foreshadowing his entombment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar1993401â470_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar1993401â470-272">[261]</a></sup> Jesus then makes his Messianic entry into Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72_161-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72-161">[150]</a></sup>
The cheering crowds greeting Jesus as he enters Jerusalem add to the animosity between him and the establishment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70_205-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007155â70-205">[194]</a></sup> In John, Jesus has already cleansed the Second Temple during an earlier Passover visit to Jerusalem. John next recounts Jesus' Last Supper with his disciples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72_161-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985270â72-161">[150]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Last_Supper">Last Supper</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Jesus_predicts_his_betrayal" title="Jesus predicts his betrayal">Jesus predicts his betrayal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Denial_of_Peter" title="Denial of Peter">Denial of Peter</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper_in_Christian_art" title="Last Supper in Christian art">Last Supper in Christian art</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Juan_de_Juanes.jpg"><img alt="A depiction of the Last Supper. Jesus sits in the center, his apostles gathered around on either side of him." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1215" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Juan_de_Juanes.jpg/260px-%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Juan_de_Juanes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Juan_de_Juanes.jpg/390px-%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Juan_de_Juanes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Juan_de_Juanes.jpg/520px-%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Juan_de_Juanes.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Juan_de_Juanes.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a>, depicted by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Juan_de_Juanes" title="Juan de Juanes">Juan de Juanes</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â1562</span></div></div></div>
<p>The Last Supper is the final meal that Jesus shares with his twelve apostles in Jerusalem before his crucifixion. The Last Supper is mentioned in all four canonical gospels; Paul's <a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_to_the_Corinthians" title="First Epistle to the Corinthians">First Epistle to the Corinthians</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[262]</a></sup> also refers to it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fahlbusch52_85-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fahlbusch52-85">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003465â77_86-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003465â77-86">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007180â91_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007180â91-274">[263]</a></sup> During the meal, <a href="/wiki/Jesus_predicts_his_betrayal" title="Jesus predicts his betrayal">Jesus predicts</a> that one of his apostles will betray him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007182_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007182-275">[264]</a></sup> Despite each Apostle's assertion that he would not betray him, Jesus reiterates that the betrayer would be one of those present. Matthew 26:23â25 and John 13:26â27 specifically identify Judas as the traitor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fahlbusch52_85-2"><a href="#cite_note-Fahlbusch52-85">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003465â77_86-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003465â77-86">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007182_275-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007182-275">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Synoptics, Jesus takes bread, breaks it, and gives it to the disciples, saying, "This is my body, which is given for you". He then has them all drink from a cup, saying, "This cup that is poured out for you is the new covenant in my blood,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fahlbusch52_85-3"><a href="#cite_note-Fahlbusch52-85">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Eucharist_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Eucharist-277">[266]</a></sup> The Christian <a href="/wiki/Sacrament" title="Sacrament">sacrament</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ordinance_(Christian)" title="Ordinance (Christian)">ordinance</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist" title="Eucharist">Eucharist</a> is based on these events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[267]</a></sup> Although the Gospel of John does not include a description of the bread-and-wine ritual during the Last Supper, most scholars agree that John 6:22â59 (the <a href="/wiki/Bread_of_Life_Discourse" title="Bread of Life Discourse">Bread of Life Discourse</a>) has a eucharistic character and resonates with the <a href="/wiki/Origin_of_the_Eucharist#Institution_narratives" title="Origin of the Eucharist">institution narratives</a> in the Synoptic Gospels and in the Pauline writings on the Last Supper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreedman2000792_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreedman2000792-279">[268]</a></sup>
</p><p>In all four gospels, Jesus predicts that Peter will deny knowledge of him three times before the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rooster" title="Rooster">rooster</a> crows the next morning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Denial_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-Denial-280">[269]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[270]</a></sup> In Luke and John, the prediction is made during the Supper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[271]</a></sup> In Matthew and Mark, the prediction is made after the Supper; Jesus also predicts that all his disciples will desert him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[272]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWalvoordZuck198383â85_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWalvoordZuck198383â85-284">[273]</a></sup> The Gospel of John provides the only account of <a href="/wiki/Maundy_(foot_washing)" title="Maundy (foot washing)">Jesus washing his disciples' feet</a> after the meal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985272â85_154-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985272â85-154">[143]</a></sup> John also includes a long sermon by Jesus, preparing his disciples (now without Judas) for his departure. Chapters 14â17 of the Gospel of John are known as the <a href="/wiki/Farewell_Discourse" title="Farewell Discourse">Farewell Discourse</a> and are a significant source of <a href="/wiki/Christology" title="Christology">Christological</a> content.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gail142_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gail142-285">[274]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman546_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herman546-286">[275]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Agony_in_the_Garden.2C_betrayal.2C_and_arrest"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Agony_in_the_Garden,_betrayal,_and_arrest">Agony in the Garden, betrayal, and arrest</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Agony_in_the_Garden" title="Agony in the Garden">Agony in the Garden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kiss_of_Judas" title="Kiss of Judas">Kiss of Judas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arrest_of_Jesus" title="Arrest of Jesus">Arrest of Jesus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Malchus" title="Malchus">Malchus</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Taking_of_Christ-Caravaggio_(c.1602).jpg"><img alt="Judas kisses Jesus, and soldiers rush to seize the latter." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7666" data-file-width="9893" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/The_Taking_of_Christ-Caravaggio_%28c.1602%29.jpg/220px-The_Taking_of_Christ-Caravaggio_%28c.1602%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/The_Taking_of_Christ-Caravaggio_%28c.1602%29.jpg/330px-The_Taking_of_Christ-Caravaggio_%28c.1602%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/The_Taking_of_Christ-Caravaggio_%28c.1602%29.jpg/440px-The_Taking_of_Christ-Caravaggio_%28c.1602%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Taking_of_Christ-Caravaggio_(c.1602).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A depiction of the <a href="/wiki/Kiss_of_Judas" title="Kiss of Judas">kiss of Judas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arrest_of_Jesus" title="Arrest of Jesus">arrest of Jesus</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Caravaggio" title="Caravaggio">Caravaggio</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â1602</span></div></div></div>
<p>In the Synoptics, Jesus and his disciples go to the garden <a href="/wiki/Gethsemane" title="Gethsemane">Gethsemane</a>, where Jesus prays to be spared his coming ordeal. Then Judas comes with an armed mob, sent by the chief priests, <a href="/wiki/Scribe#Judaism" title="Scribe">scribes</a> and elders. He <a href="/wiki/Kiss_of_Judas" title="Kiss of Judas">kisses Jesus</a> to identify him to the crowd, which then <a href="/wiki/Arrest_of_Jesus" title="Arrest of Jesus">arrests Jesus</a>. In an attempt to stop them, an unnamed disciple of Jesus uses a sword to cut off the ear of a man in the crowd. After Jesus' arrest, his disciples go into hiding, and Peter, when questioned, thrice <a href="/wiki/Denial_of_Peter" title="Denial of Peter">denies</a> knowing Jesus. After the third denial, Peter hears the rooster crow and recalls Jesus' prediction about his denial. Peter then weeps bitterly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWalvoordZuck198383â85_284-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWalvoordZuck198383â85-284">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985285â96_196-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985285â96-196">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Denial_280-1"><a href="#cite_note-Denial-280">[269]</a></sup>
</p><p>In John 18:1â11, Jesus does not pray to be spared his crucifixion, as the gospel portrays him as scarcely touched by such human weakness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus-287">[276]</a></sup> The people who arrest him are <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Roman_army" title="Imperial Roman army">Roman soldiers</a> and Temple guards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[277]</a></sup> Instead of being betrayed by a kiss, Jesus proclaims his identity, and when he does, the soldiers and officers fall to the ground. The gospel identifies Peter as the disciple who used the sword, and Jesus rebukes him for it.
</p>
<h4><span id="Trials_by_the_Sanhedrin.2C_Herod.2C_and_Pilate"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Trials_by_the_Sanhedrin,_Herod,_and_Pilate">Trials by the Sanhedrin, Herod, and Pilate</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sanhedrin_trial_of_Jesus" title="Sanhedrin trial of Jesus">Sanhedrin trial of Jesus</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pilate%27s_Court" title="Pilate's Court">Pilate's Court</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesus_at_Herod%27s_Court" title="Jesus at Herod's Court">Jesus at Herod's Court</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Jesus,_King_of_the_Jews" title="Jesus, King of the Jews">Jesus, King of the Jews</a>; <a href="/wiki/John_18:38" title="John 18:38">John 18:38</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Ecce_homo" title="Ecce homo">Ecce homo</a></div>
<p>After his arrest, Jesus is taken late at night to the private residence of the high priest, <a href="/wiki/Caiaphas" title="Caiaphas">Caiaphas</a>, who had been installed by Pilate's predecessor, the Roman procurator <a href="/wiki/Valerius_Gratus" title="Valerius Gratus">Valerius Gratus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[278]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sanhedrin" title="Sanhedrin">Sanhedrin</a> was a Jewish judicial body,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown1997146_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown1997146-290">[279]</a></sup> The gospel accounts differ on the <a href="/wiki/Sanhedrin_trial_of_Jesus" title="Sanhedrin trial of Jesus">details of the trials</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[280]</a></sup> In Matthew 26:57, Mark 14:53 and Luke 22:54, Jesus is taken to the house of the high priest, <a href="/wiki/Caiaphas" title="Caiaphas">Caiaphas</a>, where he is <a href="/wiki/Mocking_of_Jesus" title="Mocking of Jesus">mocked</a> and beaten that night. Early the next morning, the chief priests and scribes lead Jesus away into their council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003487â500_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003487â500-292">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009396â400_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009396â400-293">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holman608_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-Holman608-294">[283]</a></sup> John 18:12â14 states that Jesus is first taken to <a href="/wiki/Annas" title="Annas">Annas</a>, Caiaphas's father-in-law, and then to the high priest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003487â500_292-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003487â500-292">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009396â400_293-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009396â400-293">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holman608_294-1"><a href="#cite_note-Holman608-294">[283]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ecce_homo_by_Antonio_Ciseri_(1).jpg"><img alt="A depiction of Jesus' public trial" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="612" data-file-width="799" decoding="async" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Ecce_homo_by_Antonio_Ciseri_%281%29.jpg/260px-Ecce_homo_by_Antonio_Ciseri_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Ecce_homo_by_Antonio_Ciseri_%281%29.jpg/390px-Ecce_homo_by_Antonio_Ciseri_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Ecce_homo_by_Antonio_Ciseri_%281%29.jpg/520px-Ecce_homo_by_Antonio_Ciseri_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ecce_homo_by_Antonio_Ciseri_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Ecce homo!</i> <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Ciseri" title="Antonio Ciseri">Antonio Ciseri</a>'s 1871 depiction of <a href="/wiki/Pontius_Pilate" title="Pontius Pilate">Pontius Pilate</a> presenting Jesus to the public</div></div></div>
<p>During the trials Jesus speaks very little, mounts no defense, and gives very infrequent and indirect answers to the priests' questions, prompting an officer to slap him. In Matthew 26:62, Jesus' unresponsiveness leads Caiaphas to ask him, "Have you no answer?"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003487â500_292-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003487â500-292">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009396â400_293-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009396â400-293">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holman608_294-2"><a href="#cite_note-Holman608-294">[283]</a></sup> In Mark 14:61 the high priest then asks Jesus, "Are you the Messiah, the Son of the Blessed One?" Jesus replies, "I am", and then predicts the coming of the <a href="/wiki/Son_of_man_(Christianity)" title="Son of man (Christianity)">Son of Man</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-6"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup> This provokes Caiaphas to tear his own robe in anger and to accuse Jesus of blasphemy. In Matthew and Luke, Jesus' answer is more ambiguous:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-7"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003495_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003495-295">[284]</a></sup> in Matthew 26:64 he responds, "You have said so", and in Luke 22:70 he says, "You say that I am".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009396â98_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009396â98-296">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Jewish elders take Jesus to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pilate%27s_Court" title="Pilate's Court">Pilate's Court</a> and ask the Roman governor, <a href="/wiki/Pontius_Pilate" title="Pontius Pilate">Pontius Pilate</a>, to judge and condemn Jesus for various allegations: subverting the nation, opposing the payment of tribute, claiming to be Christ, a King, and claiming to be the son of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holman608_294-3"><a href="#cite_note-Holman608-294">[283]</a></sup> The use of the word "king" is central to the discussion between Jesus and Pilate. In John 18:36 Jesus states, "My kingdom is not from this world", but he does not unequivocally deny being the King of the Jews.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[289]</a></sup> In Luke 23:7â15, Pilate realizes that Jesus is a Galilean, and thus comes under the jurisdiction of <a href="/wiki/Herod_Antipas" title="Herod Antipas">Herod Antipas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Herodian_Tetrarchy" title="Herodian Tetrarchy">Tetrarch</a> of Galilee and Perea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992172_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992172-301">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMajernÃ­kPonessaManhardt2005181_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMajernÃ­kPonessaManhardt2005181-302">[291]</a></sup> Pilate sends Jesus to Herod to be tried,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarter2003120â21_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarter2003120â21-303">[292]</a></sup> but Jesus says almost nothing in response to Herod's questions. Herod and his soldiers mock Jesus, put an expensive robe on him to make him look like a king, and return him to Pilate,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992172_301-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992172-301">[290]</a></sup> who then calls together the Jewish elders and announces that he has "not found this man guilty".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarter2003120â21_303-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarter2003120â21-303">[292]</a></sup>
</p><p>Observing a <a href="/wiki/Passover" title="Passover">Passover</a> custom of the time, Pilate allows one prisoner chosen by the crowd to be released. He gives the people a choice between Jesus and a murderer called <a href="/wiki/Barabbas" title="Barabbas">Barabbas</a> (<span title="Hebrew-language text"><span lang="he"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D7%91%D7%A8-%D7%90%D7%91%D7%90" title="wikt:××¨-×××">××¨-×××</a></span></span> or <i>Bar-abbÃ¢</i>, "son of the father", from the common given name <i><a href="/wiki/Abba_(given_name)" title="Abba (given name)">Abba</a></i>: 'father').<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2012b453_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2012b453-304">[293]</a></sup> Persuaded by the elders,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[294]</a></sup> the mob chooses to release Barabbas and crucify Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009400â01_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009400â01-306">[295]</a></sup> Pilate writes a sign in Hebrew, Latin, and Greek that reads "Jesus of Nazareth, the King of the Jews" (abbreviated as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INRI" title="INRI">INRI</a> in depictions) to be affixed to Jesus' cross,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[296]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown198893_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown198893-308">[297]</a></sup> then <a href="/wiki/Flagellation_of_Christ" title="Flagellation of Christ">scourges Jesus</a> and sends him to be crucified. The soldiers place a <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_thorns" title="Crown of thorns">crown of thorns</a> on Jesus' head and ridicule him as the King of the Jews. They beat and taunt him before taking him to <a href="/wiki/Calvary" title="Calvary">Calvary</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Senior_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-Senior-309">[298]</a></sup> also called Golgotha, for crucifixion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003487â500_292-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003487â500-292">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holman608_294-4"><a href="#cite_note-Holman608-294">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009402_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009402-310">[299]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Crucifixion_and_entombment">Crucifixion and entombment</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">Crucifixion of Jesus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Burial_of_Jesus" title="Burial of Jesus">Burial of Jesus</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Sayings_of_Jesus_on_the_cross" title="Sayings of Jesus on the cross">Sayings of Jesus on the cross</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crucifixion_eclipse" title="Crucifixion eclipse">Crucifixion eclipse</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pietro_Perugino_040.jpg"><img alt="A depiction of Jesus on the cross" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="2195" decoding="async" height="328" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Pietro_Perugino_040.jpg/180px-Pietro_Perugino_040.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Pietro_Perugino_040.jpg/270px-Pietro_Perugino_040.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Pietro_Perugino_040.jpg/360px-Pietro_Perugino_040.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pietro_Perugino_040.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pietro_Perugino" title="Pietro Perugino">Pietro Perugino</a>'s depiction of the <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">Crucifixion</a> as <i><a href="/wiki/Stabat_Mater_(art)" title="Stabat Mater (art)">Stabat Mater</a></i>, 1482</div></div></div>
<p>Jesus' crucifixion is described in all four canonical gospels. After the trials, Jesus is led to <a href="/wiki/Calvary" title="Calvary">Calvary</a> <a href="/wiki/Christ_Carrying_the_Cross" title="Christ Carrying the Cross">carrying his cross</a>; the route traditionally thought to have been taken is known as the <a href="/wiki/Via_Dolorosa" title="Via Dolorosa">Via Dolorosa</a>. The three Synoptic Gospels indicate that <a href="/wiki/Simon_of_Cyrene" title="Simon of Cyrene">Simon of Cyrene</a> assists him, having been compelled by the Romans to do so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20-311">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009211â14_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009211â14-312">[301]</a></sup> In Luke 23:27â28, Jesus tells the women in the multitude of people following him not to weep for him but for themselves and their children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20_311-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20-311">[300]</a></sup> At Calvary, Jesus is offered a sponge soaked in a concoction usually offered as a <a href="/wiki/Analgesic" title="Analgesic">painkiller</a>. According to Matthew and Mark, he refuses it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20_311-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20-311">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009211â14_312-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009211â14-312">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>The soldiers then crucify Jesus and <a href="/wiki/Sortes_(ancient_Rome)" title="Sortes (ancient Rome)">cast lots</a> for his clothes. Above Jesus' head on the cross is Pilate's inscription, "Jesus of Nazareth, the King of the Jews". Soldiers and passersby <a href="/wiki/Mocking_of_Jesus" title="Mocking of Jesus">mock</a> him about it. Two convicted thieves are crucified along with Jesus. In Matthew and Mark, both thieves mock Jesus. In Luke, <a href="/wiki/Impenitent_thief" title="Impenitent thief">one of them</a> rebukes Jesus, while <a href="/wiki/Penitent_thief" title="Penitent thief">the other</a> defends him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20_311-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20-311">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoninger1999271_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoninger1999271-313">[302]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman2009[httpsarchiveorgdetailsjesusinterrupted00ehrm_0page82_82]_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman2009[httpsarchiveorgdetailsjesusinterrupted00ehrm_0page82_82]-314">[303]</a></sup> Jesus tells the latter: "today you will be with me in Paradise."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[304]</a></sup> In John, Mary, the mother of Jesus, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beloved_disciple" title="Beloved disciple">beloved disciple</a> were at the crucifixion. Jesus tells the beloved disciple to take care of his mother.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[305]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Roman soldiers break the two thieves' legs (a procedure designed to hasten death in a crucifixion), but they do not break those of Jesus, as he is already dead (John 19:33). In John 19:34, <a href="/wiki/Longinus" title="Longinus">one soldier</a> pierces Jesus' side with a <a href="/wiki/Holy_Lance" title="Holy Lance">lance</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Five_Holy_Wounds" title="Five Holy Wounds">blood and water</a> flow out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoninger1999271_313-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoninger1999271-313">[302]</a></sup> In the Synoptics, when Jesus dies, the heavy curtain at the Temple is torn. In Matthew 27:51â54, <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_darkness" title="Crucifixion darkness">an earthquake breaks open tombs</a>. In Matthew and Mark, terrified by the events, a Roman <a href="/wiki/Centurion" title="Centurion">centurion</a> states that Jesus was the <a href="/wiki/Son_of_God_(Christianity)" title="Son of God (Christianity)">Son of God</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20_311-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20-311">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009213â14_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009213â14-317">[306]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the same day, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_of_Arimathea" title="Joseph of Arimathea">Joseph of Arimathea</a>, with Pilate's permission and with <a href="/wiki/Nicodemus" title="Nicodemus">Nicodemus</a>'s help, <a href="/wiki/Descent_from_the_Cross" title="Descent from the Cross">removes Jesus' body from the cross</a>, wraps him in a clean cloth, and buries him in his new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sepulchre" title="Sepulchre">rock-hewn tomb</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20_311-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20-311">[300]</a></sup> In Matthew 27:62â66, on the following day the chief Jewish priests ask Pilate for the tomb to be secured, and with Pilate's permission the priests place seals on the large stone covering the entrance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20_311-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003509â20-311">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris1992727_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris1992727-318">[307]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Resurrection_and_ascension">Resurrection and ascension</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus" title="Resurrection of Jesus">Resurrection of Jesus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Post-resurrection_appearances_of_Jesus" title="Post-resurrection appearances of Jesus">Post-resurrection appearances of Jesus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ascension_of_Jesus" title="Ascension of Jesus">Ascension of Jesus</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Empty_tomb" title="Empty tomb">Empty tomb</a>, <a href="/wiki/Great_Commission" title="Great Commission">Great Commission</a>, <a href="/wiki/Second_Coming" title="Second Coming">Second Coming</a>, <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus_in_Christian_art" title="Resurrection of Jesus in Christian art">Resurrection of Jesus in Christian art</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ascension_of_Jesus_in_Christian_art" title="Ascension of Jesus in Christian art">Ascension of Jesus in Christian art</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Overview_of_resurrection_appearances_in_the_Gospels_and_Paul" title="Overview of resurrection appearances in the Gospels and Paul">Overview of resurrection appearances in the Gospels and Paul</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alexander_Ivanov_-_Christ%27s_Appearance_to_Mary_Magdalene_after_the_Resurrection_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg"><img alt="Jesus appearing to Mary Magdalene after his resurrection from the dead, depicted by Alexander Andreyevich Ivanov." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3556" data-file-width="4725" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Alexander_Ivanov_-_Christ%27s_Appearance_to_Mary_Magdalene_after_the_Resurrection_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/260px-Alexander_Ivanov_-_Christ%27s_Appearance_to_Mary_Magdalene_after_the_Resurrection_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Alexander_Ivanov_-_Christ%27s_Appearance_to_Mary_Magdalene_after_the_Resurrection_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/390px-Alexander_Ivanov_-_Christ%27s_Appearance_to_Mary_Magdalene_after_the_Resurrection_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Alexander_Ivanov_-_Christ%27s_Appearance_to_Mary_Magdalene_after_the_Resurrection_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/520px-Alexander_Ivanov_-_Christ%27s_Appearance_to_Mary_Magdalene_after_the_Resurrection_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alexander_Ivanov_-_Christ%27s_Appearance_to_Mary_Magdalene_after_the_Resurrection_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Appearance of Jesus Christ to Maria Magdalena</i> by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Andreyevich_Ivanov" title="Alexander Andreyevich Ivanov">Alexander Andreyevich Ivanov</a>, 1835</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Mary_Magdalene" title="Mary Magdalene">Mary Magdalene</a> (alone in the Gospel of John, but accompanied by other women in the Synoptics) goes to Jesus' tomb on Sunday morning and is surprised to find it empty.
