Despite Jesus' teaching, the disciples had not understood that Jesus would rise again.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985308â09_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985308â09-319">[308]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>In <a href="/wiki/Matthew_28" title="Matthew 28">Matthew 28</a>, there are guards at the tomb. An angel descends from Heaven, and opens the tomb. The guards faint from fear. Jesus appears to Mary Magdalene and "the other Mary" after they visited the tomb. Jesus then appears to the eleven remaining disciples in Galilee and <a href="/wiki/Great_Commission" title="Great Commission">commissions them</a> to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baptize" title="Baptize">baptize</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Noachide" title="Noachide">all nations</a> in the name of the Father, Son and Holy Spirit,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985272â85_154-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985272â85-154">[143]</a></sup> <i>"teaching them to obey everything that I have commanded you."</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[309]</a></sup></li>
<li>In <a href="/wiki/Mark_16" title="Mark 16">Mark 16</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salome_(disciple)" title="Salome (disciple)">Salome</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_James" title="Mary, mother of James">Mary, mother of James</a> are with Mary Magdalene.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[310]</a></sup> In the tomb, a young man in a white robe (an angel) tells them that Jesus will meet his disciples in Galilee, as he had told them (referring to Mark 14:28).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-May_Metzger_Mark_101-4"><a href="#cite_note-May_Metzger_Mark-101">[92]</a></sup></li>
<li>In Luke, Mary and various other women meet two angels at the tomb, but the eleven disciples do not believe their story.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[311]</a></sup> Jesus appears to two of his followers in Emmaus. He also makes an appearance to Peter. Jesus then appears that same day to his disciples in Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[312]</a></sup> Although he appears and vanishes mysteriously, he also eats and lets them touch him to prove that he is not a spirit. He repeats his command to bring his teaching to all nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[313]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985297â301_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985297â301-325">[314]</a></sup></li>
<li>In John, Mary is alone at first, but Peter and the beloved disciple come and see the tomb as well. Jesus then appears to Mary at the tomb. He later appears to the disciples, breathes on them, and gives them the power to forgive and retain sins. In a second visit to disciples, he proves to a doubting disciple ("<a href="/wiki/Doubting_Thomas" title="Doubting Thomas">Doubting Thomas</a>") that he is flesh and blood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10_131-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985302â10-131">[122]</a></sup> The disciples return to Galilee, where Jesus makes another appearance. He performs a miracle known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catch_of_153_fish" title="Catch of 153 fish">catch of 153 fish</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a>, after which Jesus encourages Peter to serve his followers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003521â30_92-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003521â30-92">[84]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007216â26_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoxEasley2007216â26-326">[315]</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>Jesus' <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entering_Heaven_alive" title="Entering Heaven alive">ascension into Heaven</a> is described in Luke 24:50â53, Acts 1:1â11 and mentioned in 1 Timothy 3:16. In the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>, forty days after the Resurrection, as the disciples look on, "he was lifted up, and a cloud took him out of their sight". 1 Peter 3:22 states that Jesus has "gone into heaven and is at the right hand of God".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2003521â30_92-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2003521â30-92">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Acts of the Apostles describes several appearances of Jesus after his Ascension. In Acts 7:55, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Stephen" title="Saint Stephen">Stephen</a> gazes into heaven and sees "Jesus standing at the right hand of God" just before his death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[316]</a></sup> On the road to <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a>, the Apostle <a href="/wiki/Conversion_of_Paul_the_Apostle" title="Conversion of Paul the Apostle">Paul is converted</a> to Christianity after seeing a blinding light and hearing a voice saying, "I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[317]</a></sup> In Acts 9:10â18, Jesus instructs <a href="/wiki/Ananias_of_Damascus" title="Ananias of Damascus">Ananias of Damascus</a> in a vision to heal Paul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarringtonActs_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-HarringtonActs-329">[318]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Revelation" title="Book of Revelation">Book of Revelation</a> includes a revelation from Jesus concerning the <a href="/wiki/Christian_eschatology" title="Christian eschatology">last days of Earth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[319]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Christianity">Early Christianity</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">Early Christianity</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Good_shepherd_02b_close.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="384" data-file-width="272" decoding="async" height="282" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Good_shepherd_02b_close.jpg/200px-Good_shepherd_02b_close.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Good_shepherd_02b_close.jpg 1.5x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Good_shepherd_02b_close.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 3rd century depiction of Jesus as the <a href="/wiki/Good_Shepherd" title="Good Shepherd">Good Shepherd</a></div></div></div>
<p>After Jesus' life, his followers, as described in the first chapters of the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>, were all <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a> either by birth or <a href="/wiki/Conversion_to_Judaism" title="Conversion to Judaism">conversion</a>, for which the biblical term "<a href="/wiki/Proselyte" title="Proselyte">proselyte</a>" is used,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[320]</a></sup> and referred to by historians as <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Christian" title="Jewish Christian">Jewish Christians</a>. The early Gospel message was spread <a href="/wiki/Oral_gospel_traditions" title="Oral gospel traditions">orally</a>, probably in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aramaic_language" title="Aramaic language">Aramaic</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman201287â90_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman201287â90-332">[321]</a></sup> but almost immediately also in <a href="/wiki/Koine_Greek" title="Koine Greek">Greek</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[322]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>'s Acts of the Apostles and <a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Galatians" title="Epistle to the Galatians">Epistle to the Galatians</a> record that the first Christian community was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Christian_church" title="First Christian church">centered in Jerusalem</a> and its leaders included <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Peter</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_(brother_of_Jesus)" title="James (brother of Jesus)">James, the brother of Jesus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/John_the_Apostle" title="John the Apostle">John the Apostle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[323]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/Conversion_of_Paul_the_Apostle" title="Conversion of Paul the Apostle">conversion of Paul the Apostle</a>, he claimed the title of "Apostle to the Gentiles". Paul's influence on Christian thinking is said to be more significant than that of any other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authorship_of_the_New_Testament" title="Authorship of the New Testament">New Testament author</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[324]</a></sup> By the end of the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_1st_century" title="Christianity in the 1st century">1st century</a>, Christianity began to be recognized internally and externally as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Split_of_early_Christianity_and_Judaism" title="Split of early Christianity and Judaism">separate religion from Judaism</a> which itself was refined and developed further in the centuries after the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(70_CE)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (70 CE)">destruction</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">Second Temple</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[325]</a></sup>
</p><p>Numerous quotations in the New Testament and other Christian writings of the first centuries, indicate that early Christians generally used and revered the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> (the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tanakh" title="Tanakh">Tanakh</a>) as <a href="/wiki/Religious_text" title="Religious text">religious text</a>, mostly in the Greek (<a href="/wiki/Septuagint" title="Septuagint">Septuagint</a>) or Aramaic (<a href="/wiki/Targum" title="Targum">Targum</a>) translations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>Early Christians wrote many religious works, including the ones included in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canon_of_the_New_Testament" title="Canon of the New Testament">canon of the New Testament</a>. The canonical texts, which have become the main sources used by historians to try to understand the historical Jesus and sacred texts within Christianity, were probably written between 50 and 120 AD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ehrman120ce_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ehrman120ce-338">[327]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_views">Historical views</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Historical_Jesus" title="Historical Jesus">Historical Jesus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quest_for_the_historical_Jesus" title="Quest for the historical Jesus">Quest for the historical Jesus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Scholarly_interpretation_of_Gospel_elements" title="Scholarly interpretation of Gospel elements">Scholarly interpretation of Gospel elements</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Biblical_criticism" title="Biblical criticism">Biblical criticism</a></div>
<p>Prior to the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a>, the Gospels were usually regarded as accurate historical accounts, but since then scholars have emerged who question the reliability of the Gospels and draw a distinction between the Jesus described in the Gospels and the Jesus of history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevine20065_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevine20065-339">[328]</a></sup> Since the 18th century, three separate scholarly quests for the historical Jesus have taken place, each with distinct characteristics and based on different research criteria, which were often developed during the quest that applied them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113_124-9"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitherington1997113-124">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPowell199819â23_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPowell199819â23-340">[329]</a></sup> While there is widespread scholarly agreement on the existence of Jesus,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exist_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-exist-22">[e]</a></sup> and a basic consensus on the general outline of his life,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[l]</a></sup> the portraits of Jesus constructed by various scholars often differ from each other, and from the image portrayed in the gospel accounts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenWinter20025_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenWinter20025-343">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[332]</a></sup>
</p><p>Approaches to the historical reconstruction of the life of Jesus have varied from the "maximalist" approaches of the 19th century, in which the gospel accounts were accepted as reliable evidence wherever it is possible, to the "minimalist" approaches of the early 20th century, where hardly anything about Jesus was accepted as historical.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeener2012163_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeener2012163-345">[333]</a></sup> In the 1950s, as the second quest for the historical Jesus gathered pace, the minimalist approaches faded away, and in the 21st century, minimalists such as <a href="/wiki/Robert_M._Price" title="Robert M. Price">Price</a> are a very small minority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChiltonEvans199827_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChiltonEvans199827-346">[334]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans2012a4â5_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans2012a4â5-347">[335]</a></sup> Although a belief in the <a href="/wiki/Biblical_inerrancy" title="Biblical inerrancy">inerrancy</a> of the Gospels cannot be supported historically, many scholars since the 1980s have held that, beyond the few facts considered to be historically certain, certain other elements of Jesus' life are "historically probable".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChiltonEvans199827_346-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChiltonEvans199827-346">[334]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenWinter2002142â143_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenWinter2002142â143-349">[337]</a></sup> Modern scholarly research on the historical Jesus thus focuses on identifying the most probable elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeier2006124_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeier2006124-351">[339]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Judea_and_Galilee_in_the_1st_century">Judea and Galilee in the 1st century</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Palestine_in_the_time_of_Jesus.jpg"><img alt="A map. See description" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2573" data-file-width="1826" decoding="async" height="310" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Palestine_in_the_time_of_Jesus.jpg/220px-Palestine_in_the_time_of_Jesus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Palestine_in_the_time_of_Jesus.jpg/330px-Palestine_in_the_time_of_Jesus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Palestine_in_the_time_of_Jesus.jpg/440px-Palestine_in_the_time_of_Jesus.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Palestine_in_the_time_of_Jesus.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a> and neighboring areas at the time of Jesus</div></div></div>
<p>In AD 6, <a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edom" title="Edom">Idumea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Samaria" title="Samaria">Samaria</a> were transformed from a <a href="/wiki/Herodian_dynasty" title="Herodian dynasty">Herodian</a> <a href="/wiki/Client_state" title="Client state">client kingdom</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> into an imperial province, also called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judea_(Roman_province)" title="Judea (Roman province)">Judea</a>. A Roman <a href="/wiki/Prefect" title="Prefect">prefect</a>, rather than a client king, ruled the land. The prefect ruled from <a href="/wiki/Caesarea_Maritima" title="Caesarea Maritima">Caesarea Maritima</a>, leaving <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> to be run by the <a href="/wiki/List_of_High_Priests_of_Israel" title="List of High Priests of Israel">High Priest of Israel</a>. As an exception, the prefect came to Jerusalem during religious festivals, when religious and patriotic enthusiasm sometimes inspired unrest or uprisings. Gentile lands surrounded the Jewish territories of Judea and <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a>, but Roman law and practice allowed Jews to remain separate legally and culturally. Galilee was evidently prosperous, and poverty was limited enough that it did not threaten the social order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-8"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>This was the era of <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_Judaism" title="Hellenistic Judaism">Hellenistic Judaism</a>, which combined <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Jewish religious tradition</a> with elements of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic" title="Hellenistic">Hellenistic</a> Greek culture. Until the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">fall of the Western Roman Empire</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests" title="Muslim conquests">Muslim conquests</a> of the Eastern Mediterranean, the main centers of Hellenistic Judaism were <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> (Egypt) and <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">Antioch</a> (now Southern Turkey), the two main <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greek_colonies" title="Greek colonies">Greek urban settlements</a> of the <a href="/wiki/MENA" title="MENA">Middle East and North Africa</a> area, both founded at the end of the 4th century BCE in the wake of the conquests of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>. Hellenistic Judaism also existed in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_during_the_Second_Temple_Period" title="Jerusalem during the Second Temple Period">Jerusalem during the Second Temple Period</a>, where there was conflict between <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenizers</a> and traditionalists (sometimes called <a href="/wiki/Judaizers" title="Judaizers">Judaizers</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> was translated from <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Hebrew" title="Biblical Hebrew">Biblical Hebrew</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Aramaic" title="Biblical Aramaic">Biblical Aramaic</a> into <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Koine_Greek" title="Jewish Koine Greek">Jewish Koine Greek</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Targum" title="Targum">Targum</a> translations into Aramaic were also generated during this era, both due to the decline of knowledge of Hebrew.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[340]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jews based their faith and religious practice on the <a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah">Torah</a>, five books said to have been given by God to <a href="/wiki/Moses" title="Moses">Moses</a>. The three prominent religious parties were the <a href="/wiki/Pharisees" title="Pharisees">Pharisees</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Essenes" title="Essenes">Essenes</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sadducees" title="Sadducees">Sadducees</a>. Together these parties represented only a small fraction of the population. Most Jews looked forward to a time that God would deliver them from their pagan rulers, possibly through war against the Romans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-9"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sources">Sources</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sources_for_the_historicity_of_Jesus" title="Sources for the historicity of Jesus">Sources for the historicity of Jesus</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Josephus_on_Jesus" title="Josephus on Jesus">Josephus on Jesus</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tacitus_on_Christ" title="Tacitus on Christ">Tacitus on Christ</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:WorksJosephus1640TP.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1032" data-file-width="688" decoding="async" height="270" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/WorksJosephus1640TP.jpg/180px-WorksJosephus1640TP.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/WorksJosephus1640TP.jpg/270px-WorksJosephus1640TP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/WorksJosephus1640TP.jpg/360px-WorksJosephus1640TP.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:WorksJosephus1640TP.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 1640 edition of the works of Josephus, a 1st-century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Jews" title="Roman Jews">Roman-Jewish</a> historian who referred to Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009431â36_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009431â36-353">[341]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New Testament scholars face a formidable challenge when they analyze the canonical Gospels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985263_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985263-354">[342]</a></sup>
The Gospels are not biographies in the modern sense, and the authors explain Jesus' theological significance and recount his public ministry while omitting many details of his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985263_354-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985263-354">[342]</a></sup>
The reports of supernatural events associated with Jesus' death and resurrection make the challenge even more difficult.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris1985263_354-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris1985263-354">[342]</a></sup>
Scholars regard the Gospels as compromised sources of information because the writers were trying to glorify Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders19933_111-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders19933-111">[102]</a></sup>
Even so, the sources for Jesus' life are better than sources scholars have for the life of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders19933_111-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders19933-111">[102]</a></sup>
Scholars use a number of criteria, such as the <a href="/wiki/Criterion_of_multiple_attestation" title="Criterion of multiple attestation">criterion of independent attestation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Biblical_criticism#Coherence" title="Biblical criticism">criterion of coherence</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Criterion_of_discontinuity" title="Criterion of discontinuity">criterion of discontinuity</a> to judge the historicity of events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERausch200336â37_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERausch200336â37-355">[343]</a></sup> The historicity of an event also depends on the reliability of the source; indeed, the Gospels are not independent nor consistent records of Jesus' life. Mark, which is most likely the earliest written gospel, has been considered for many decades the most historically accurate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[344]</a></sup> John, the latest written gospel, differs considerably from the Synoptic Gospels, and thus is generally considered less reliable, although more and more scholars now also recognize that it may contain a core of older material as historically valuable as the Synoptic tradition or even more so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[345]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some scholars (most notably the <a href="/wiki/Jesus_Seminar" title="Jesus Seminar">Jesus Seminar</a>) believe that the non-canonical <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Thomas" title="Gospel of Thomas">Gospel of Thomas</a> might be an independent witness to many of Jesus' parables and aphorisms. For example, Thomas confirms that Jesus blessed the poor and that this saying circulated independently before being combined with similar sayings in the <a href="/wiki/Q_source" title="Q source">Q source</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar1993471â532_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar1993471â532-358">[346]</a></sup> However, the majority of scholars are skeptical about this text and believe it should be dated to the 2nd century CE instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[347]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[348]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other select non-canonical Christian texts may also have value for historical Jesus research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199817â62_115-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199817â62-115">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>Early non-Christian sources that attest to the historical existence of Jesus include the works of the historians <a href="/wiki/Josephus" title="Josephus">Josephus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tacitus" title="Tacitus">Tacitus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[m]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009431â36_353-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlomberg2009431â36-353">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Voorst200039â53_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Voorst200039â53-363">[350]</a></sup> Josephus scholar <a href="/wiki/Louis_Feldman" title="Louis Feldman">Louis Feldman</a> has stated that "few have doubted the genuineness" of Josephus's reference to Jesus in <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Antiquities_of_the_Jews/Book_XX#Chapter_9" title="s:The Antiquities of the Jews/Book XX">book 20</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Antiquities_of_the_Jews" title="Antiquities of the Jews">Antiquities of the Jews</a></i>, and it is disputed only by a small number of scholars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Voorst200083_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Voorst200083-364">[351]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[352]</a></sup> Tacitus referred to Christ and his execution by Pilate in <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Annals_(Tacitus)/Book_15#44" title="s:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 15">book 15</a> of his work <i><a href="/wiki/Annals_(Tacitus)" title="Annals (Tacitus)">Annals</a></i>. Scholars generally consider Tacitus's reference to the execution of Jesus to be both authentic and of historical value as an independent Roman source.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[353]</a></sup>
</p><p>Non-Christian sources are valuable in two ways. First, they show that even neutral or hostile parties never show any doubt that Jesus actually existed. Second, they present a rough picture of Jesus that is compatible with that found in the Christian sources: that Jesus was a teacher, had a reputation as a miracle worker, had a brother James, and died a violent death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998-367">[354]</a></sup>
</p><p>Archaeology helps scholars better understand Jesus' social world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReed200218_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReed200218-368">[355]</a></sup> Recent archaeological work, for example, indicates that <a href="/wiki/Capernaum" title="Capernaum">Capernaum</a>, a city important in Jesus' ministry, was poor and small, without even a <a href="/wiki/Forum_(Roman)" title="Forum (Roman)">forum</a> or an <a href="/wiki/Agora" title="Agora">agora</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gowler_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gowler-369">[356]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[357]</a></sup> This archaeological discovery resonates well with the scholarly view that Jesus advocated reciprocal sharing among the destitute in that area of Galilee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gowler_369-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gowler-369">[356]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Chronology">Chronology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chronology_of_Jesus" title="Chronology of Jesus">Chronology of Jesus</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Anno_Domini" title="Anno Domini">Anno Domini</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saturnalia#Influence" title="Saturnalia">Saturnalia Â§Â Influence</a></div>
<p>Jesus was a Galilean Jew,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVermes198120,_26,_27,_29_14-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVermes198120,_26,_27,_29-14">[10]</a></sup> born around the beginning of the 1st century, who died in 30 or 33 AD in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judea_(Roman_province)" title="Judea (Roman province)">Judea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHumphreysWaddington1992340_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHumphreysWaddington1992340-371">[358]</a></sup> The general scholarly consensus is that Jesus was a contemporary of <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a> and was crucified as ordered by the Roman governor <a href="/wiki/Pontius_Pilate" title="Pontius Pilate">Pontius Pilate</a>, who held office from 26 to 36 AD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevine20064_29-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevine20064-29">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Gospels offer several indications concerning the year of Jesus' birth. Matthew 2:1 associates the birth of Jesus with the reign of <a href="/wiki/Herod_the_Great" title="Herod the Great">Herod the Great</a>, who died around 4 BC, and Luke 1:5 mentions that Herod was on the throne shortly before the birth of Jesus,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaier1989115â18_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaier1989115â18-372">[359]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992121â22_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992121â22-373">[360]</a></sup> although this gospel also associates the birth with the <a href="/wiki/Census_of_Quirinius" title="Census of Quirinius">Census of Quirinius</a> which took place ten years later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009137â38_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009137â38-374">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992122â24_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992122â24-375">[362]</a></sup> Luke 3:23 states that Jesus was "about thirty years old" at the start of his <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Jesus" title="Ministry of Jesus">ministry</a>, which according to Acts 10:37â38 was preceded by John the Baptist's ministry, which was recorded in Luke 3:1â2 to have begun in the 15th year of <a href="/wiki/Tiberius" title="Tiberius">Tiberius</a>'s reign (28 or 29 AD).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992121â22_373-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENiswonger1992121â22-373">[360]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vermes2006_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vermes2006-376">[363]</a></sup> By collating the gospel accounts with historical data and using various other methods, most scholars arrive at a date of birth for Jesus between 6 and 4 BC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vermes2006_376-1"><a href="#cite_note-Vermes2006-376">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunn2003324_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunn2003324-377">[364]</a></sup> but some propose estimates that include a wider range.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[n]</a></sup>
</p><p>The date range for Jesus' ministry has been estimated using several different approaches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009140_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009140-379">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreedman2000249_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreedman2000249-380">[366]</a></sup> One of these applies the reference in Luke 3:1â2, Acts 10:37â38 and the dates of Tiberius's reign, which are well known, to give a date of around 28â29 AD for the start of Jesus' ministry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaier1989120â21_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaier1989120â21-381">[367]</a></sup> Another approach estimates a date around 27â29 AD by using the statement about the temple in John 2:13â20, which asserts that the <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">temple in Jerusalem</a> was in its 46th year of construction at the start of Jesus' ministry, together with Josephus's statement<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[368]</a></sup> that the temple's reconstruction was started by Herod the Great in the 18th year of his reign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009140_379-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009140-379">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaier1989123_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaier1989123-383">[369]</a></sup> A further method uses the date of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beheading_of_St._John_the_Baptist" title="Beheading of St. John the Baptist">death of John the Baptist</a> and the marriage of <a href="/wiki/Herod_Antipas" title="Herod Antipas">Herod Antipas</a> to <a href="/wiki/Herodias" title="Herodias">Herodias</a>, based on the writings of Josephus, and correlates it with Matthew 14:4 and Mark 6:18.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[371]</a></sup> Given that most scholars date the marriage of Herod and Herodias as AD 28â35, this yields a date about 28â29 AD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreedman2000249_380-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreedman2000249-380">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of approaches have been used to estimate the year of the crucifixion of Jesus. Most scholars agree that he died in 30 or 33 AD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHumphreysWaddington1992340_371-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHumphreysWaddington1992340-371">[358]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009398_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009398-386">[372]</a></sup> The Gospels state that the event occurred during the prefecture of Pilate, the Roman governor of Judea from 26 to 36 AD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199881â83_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199881â83-387">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarter200344â45_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarter200344â45-389">[375]</a></sup> The date for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conversion_of_Paul" title="Conversion of Paul">conversion of Paul</a> (estimated to be 33â36 AD) acts as an upper bound for the date of Crucifixion. The dates for Paul's conversion and ministry can be determined by analyzing the <a href="/wiki/Pauline_epistles" title="Pauline epistles">Pauline epistles</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009398â400_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009398â400-390">[376]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[377]</a></sup> Astronomers have tried to estimate the precise date of the Crucifixion by analyzing lunar motion and calculating historic dates of <a href="/wiki/Passover" title="Passover">Passover</a>, a festival based on the <a href="/wiki/Lunisolar_calendar" title="Lunisolar calendar">lunisolar</a> <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_calendar" title="Hebrew calendar">Hebrew calendar</a>. The most widely accepted dates derived from this method are 7 April 30 AD, and 3 April 33 AD (both <a href="/wiki/Julian_calendar" title="Julian calendar">Julian</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[378]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historicity_of_events">Historicity of events</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Historicity_of_Jesus" title="Historicity of Jesus">Historicity of Jesus</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cultural_and_historical_background_of_Jesus" title="Cultural and historical background of Jesus">Cultural and historical background of Jesus</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_the_Roman_Empire" title="History of the Jews in the Roman Empire">History of the Jews in the Roman Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Historical_criticism" title="Historical criticism">Historical criticism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Textual_criticism" title="Textual criticism">Textual criticism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Historical_reliability_of_the_Gospels" title="Historical reliability of the Gospels">Historical reliability of the Gospels</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:310px;max-width:310px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wien-_Parlament-Tacitus.jpg"><img alt="A white statue of a man" data-file-height="2576" data-file-width="1952" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Wien-_Parlament-Tacitus.jpg/150px-Wien-_Parlament-Tacitus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Wien-_Parlament-Tacitus.jpg/225px-Wien-_Parlament-Tacitus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Wien-_Parlament-Tacitus.jpg/300px-Wien-_Parlament-Tacitus.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:154px;max-width:154px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MII.png"><img alt="An apparently old document" data-file-height="3373" data-file-width="2600" decoding="async" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/MII.png/152px-MII.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/MII.png/228px-MII.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/MII.png/304px-MII.png 2x" width="152"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Roman senator and historian <a href="/wiki/Tacitus" title="Tacitus">Tacitus</a> (pictured left) mentioned the execution of "Christus" (Jesus) by Pilate in a passage describing the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_Rome" title="Great Fire of Rome">Great Fire of Rome</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nero" title="Nero">Nero</a>'s persecution of Christians in the <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Annals_(Tacitus)/Book_15#44" title="s:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 15">Annals</a></i>, a history of the Roman Empire during the 1stÂ century.</div></div></div></div>
<p>Nearly all historical scholars accept Jesus' historical existence as a real person.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exist_22-2"><a href="#cite_note-exist-22">[e]</a></sup> Scholars have reached a limited consensus on the basics of Jesus' life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-White_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-White-393">[379]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Brothers_of_Jesus" title="Brothers of Jesus">Brothers of Jesus</a></div>
<p>Many scholars agree that Joseph, Jesus' father, died before Jesus began his ministry. Joseph is not mentioned at all in the Gospels during Jesus' ministry. Joseph's death would explain why in Mark 6:3, Jesus' neighbors refer to Jesus as the "son of Mary" (sons were usually identified by their fathers).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown1978[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidML1mnUBwmhcCpgPA64_64]_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown1978[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidML1mnUBwmhcCpgPA64_64]-394">[380]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Theissen and Merz, it is common for extraordinary <a href="/wiki/Charismatic_authority" title="Charismatic authority">charismatic leaders</a>, such as Jesus, to come into conflict with their ordinary families.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998194_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998194-395">[381]</a></sup> In Mark, Jesus' family comes to get him, fearing that he is mad (Mark 3:20â34), and this account is thought to be historical because early Christians would likely not have invented it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[382]</a></sup> After Jesus' death, many members of his family joined the Christian movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998194_395-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998194-395">[381]</a></sup> Jesus' brother <a href="/wiki/James,_brother_of_Jesus" title="James, brother of Jesus">James</a> became a leader of the Jerusalem Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005James,_St._397-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005James,_St.-397">[383]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/G%C3%A9za_Vermes" title="GÃ©za Vermes">GÃ©za Vermes</a> says that the doctrine of the <a href="/wiki/Virgin_birth_of_Jesus" title="Virgin birth of Jesus">virgin birth of Jesus</a> arose from theological development rather than from historical events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVermes1981283_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVermes1981283-398">[384]</a></sup>
Despite the widely held view that the authors of the Synoptic Gospels drew upon each other (the so-called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Synoptic_problem" title="Synoptic problem">synoptic problem</a>), other scholars take it as significant that the virgin birth is <a href="/wiki/Criterion_of_multiple_attestation" title="Criterion of multiple attestation">attested</a> by two separate gospels, Matthew and Luke.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[385]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeener2009b[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid8C2Y_HaL5W0CpgPA83_83]_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeener2009b[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid8C2Y_HaL5W0CpgPA83_83]-400">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[390]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/E._P._Sanders" title="E. P. Sanders">E. P. Sanders</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Nativity_of_Jesus" title="Nativity of Jesus">birth narratives</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Gospel of Matthew</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke" title="Gospel of Luke">Gospel of Luke</a> are the clearest case of invention in the Gospel narratives of Jesus' life. Both accounts have Jesus born in <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem">Bethlehem</a>, in accordance with Jewish salvation history, and both have him growing up in Nazareth. But Sanders points that the two Gospels report completely different and irreconcilable explanations for how that happened. Luke's account of a census in which everyone returned to their ancestral cities is not plausible. Matthew's account is more plausible, but the story reads as though it was invented to identify Jesus as like a new <a href="/wiki/Moses" title="Moses">Moses</a>, and the historian <a href="/wiki/Josephus" title="Josephus">Josephus</a> reports Herod the Great's brutality without ever mentioning that <a href="/wiki/Massacre_of_the_Innocents" title="Massacre of the Innocents">he massacred little boys</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199385â88_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199385â88-405">[391]</a></sup> The contradictions between the two Gospels was probably apparent to the early Christians already, since attempts to harmonize the two narratives are already present in the earlier apochryphal <a href="/wiki/Infancy_gospels" title="Infancy gospels">infancy gospels</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Infancy_Gospel_of_Thomas" title="Infancy Gospel of Thomas">Infancy Gospel of Thomas</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_James" title="Gospel of James">Gospel of James</a>), which are dated to the 2nd century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[393]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sanders says that the genealogies of Jesus are based not on historical information but on the authors' desire to show that Jesus was the universal Jewish savior.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199380â91_138-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199380â91-138">[129]</a></sup> In any event, once the doctrine of the virgin birth of Jesus became established, that tradition superseded the earlier tradition that he was descended from <a href="/wiki/David" title="David">David</a> through Joseph.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998196_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998196-408">[394]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke" title="Gospel of Luke">Gospel of Luke</a> reports that Jesus was a <a href="/wiki/Consanguinity" title="Consanguinity">blood relative</a> of <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a>, but scholars generally consider this connection to be invented.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199380â91_138-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199380â91-138">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[395]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Baptism">Baptism</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E1%80%97%E1%80%90%E1%80%B9%E1%80%90%E1%80%AD%E1%80%87%E1%80%B6.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="3024" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%E1%80%97%E1%80%90%E1%80%B9%E1%80%90%E1%80%AD%E1%80%87%E1%80%B6.jpg/220px-%E1%80%97%E1%80%90%E1%80%B9%E1%80%90%E1%80%AD%E1%80%87%E1%80%B6.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%E1%80%97%E1%80%90%E1%80%B9%E1%80%90%E1%80%AD%E1%80%87%E1%80%B6.jpg/330px-%E1%80%97%E1%80%90%E1%80%B9%E1%80%90%E1%80%AD%E1%80%87%E1%80%B6.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%E1%80%97%E1%80%90%E1%80%B9%E1%80%90%E1%80%AD%E1%80%87%E1%80%B6.jpg/440px-%E1%80%97%E1%80%90%E1%80%B9%E1%80%90%E1%80%AD%E1%80%87%E1%80%B6.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E1%80%97%E1%80%90%E1%80%B9%E1%80%90%E1%80%AD%E1%80%87%E1%80%B6.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Baptism in the Jordan River, the river where Jesus was baptized</div></div></div>
<p>Most modern scholars consider Jesus' baptism to be a definite historical fact, along with his crucifixion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunn2003339_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunn2003339-7">[6]</a></sup> Theologian <a href="/wiki/James_Dunn_(theologian)" title="James Dunn (theologian)">James D. G. Dunn</a> states that they "command almost universal assent" and "rank so high on the 'almost impossible to doubt or deny' scale of historical facts" that they are often the starting points for the study of the historical Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunn2003339_7-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunn2003339-7">[6]</a></sup> Scholars adduce the <a href="/wiki/Criterion_of_embarrassment" title="Criterion of embarrassment">criterion of embarrassment</a>, saying that early Christians would not have invented a baptism that might imply that Jesus committed <a href="/wiki/Sin" title="Sin">sins</a> and wanted to <a href="/wiki/Repentance" title="Repentance">repent</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPowell199847_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPowell199847-410">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[397]</a></sup> According to Theissen and Merz, Jesus was inspired by <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a> and took over from him many elements of his teaching.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998235_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998235-412">[398]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ministry_in_Galilee">Ministry in Galilee</span></h4>
<p>Most scholars hold that Jesus lived in <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a> and <a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a> and did not preach or study elsewhere.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dunn303_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dunn303-413">[399]</a></sup> They agree that Jesus debated with Jewish authorities on the subject of God, performed some healings, taught in <a href="/wiki/Parable" title="Parable">parables</a> and gathered followers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevine20064_29-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevine20064-29">[23]</a></sup> Jesus' Jewish critics considered his ministry to be scandalous because he feasted with sinners, fraternized with women, and allowed his followers to pluck grain on the Sabbath.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933_100-30"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar19933-100">[91]</a></sup> According to Sanders, it is not plausible that disagreements over how to interpret the Law of Moses and the Sabbath would have led Jewish authorities to want Jesus killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders1993205â23_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders1993205â23-414">[400]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Ehrman, Jesus taught that a coming kingdom was everyone's proper focus, not anything in this life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999167â70_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999167â70-415">[401]</a></sup> He taught about the Jewish Law, seeking its true meaning, sometimes in opposition to other traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999164â67_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999164â67-416">[402]</a></sup> Jesus put love at the center of the Law, and following that Law was an apocalyptic necessity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999164â67_416-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999164â67-416">[402]</a></sup> His ethical teachings called for forgiveness, not judging others, loving enemies, and caring for the poor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999171â76_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999171â76-417">[403]</a></sup> Funk and Hoover note that typical of Jesus were <a href="/wiki/Paradox" title="Paradox">paradoxical</a> or surprising turns of phrase, such as advising one, when struck on the cheek, <a href="/wiki/Turning_the_other_cheek" title="Turning the other cheek">to offer the other cheek</a> to be struck as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar1993294_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunkHooverThe_Jesus_Seminar1993294-419">[405]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Gospels portray Jesus teaching in well-defined sessions, such as the <a href="/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Mount" title="Sermon on the Mount">Sermon on the Mount</a> in the Gospel of Matthew or the parallel <a href="/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Plain" title="Sermon on the Plain">Sermon on the Plain</a> in Luke. According to Gerd Theissen and Annette Merz, these teaching sessions include authentic teachings of Jesus, but the scenes were invented by the respective evangelists to frame these teachings, which had originally been recorded without context.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199817â62_115-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199817â62-115">[106]</a></sup> While Jesus' <a href="/wiki/Miracle" title="Miracle">miracles</a> fit within the social context of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_history" title="Ancient history">antiquity</a>, he defined them differently. First, he attributed them to the faith of those healed. Second, he connected them to <a href="/wiki/Eschatology" title="Eschatology">end times</a> prophecy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998310_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998310-420">[406]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jesus chose <a href="/wiki/Apostles_in_the_New_Testament" title="Apostles in the New Testament">twelve disciples</a> (the "Twelve"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199310_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199310-421">[407]</a></sup> evidently as an <a href="/wiki/Apocalypticism" title="Apocalypticism">apocalyptic</a> message.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87-422">[408]</a></sup> All three Synoptics mention the Twelve, although the names on Luke's list vary from those in Mark and Matthew, suggesting that Christians were not certain who all the disciples were.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87_422-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87-422">[408]</a></sup> The twelve disciples might have represented the twelve original <a href="/wiki/Twelve_Tribes_of_Israel" title="Twelve Tribes of Israel">tribes of Israel</a>, which would be restored once God's rule was instituted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87_422-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87-422">[408]</a></sup> The disciples were reportedly meant to be the rulers of the tribes in the coming Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[409]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87_422-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87-422">[408]</a></sup> According to Bart Ehrman, Jesus' promise that the Twelve would rule is historical, because the Twelve included <a href="/wiki/Judas_Iscariot" title="Judas Iscariot">Judas Iscariot</a>. In Ehrman's view, no Christians would have invented a line from Jesus, promising rulership to the disciple who betrayed him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87_422-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999186â87-422">[408]</a></sup>
In Mark, the disciples play hardly any role other than a negative one. While others sometimes respond to Jesus with complete faith, his disciples are puzzled and doubtful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders1993123â24_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders1993123â24-424">[410]</a></sup> They serve as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foil_(literature)" title="Foil (literature)">foil</a> to Jesus and to other characters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders1993123â24_424-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders1993123â24-424">[410]</a></sup> The failings of the disciples are probably exaggerated in Mark, and the disciples make a better showing in Matthew and Luke.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders1993123â24_424-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders1993123â24-424">[410]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sanders says that Jesus' mission was not about <a href="/wiki/Repentance" title="Repentance">repentance</a>, although he acknowledges that this opinion is unpopular. He argues that repentance appears as a strong theme only in Luke, that repentance was <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a>'s message, and that Jesus' ministry would not have been scandalous if the sinners he ate with had been repentant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders1993230â36_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders1993230â36-425">[411]</a></sup> According to Theissen and Merz, Jesus taught that God was generously giving people an opportunity to repent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998336_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998336-426">[412]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Role">Role</span></h4>
<p>Jesus taught that an apocalyptic figure, the "<a href="/wiki/Son_of_man_(Christianity)" title="Son of man (Christianity)">Son of Man</a>", would soon come on clouds of glory to gather the elect, or chosen ones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[413]</a></sup> He referred to himself as a "<a href="/wiki/Son_of_man" title="Son of man">son of man</a>" in the colloquial sense of "a person", but scholars do not know whether he also meant himself when he referred to the heavenly "Son of Man". <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">Paul the Apostle</a> and other early Christians interpreted the "Son of Man" as the risen Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-10"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Gospels refer to Jesus not only as a messiah but in the absolute form as "the Messiah" or, equivalently, "the Christ". In early Judaism, this absolute form of the title is not found, but only phrases such as "his messiah". The tradition is ambiguous enough to leave room for debate as to whether Jesus defined his <a href="/wiki/Eschatology" title="Eschatology">eschatological</a> role as that of the messiah.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Messiah_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Messiah-428">[414]</a></sup> The Jewish messianic tradition included many different forms, some of them focused on a messiah figure and others not.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998533â40_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998533â40-429">[415]</a></sup> Based on the Christian tradition, <a href="/wiki/Gerd_Theissen" title="Gerd Theissen">Gerd Theissen</a> advances the hypothesis that Jesus saw himself in messianic terms but did not claim the title "Messiah".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998533â40_429-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998533â40-429">[415]</a></sup> Bart Ehrman argues that Jesus did consider himself to be the messiah, albeit in the sense that he would be the king of the new political order that God would usher in,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[416]</a></sup> not in the sense that most people today think of the term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[417]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Passover_and_crucifixion_in_Jerusalem">Passover and crucifixion in Jerusalem</span></h4>
<p>Around AD 30, Jesus and his followers traveled from <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a> to <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> to observe <a href="/wiki/Passover" title="Passover">Passover</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199310_421-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199310-421">[407]</a></sup> Jesus caused a disturbance in the <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">Second Temple</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199311_31-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199311-31">[25]</a></sup> which was the center of Jewish religious and civil authority. Sanders associates it with Jesus' prophecy that the Temple would be totally demolished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders1993254â62_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders1993254â62-432">[418]</a></sup> Jesus held a last meal with his disciples, which is the origin of the Christian sacrament of bread and wine. His words as recorded in the Synoptic gospels and Paul's <a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_to_the_Corinthians" title="First Epistle to the Corinthians">First Letter to the Corinthians</a> do not entirely agree, but this symbolic meal appears to have pointed to Jesus' place in the coming Kingdom of God when very probably Jesus knew he was about to be killed, although he may have still hoped that God might yet intervene.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders1993263â64_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders1993263â64-433">[419]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Gospels say that Jesus was betrayed to the authorities by a disciple, and many scholars consider this report to be highly reliable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ_190-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ-190">[179]</a></sup> He was executed on the orders of <a href="/wiki/Pontius_Pilate" title="Pontius Pilate">Pontius Pilate</a>, the Roman <a href="/wiki/Prefect" title="Prefect">prefect</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judea_(Roman_province)" title="Judea (Roman province)">Judaea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199311_31-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199311-31">[25]</a></sup> Pilate most likely saw Jesus' reference to the Kingdom of God as a threat to Roman authority and worked with the Temple elites to have Jesus executed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998465â66_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998465â66-434">[420]</a></sup> The Sadducean high-priestly leaders of the Temple more plausibly had Jesus executed for political reasons than for his teaching.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ_190-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ-190">[179]</a></sup> They may have regarded him as a threat to stability, especially after he caused a disturbance at the Second Temple.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ_190-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ-190">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JE1906_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-JE1906-50">[43]</a></sup> Other factors, such as Jesus' triumphal entry into Jerusalem, may have contributed to this decision.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders1993269â73_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders1993269â73-435">[421]</a></sup> Most scholars consider Jesus' crucifixion to be factual, because early Christians would not have invented the painful death of their leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunn2003339_7-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunn2003339-7">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeier2006126â28_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeier2006126â28-436">[422]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="After_crucifixion">After crucifixion</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Resurrection_Beaufort_arms_in_border_(f._131)_Cropped.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2417" data-file-width="1894" decoding="async" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/The_Resurrection_Beaufort_arms_in_border_%28f._131%29_Cropped.jpg/180px-The_Resurrection_Beaufort_arms_in_border_%28f._131%29_Cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/The_Resurrection_Beaufort_arms_in_border_%28f._131%29_Cropped.jpg/270px-The_Resurrection_Beaufort_arms_in_border_%28f._131%29_Cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/The_Resurrection_Beaufort_arms_in_border_%28f._131%29_Cropped.jpg/360px-The_Resurrection_Beaufort_arms_in_border_%28f._131%29_Cropped.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Resurrection_Beaufort_arms_in_border_(f._131)_Cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Resurrection of Christ from a 16th-century manuscript of <i>La Passion de Nostre Seigneur</i></div></div></div>
<p>After Jesus' death, his followers said he was restored to life, although exact details of their experiences are unclear. The gospel reports contradict each other, possibly suggesting competition among those claiming to have seen him first rather than deliberate fraud.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders1993276â81_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders1993276â81-437">[423]</a></sup> On the other hand, <a href="/wiki/L._Michael_White" title="L. Michael White">L. Michael White</a> suggests that inconsistencies in the Gospels reflect differences in the agendas of their unknown authors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-White_393-1"><a href="#cite_note-White-393">[379]</a></sup> The followers of Jesus formed a community to wait for his return and the founding of his kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199311_31-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199311-31">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Portraits_of_Jesus">Portraits of Jesus</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Historical_Jesus" title="Historical Jesus">Historical Jesus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Quest_for_the_historical_Jesus" title="Quest for the historical Jesus">Quest for the historical Jesus</a></div>
<p>Modern research on the historical Jesus has not led to a unified picture of the historical figure, partly because of the variety of academic traditions represented by the scholars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenWinter20024â5_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenWinter20024â5-438">[424]</a></sup> Given the scarcity of historical sources, it is generally difficult for any scholar to construct a portrait of Jesus that can be considered historically valid beyond the basic elements of his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009117â25_112-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009117â25-112">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman199922â23_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman199922â23-113">[104]</a></sup> The portraits of Jesus constructed in these quests often differ from each other, and from the image portrayed in the Gospels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenWinter20025_343-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenWinter20025-343">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Historical_Jesus,_Quest_of_the_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Historical_Jesus,_Quest_of_the-439">[425]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jesus is seen as the founder of, in the words of Sanders, a "renewal movement within Judaism". One of the criteria used to discern historical details in the "third quest" is the criterion of plausibility, relative to Jesus' Jewish context and to his influence on Christianity. A disagreement in contemporary research is whether Jesus was <a href="/wiki/Apocalypticism" title="Apocalypticism">apocalyptic</a>. Most scholars conclude that he was an apocalyptic preacher, like <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">Paul the Apostle</a>. In contrast, certain prominent North American scholars, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Burton_Mack" title="Burton Mack">Burton Mack</a> and John Dominic Crossan, advocate for a non-<a href="/wiki/Eschatology" title="Eschatology">eschatological</a> Jesus, one who is more of a <a href="/wiki/Cynicism_(philosophy)" title="Cynicism (philosophy)">Cynic</a> <a href="/wiki/Sage_(philosophy)" title="Sage (philosophy)">sage</a> than an apocalyptic preacher.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz19981â15_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz19981â15-440">[426]</a></sup> In addition to portraying Jesus as an apocalyptic prophet, a charismatic healer or a <a href="/wiki/Cynicism_(philosophy)" title="Cynicism (philosophy)">cynic philosopher</a>, some scholars portray him as the true messiah or an <a href="/wiki/Egalitarianism" title="Egalitarianism">egalitarian</a> prophet of <a href="/wiki/Social_change" title="Social change">social change</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CambHist23_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-CambHist23-441">[427]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009124â25_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKÃ¶stenbergerKellumQuarles2009124â25-442">[428]</a></sup> However, the attributes described in the portraits sometimes overlap, and scholars who differ on some attributes sometimes agree on others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[429]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the 18th century, scholars have occasionally put forth that Jesus was a political national messiah, but the evidence for this portrait is negligible. Likewise, the proposal that Jesus was a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zealots_(Judea)" title="Zealots (Judea)">Zealot</a> does not fit with the earliest strata of the Synoptic tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ_190-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Jesus_Christ-190">[179]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Titles_and_other_names_for_Jesus">Titles and other names for Jesus</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament" title="Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament">Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament</a></div>
<p>In addition to "Christ", Jesus is affectionately called by various other names or titles throughout the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[430]</a></sup> Some of them include:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r998391716">.mw-parser-output .div-col{margin-top:0.3em;column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .div-col-small{font-size:90%}.mw-parser-output .div-col-rules{column-rule:1px solid #aaa}.mw-parser-output .div-col dl,.mw-parser-output .div-col ol,.mw-parser-output .div-col ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .div-col li,.mw-parser-output .div-col dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 20em;">
<ul><li>Almighty (Revelation 1:8)</li>
<li>Alpha and Omega (Revelation 22:13)</li>
<li>Advocate (1 John 2:1)</li>
<li>Author and Perfecter of Our Faith (Hebrews 12:2)</li>
<li>Authority (Matthew 28:18)</li>
<li>Bread of Life (John 6:35)</li>
<li>Beloved Son of God (Matthew 3:17)</li>
<li>Counsellor (Isaiah 9:6)</li>
<li>Creator (John 1:3)</li>
<li>Chief Shepherd (1 Pet. 5:4)</li>
<li>The Bridegroom (Matthew 9:15)</li>
<li>The Bread of Life (John 6:35)</li>
<li>Deliverer (1 Thessalonians 1:10)</li>
<li>The Door (John 10:9)</li>
<li>Eternal (John 8:58)</li>
<li>Faithful and True (Revelation 19:11)</li>
<li>God (John 20:28, 2 Peter 1:1)</li>
<li>Good Shepherd (John 10:11)</li>
<li>Great High Priest (Hebrews 4:14)</li>
<li>Head of the Church (Ephesians 1:22)</li>
<li>Holy Servant (Acts 4:29-30)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/I_am_(biblical_term)" title="I am (biblical term)">I am</a> (John 8:58)</li>
<li>Immanuel (Isaiah 7:14)</li>
<li>Indescribable Gift (2 Corinthians 9:15)</li>
<li>Judge (Acts 10:42)</li>
<li>King of Kings (Revelation 17:14)</li>
<li>Lamb of God (John 1:29)</li>
<li>The Life (John 11:25, 14:6)</li>
<li>Light of the World (John 8:12)</li>
<li>Lion of the Tribe of Judah (Revelation 5:5)</li>
<li>Lord of All (Philippians 2:9-11)</li>
<li>Mediator (I Timothy 2:5)</li>
<li>The Messiah (John 1:41)</li>
<li>One Who Sets Free (John 8:36)</li>
<li>Our Hope (1 Timothy 1:1)</li>
<li>Peace (Ephesians 2:14)</li>
<li>Prophet (Mark 6:4)</li>
<li>The Resurrection (John 11:25)</li>
<li>Risen Lord (1 Corinthians 15:3-4)</li>
<li>The Rock (1 Corinthians 10:4)</li>
<li>Sacrifice for Our Sins (1 John 4:10)</li>
<li>Savior (Luke 2:11)</li>
<li>Son of Man (Luke 19:10)</li>
<li>Son of the Most High (Luke 1:32)</li>
<li>Supreme Creator Over All (Colossians 1:16-17)</li>
<li>True Vine (John 15:1)</li>
<li>The Truth (John 8:32, 14:6)</li>
<li>Victorious One (Revelation 3:21)</li>
<li>The Way (John 14:6)</li>
<li>The Word (John 1:1)</li></ul>
</div>
<h3><span id="Language.2C_ethnicity.2C_and_appearance"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Language,_ethnicity,_and_appearance">Language, ethnicity, and appearance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Language_of_Jesus" title="Language of Jesus">Language of Jesus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Race_and_appearance_of_Jesus" title="Race and appearance of Jesus">Race and appearance of Jesus</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CompositeJesus.JPG"><img alt="Twelve depictions of Jesus from around the world" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="398" data-file-width="272" decoding="async" height="263" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/CompositeJesus.JPG/180px-CompositeJesus.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/CompositeJesus.JPG/270px-CompositeJesus.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/CompositeJesus.JPG 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CompositeJesus.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The ethnicity of Jesus in art has been influenced by cultural settings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoulden200663â99_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoulden200663â99-445">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Erricker44_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-Erricker44-446">[432]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Jesus grew up in Galilee and much of his ministry took place there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreenMcKnightMarshall1992442_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreenMcKnightMarshall1992442-447">[433]</a></sup> The languages spoken in Galilee and Judea during the 1st century AD include <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Palestinian_Aramaic" title="Jewish Palestinian Aramaic">Jewish Palestinian Aramaic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Koine_Greek" title="Koine Greek">Greek</a>, with Aramaic being predominant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BarrLang_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-BarrLang-448">[434]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Porter110_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-Porter110-449">[435]</a></sup> There is substantial consensus that Jesus gave most of his teachings in Aramaic<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunn2003313â15_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunn2003313â15-450">[436]</a></sup> in the <a href="/wiki/Galilean_dialect" title="Galilean dialect">Galilean dialect</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen_C._Myers_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-Allen_C._Myers-451">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopedia_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopedia-452">[438]</a></sup>
