</p><p>Modern scholars agree that Jesus was a Jew of 1st-century <a href="/wiki/Palestine_(region)" title="Palestine (region)">Palestine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman199996_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman199996-453">[439]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Ioudaios" title="Ioudaios">Ioudaios</a></i> in New Testament Greek<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[o]</a></sup> is a term which in the contemporary context may refer to religion (<a href="/wiki/Second_Temple_Judaism" title="Second Temple Judaism">Second Temple Judaism</a>), ethnicity (of Judea), or both.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[442]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[443]</a></sup> In a review of the state of modern scholarship, <a href="/wiki/Amy-Jill_Levine" title="Amy-Jill Levine">Amy-Jill Levine</a> writes that the entire question of ethnicity is "fraught with difficulty", and that "beyond recognizing that 'Jesus was Jewish', rarely does the scholarship address what being 'Jewish' means".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevine200610_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevine200610-459">[444]</a></sup>
</p><p>The New Testament gives no description of the physical appearance of Jesus before his deathâit is generally indifferent to racial appearances and does not refer to the features of the people it mentions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[445]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Perkinson30_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-Perkinson30-461">[446]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kidd48_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kidd48-462">[447]</a></sup> Jesus probably looked like a typical Jewish man of his time; standing around 166Â cm (5Â ft 5Â in) tall with a thin but fit build, <a href="/wiki/Olive_skin" title="Olive skin">olive-brown skin</a>, brown eyes and short, dark hair. He also likely had a beard that was not particularly long or heavy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[448]</a></sup> His clothing may have suggested poverty consisting of a mantle (shawl) with tassels, a knee-length basic tunic and sandals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[449]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Christ_myth_theory">Christ myth theory</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Christ_myth_theory" title="Christ myth theory">Christ myth theory</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Christ_myth_theory" title="Christ myth theory">Christ myth theory</a> is the hypothesis that Jesus of Nazareth never existed; or if he did, that he had virtually nothing to do with the founding of Christianity and the accounts in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gospels" title="Gospels">gospels</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[p]</a></sup> Stories of Jesus' birth, along with other key events, have so many mythic elements that some scholars have suggested that Jesus himself was a <a href="/wiki/Myth" title="Myth">myth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998113â15_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz1998113â15-467">[451]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Bruno_Bauer" title="Bruno Bauer">Bruno Bauer</a> (1809â1882) taught that the first Gospel was a work of literature that produced history rather than described it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199890_468-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199890-468">[452]</a></sup>
According to <a href="/wiki/Albert_Kalthoff" title="Albert Kalthoff">Albert Kalthoff</a> (1850â1906), a social movement produced Jesus when it encountered Jewish messianic expectations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199890_468-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199890-468">[452]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Arthur_Drews" title="Arthur Drews">Arthur Drews</a> (1865â1935) saw Jesus as the concrete form of a myth that predated Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199890_468-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199890-468">[452]</a></sup>
Despite arguments put forward by authors who have questioned the existence of a <a href="/wiki/Historical_Jesus" title="Historical Jesus">historical Jesus</a>, there remains a strong consensus in <a href="/wiki/Historical_criticism" title="Historical criticism">historical-critical biblical scholarship</a> that a historical Jesus did live in that area and in that time period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DunnPaul35_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-DunnPaul35-469">[453]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Then'_2004_page_34_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-Then'_2004_page_34-470">[454]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jesus'_page_200_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jesus'_page_200-471">[455]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jesus'_page_145_472-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jesus'_page_145-472">[456]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-voorst16_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-voorst16-473">[457]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Perspectives">Perspectives</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religious_perspectives_on_Jesus" title="Religious perspectives on Jesus">Religious perspectives on Jesus</a></div>
<p>Apart from his own disciples and followers, the Jews of Jesus' day generally rejected him as the messiah, as do the great majority of Jews today.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Christian theologians, <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_council" title="Ecumenical council">ecumenical councils</a>, reformers and others have written extensively about Jesus over the centuries. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_sect" title="Christian sect">Christian sects</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_schisms" title="Christian schisms">schisms</a> have often been defined or characterized by their descriptions of Jesus. Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/Manichaeism" title="Manichaeism">Manichaeans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gnosticism" title="Gnosticism">Gnostics</a>, Muslims, <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druzes</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hitti_1928_37_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hitti_1928_37-474">[458]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dana_2008_17_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dana_2008_17-475">[459]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith">BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith</a>, and others, have found prominent places for Jesus in their religions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[461]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[462]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Christian">Christian</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Christianity" title="Jesus in Christianity">Jesus in Christianity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christ_(title)" title="Christ (title)">Christ (title)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Christology" title="Christology">Christology</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shield-Trinity-Scutum-Fidei-English.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="468" data-file-width="520" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Shield-Trinity-Scutum-Fidei-English.svg/220px-Shield-Trinity-Scutum-Fidei-English.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Shield-Trinity-Scutum-Fidei-English.svg/330px-Shield-Trinity-Scutum-Fidei-English.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Shield-Trinity-Scutum-Fidei-English.svg/440px-Shield-Trinity-Scutum-Fidei-English.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shield-Trinity-Scutum-Fidei-English.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Trinity" title="Trinity">Trinity</a> is the belief in Christianity that God is one God in three persons: <a href="/wiki/God_the_Father" title="God the Father">God the Father</a>, <a href="/wiki/God_the_Son" title="God the Son">God the Son</a> (<a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Christianity" title="Jesus in Christianity">Jesus</a>), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit_(Christianity)" title="Holy Spirit (Christianity)">God the Holy Spirit</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Christ_with_beard.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="558" decoding="async" height="237" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Christ_with_beard.jpg/220px-Christ_with_beard.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Christ_with_beard.jpg/330px-Christ_with_beard.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Christ_with_beard.jpg/440px-Christ_with_beard.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Christ_with_beard.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jesus is depicted with the <a href="/wiki/Alpha_and_Omega" title="Alpha and Omega">Alpha and Omega</a> letters in the <a href="/wiki/Catacombs_of_Rome" title="Catacombs of Rome">Catacombs of Rome</a> from the 4thÂ century.</div></div></div>
<p>Jesus is the central figure of Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcGrath20064â6_128-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcGrath20064â6-128">[119]</a></sup> Although Christian views of Jesus vary, it is possible to summarize the key beliefs shared among major <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">denominations</a>, as stated in their <a href="/wiki/Catechism" title="Catechism">catechetical</a> or <a href="/wiki/Confessionalism_(religion)" title="Confessionalism (religion)">confessional</a> texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[464]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[465]</a></sup> Christian views of Jesus are derived from various sources, including the canonical gospels and New Testament letters such as the Pauline epistles and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Johannine_writings" title="Johannine writings">Johannine writings</a>. These documents outline the key beliefs held by Christians about Jesus, including his divinity, humanity, and earthly life, and that he is the Christ and the <a href="/wiki/Son_of_God_(Christianity)" title="Son of God (Christianity)">Son of God</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[466]</a></sup> Despite their many shared beliefs, not all Christian denominations agree on all doctrines, and both <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="EastâWest Schism">major and minor differences</a> on teachings and beliefs have persisted throughout Christianity for centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Great_Schism_483-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Great_Schism-483">[467]</a></sup>
</p><p>The New Testament states that the resurrection of Jesus is the foundation of the Christian faith.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[468]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[469]</a></sup> Christians believe that through his <a href="/wiki/Sacrifice#Christinity" title="Sacrifice">sacrificial</a> death and resurrection, humans can be <a href="/wiki/Reconciliation_(theology)" title="Reconciliation (theology)">reconciled with God</a> and are thereby offered <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salvation_(Christianity)" title="Salvation (Christianity)">salvation</a> and the promise of <a href="/wiki/Eternal_life_(Christianity)" title="Eternal life (Christianity)">eternal life</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oxford_Companion_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Companion-35">[29]</a></sup> Recalling the words of John the Baptist on the day after Jesus' baptism, these doctrines sometimes refer to Jesus as the Lamb of God, who was crucified to fulfill his role as the servant of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[470]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[471]</a></sup> Jesus is thus seen as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Adam" title="New Adam">new and last Adam</a>, whose obedience contrasts with <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_man" title="Fall of man">Adam's disobedience</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[472]</a></sup> Christians view Jesus as a role model, whose God-focused life believers are encouraged to imitate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcGrath20064â6_128-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcGrath20064â6-128">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>At present, most Christians believe that Jesus is both human and the Son of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman2014_489-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman2014-489">[473]</a></sup> While there has been <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christological_controversies" title="Christological controversies">theological debate</a> over his nature,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[q]</a></sup> Trinitarian Christians generally believe that Jesus is the Logos, God's incarnation and <a href="/wiki/God_the_Son" title="God the Son">God the Son</a>, both fully divine and fully human. However, the doctrine of the Trinity is not universally accepted among Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[475]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[476]</a></sup> With the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a>, Christians such as <a href="/wiki/Michael_Servetus" title="Michael Servetus">Michael Servetus</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socinian" title="Socinian">Socinians</a> started questioning the ancient creeds that had established Jesus' two natures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-13"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup> Nontrinitarian Christian groups include <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[477]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Unitarianism" title="Unitarianism">Unitarians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Antitrinitarianism_490-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Antitrinitarianism-490">[474]</a></sup>
</p><p>Christians revere not only Jesus himself, but also <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Name_of_Jesus" title="Name of Jesus">his name</a>. Devotions to the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Name_of_Jesus" title="Holy Name of Jesus">Holy Name of Jesus</a> go back to the earliest days of Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[478]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoulden2006426_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoulden2006426-496">[479]</a></sup> These devotions and feasts exist in both <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Church" title="Western Church">Western Christianity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoulden2006426_496-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoulden2006426-496">[479]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Jewish">Jewish</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Judaism%27s_view_of_Jesus" title="Judaism's view of Jesus">Judaism's view of Jesus</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_the_Talmud" title="Jesus in the Talmud">Jesus in the Talmud</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> rejects the idea of Jesus (or any future Jewish messiah) being God,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JE1906_50-2"><a href="#cite_note-JE1906-50">[43]</a></sup> or a mediator to God, or part of a Trinity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[480]</a></sup> It holds that Jesus is not the messiah, arguing that he neither fulfilled the Messianic prophecies in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tanakh" title="Tanakh">Tanakh</a> nor embodied the personal qualifications of the Messiah.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[481]</a></sup> Jews argue that Jesus did not fulfill prophesies to build the <a href="/wiki/Third_Temple" title="Third Temple">Third Temple</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[482]</a></sup> gather Jews back to Israel,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[483]</a></sup> bring world peace,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[484]</a></sup> and unite humanity under the God of Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[485]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-simmons_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-simmons-503">[486]</a></sup> Furthermore, according to Jewish tradition, there were no prophets after <a href="/wiki/Malachi" title="Malachi">Malachi</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[487]</a></sup> who delivered his prophesies in the 5th century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[488]</a></sup>
</p><p>Judaic criticism of Jesus is long-standing, and includes a <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_the_Talmud" title="Jesus in the Talmud">range of stories</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Talmud" title="Talmud">Talmud</a>, written and compiled from the 3rd to the 5th century AD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[489]</a></sup> In one such story, <i><a href="/wiki/Yeshu" title="Yeshu">Yeshu</a> HaNozri</i> ("Jesus the Nazarene"), a lewd apostate, is executed by the Jewish high court for spreading idolatry and practicing magic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[490]</a></sup> According to some, the form Yeshu is an <a href="/wiki/Acronym" title="Acronym">acronym</a> which in Hebrew reads: "may his name and memory be blotted out."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[491]</a></sup> The majority of contemporary scholars consider that this material provides no information on the historical Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199874â75_509-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETheissenMerz199874â75-509">[492]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Mishneh_Torah" title="Mishneh Torah">Mishneh Torah</a></i>, a late 12th-century work of <a href="/wiki/Halakha" title="Halakha">Jewish law</a> written by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moses_Maimonides" title="Moses Maimonides">Moses Maimonides</a>, states that Jesus is a "stumbling block" who makes "the majority of the world to err and serve a god other than the Lord".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[493]</a></sup>
</p><p>Medieval Hebrew literature contains the anecdotal "Episode of Jesus" (known also as <i><a href="/wiki/Toledot_Yeshu" title="Toledot Yeshu">Toledot Yeshu</a></i>), in which Jesus is described as being the son of Joseph, the son of <a href="/wiki/Tiberius_Julius_Abdes_Pantera" title="Tiberius Julius Abdes Pantera">Pandera</a> (see: <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Translation:Story_of_Jesus" title="s:Translation:Story of Jesus"><i>Episode of Jesus</i></a>). The account portrays Jesus as an impostor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sutcliffe2005_511-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sutcliffe2005-511">[494]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Manichaeism">Manichaeism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Manichaeism" title="Jesus in Manichaeism">Jesus in Manichaeism</a></div>
<p>Manicheanism was the first organised religion outside of Christianity to venerate Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[495]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reeves1996_513-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reeves1996-513">[496]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[497]</a></sup> He is considered one of the four prophets, along with <a href="/wiki/Zoroaster" title="Zoroaster">Zoroaster</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mani_(prophet)" title="Mani (prophet)">Mani</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[498]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SNC_Lieu_516-0"><a href="#cite_note-SNC_Lieu-516">[499]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Islamic">Islamic</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Islam" title="Jesus in Islam">Jesus in Islam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jesus_Name_in_Arabic.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="208" data-file-width="214" decoding="async" height="194" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Jesus_Name_in_Arabic.gif/200px-Jesus_Name_in_Arabic.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/19/Jesus_Name_in_Arabic.gif 1.5x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jesus_Name_in_Arabic.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The name <i>Jesus son of Mary</i> written in <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calligraphy" title="Islamic calligraphy">Islamic calligraphy</a> followed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peace_be_upon_him_(Islam)" title="Peace be upon him (Islam)">Peace be upon him</a></div></div></div>
<p>A major figure in Islam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uscsite_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-uscsite-43">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siddiqui_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-Siddiqui-45">[38]</a></sup> Jesus (often referred to by his Quranic name <span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Isa_(name)" title="Isa (name)"><i>Ê¿ÄªsÄ</i></a></i></span>) is considered to be a <a href="/wiki/Prophets_and_messengers_in_Islam" title="Prophets and messengers in Islam">messenger</a> of <a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">God</a> (<span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All%C4%81h" title="AllÄh">AllÄh</a></i></span>) and the messiah (<a href="/wiki/Masih_(title)" title="Masih (title)"><span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">al-MasÄ«á¸¥</i></span></a>) who was sent to guide the <a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">Children of Israel</a> (<span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">BanÄ« IsrÄÊ¾Ä«l</i></span>) with a new scripture, the Gospel (referred to in Islam as <a href="/wiki/Gospel_in_Islam" title="Gospel in Islam"><span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">InjÄ«l</i></span></a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CEI_44-1"><a href="#cite_note-CEI-44">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[500]</a></sup> Muslims regard the gospels accounts in the New Testament as partially authentic, and believe that Jesus' original message was altered (<a href="/wiki/Tahrif" title="Tahrif"><span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">taá¸¥rÄ«f</i></span></a>) and that <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_in_Islam" title="Muhammad in Islam">Muhammad</a> came later to revive it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[501]</a></sup> Belief in Jesus (and all other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prophets_in_Islam" title="Prophets in Islam">messengers of God</a>) is a requirement for being a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[502]</a></sup> The Quran mentions Jesus by name 25 timesâmore often than Muhammad<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[503]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[504]</a></sup>âand emphasizes that Jesus was a mortal human who, like all other prophets, had been divinely chosen to spread God's message.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-comparative_522-0"><a href="#cite_note-comparative-522">[505]</a></sup> While the Quran affirms the Virgin birth of Jesus, he is considered to be neither an incarnation nor a <a href="/wiki/Son_of_God_(Christianity)" title="Son of God (Christianity)">son of God</a>. Islamic texts emphasize a strict notion of <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheism</a> (<span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taw%E1%B8%A5%C4%ABd" title="Tawá¸¥Ä«d">tawá¸¥Ä«d</a></i></span>) and forbid the association of partners with God, which would be <a href="/wiki/Shirk_(Islam)" title="Shirk (Islam)">idolatry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[506]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Quran describes the annunciation to Mary (<a href="/wiki/Mary_in_Islam" title="Mary in Islam"><span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">Maryam</i></span></a>) by the Holy Spirit that she is to give birth to Jesus while remaining a virgin. It calls the virgin birth a miracle that occurred by the will of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RobB32_524-0"><a href="#cite_note-RobB32-524">[507]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peters23_525-0"><a href="#cite_note-Peters23-525">[508]</a></sup> The Quran (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Q21:91" title="Q21:91">Q21:91</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Q66:12" title="Q66:12">Q66:12</a>) states that God breathed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit_(Islam)" title="Holy Spirit (Islam)">his spirit</a> into Mary while she was chaste.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RobB32_524-1"><a href="#cite_note-RobB32-524">[507]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peters23_525-1"><a href="#cite_note-Peters23-525">[508]</a></sup> Jesus is called a "spirit from God" because he was born through the action of the Spirit,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RobB32_524-2"><a href="#cite_note-RobB32-524">[507]</a></sup> but that belief does not imply <a href="/wiki/Pre-existence_of_Christ" title="Pre-existence of Christ">his pre-existence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[509]</a></sup>
</p><p>To aid in his ministry to the Jewish people, Jesus was given the ability to perform <a href="/wiki/Miracle" title="Miracle">miracles</a>, by permission of God rather than by his own power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morgan_48-1"><a href="#cite_note-Morgan-48">[41]</a></sup> Through his ministry, Jesus is seen as a <a href="/wiki/Precursor_(religion)" title="Precursor (religion)">precursor</a> to Muhammad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-comparative_522-1"><a href="#cite_note-comparative-522">[505]</a></sup> In the Quran (<a href="/wiki/An-Nisa" title="An-Nisa">Q4</a>:157â159) it is said that Jesus was not killed but was merely made to appear that way to unbelievers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[510]</a></sup> and that he was raised into the heavens while still alive by God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cite_quran|4|157|style=ref_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-cite_quran|4|157|style=ref-528">[511]</a></sup> According to most classic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunni" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelver_Shi%27ite" title="Twelver Shi'ite">Twelver Shi'ite</a> interpretations of these verses, the likeness of Jesus was cast upon a <a href="/wiki/Substitution_hypothesis" title="Substitution hypothesis">substitute</a> (most often one of the apostles), who was crucified in Jesus' stead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[512]</a></sup> However, some medieval Muslims (among others, the <a href="/wiki/Ghulat" title="Ghulat"><span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">ghulÄt</i></span></a> writing under the name of <a href="/wiki/Al-Mufaddal_ibn_Umar_al-Ju%27fi" title="Al-Mufaddal ibn Umar al-Ju'fi">al-Mufaddal ibn Umar al-Ju'fi</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Brethren_of_Purity" title="Brethren of Purity">Brethren of Purity</a>, various <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isma%27ili" title="Isma'ili">Isma'ili</a> philosophers, and the Sunni mystic <a href="/wiki/Al-Ghazali" title="Al-Ghazali">al-Ghazali</a>) affirmed the historicity of Jesus' crucifixion. These thinkers held the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Docetic" title="Docetic">docetic</a> view that, although Jesus' human form (his body) had died on the cross, his true divine nature (his spirit) had survived and ascended into heaven, so that his death was only an appearance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[513]</a></sup> Nevertheless, to Muslims it is the <i><a href="/wiki/Ascension_of_Jesus" title="Ascension of Jesus">ascension</a></i> rather than the <i><a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">crucifixion</a></i> that constitutes a major event in the life of Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Khalidi_531-0"><a href="#cite_note-Khalidi-531">[514]</a></sup> There is no mention of his resurrection on the third day, and his death plays no special role in <a href="/wiki/Soteriology#Islam" title="Soteriology">Islamic theories of salvation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[515]</a></sup> However, Jesus is a central figure in <a href="/wiki/Islamic_eschatology" title="Islamic eschatology">Islamic eschatology</a>: Muslims believe that <a href="/wiki/Second_Coming#Islam" title="Second Coming">he will return to Earth</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Eschatology" title="Eschatology">end of time</a> and defeat the <a href="/wiki/Antichrist" title="Antichrist">Antichrist</a> (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Masih_ad-Dajjal" title="Masih ad-Dajjal">ad-Dajjal</a></i>) by killing him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CEI_44-2"><a href="#cite_note-CEI-44">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the Quran, the coming of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> was predicted by Jesus: "And remember, Jesus, the son of Mary, said: âO children of Israel! I am Godâs messenger to you, confirming the law (which came) before me, and giving glad tidings of a messenger to come after me, whose name shall be Ahmad'" (Quran 61:6). Through this verse, early Arab Muslims claimed legitimacy for their new faith in the existing religious traditions and the alleged predictions of Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[516]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Isma.27ili_faith"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Isma'ili_faith">Isma'ili faith</span></h4>
<p>According to <a href="/wiki/Al-Qadi_al-Nu%27man" title="Al-Qadi al-Nu'man">Qadi al-Nu'man</a>, a famous Muslim jurist of the <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimid period</a>, Jesus is referred to as the messiah (<span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">al-masÄ«á¸¥</i></span>) in the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> because he was sent to the people who responded to him in order to remove (<i>masaá¸¥a</i>) their impurities, the ailments of their faith; whether apparent (<i><a href="/wiki/Zahir_(Islam)" title="Zahir (Islam)"><span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">áºÄhir</i></span></a></i>) or hidden (<i><a href="/wiki/Batin_(Islam)" title="Batin (Islam)"><span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">bÄá¹­in</i></span></a></i>). <a href="/wiki/Al-Qadi_al-Nu%27man" title="Al-Qadi al-Nu'man">Qadi al-Nu'man</a>, in his work <i>Foundation of Symbolic Interpretation</i> (<span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">AsÄs al-ta'wÄ«l</i></span>), talks about the spiritual birth (<span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">mÄ«lÄd al-bÄá¹­in</i></span>) of Jesus, as an interpretation of his story of physical birth (<span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">mÄ«lÄd al-áºÄhir</i></span>) mentioned in the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>. He says that <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">Mary</a>, the mother of Jesus, is a metaphor for someone who nurtured and instructed Jesus (<span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">lÄhiq</i></span>), rather than physically giving birth to him. <a href="/wiki/Al-Qadi_al-Nu%27man" title="Al-Qadi al-Nu'man">Qadi al-Nu'man</a> explains that Jesus was from the pure progeny of <a href="/wiki/Abraham_in_Islam" title="Abraham in Islam">Abraham</a>, just as <a href="/wiki/Ali" title="Ali">Ali</a> and his sons were from the pure progeny of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>, through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fatimah" title="Fatimah">Fatima</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[517]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ahmadiyya_Islam">Ahmadiyya Islam</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Ahmadiyya_Islam" title="Jesus in Ahmadiyya Islam">Jesus in Ahmadiyya Islam</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">Ahmadiyya</a> Muslim Community has several <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Ahmadiyya_Islam" title="Jesus in Ahmadiyya Islam">distinct teachings</a> about Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[518]</a></sup> Ahmadis believe that he was a mortal man who survived his crucifixion and died a natural death at the age of 120 in <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, and is buried at <a href="/wiki/Roza_Bal" title="Roza Bal">Roza Bal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[519]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Druze_Faith">Druze Faith</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Maqam_Al-masih.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Maqam_Al-masih.jpg/220px-Maqam_Al-masih.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Maqam_Al-masih.jpg/330px-Maqam_Al-masih.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Maqam_Al-masih.jpg/440px-Maqam_Al-masih.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Maqam_Al-masih.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> <a href="/wiki/Maqam_(shrine)" title="Maqam (shrine)">maqam</a> of Al-masih (Jesus) in <a href="/wiki/As-Suwayda_Governorate" title="As-Suwayda Governorate">As-Suwayda Governorate</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> faith, Jesus is considered the <a href="/wiki/Messiah" title="Messiah">Messiah</a> and one of God's important prophets,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hitti_1928_37_474-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hitti_1928_37-474">[458]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dana_2008_17_475-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dana_2008_17-475">[459]</a></sup> being among the seven prophets who appeared in different periods of history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hitti_1928_37_474-2"><a href="#cite_note-Hitti_1928_37-474">[458]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dana_2008_17_475-2"><a href="#cite_note-Dana_2008_17-475">[459]</a></sup> The Druze venerate Jesus "the son of Joseph and Mary" and his <a href="/wiki/Four_Evangelists" title="Four Evangelists">four disciples</a>, who wrote the Gospels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dana47_537-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dana47-537">[520]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the Druze manuscripts Jesus is the Greatest Imam and the incarnation of Ultimate <a href="/wiki/Reason" title="Reason">Reason</a> (<i>Akl</i>) on earth and the first cosmic principle (<i>Hadd</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dana47_537-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dana47-537">[520]</a></sup> and regards Jesus and <a href="/wiki/Hamza_ibn_Ali" title="Hamza ibn Ali">Hamza ibn Ali</a> as the incarnations of one of the five great celestial powers, who form part of their system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[521]</a></sup> Druze believe that Hamza ibn Ali was a <a href="/wiki/Reincarnation" title="Reincarnation">reincarnation</a> of Jesus,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[522]</a></sup> and that <a href="/wiki/Hamza_ibn_Ali" title="Hamza ibn Ali">Hamza ibn Ali</a> is the true Messiah, who directed the deeds of the messiah Jesus "the son of Joseph and Mary", but when Jesus "the son of Joseph and Mary" strayed from the path of the true Messiah, Hamza filled the hearts of the Jews with hatred for him - and for that reason, they crucified him, according to the Druze manuscripts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dana47_537-2"><a href="#cite_note-Dana47-537">[520]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Louis_540-0"><a href="#cite_note-Louis-540">[523]</a></sup> Despite this, <a href="/wiki/Hamza_ibn_Ali" title="Hamza ibn Ali">Hamza ibn Ali</a> took him down from the cross and allowed him to return to his family, in order to prepare men for the preaching of his religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dana47_537-3"><a href="#cite_note-Dana47-537">[520]</a></sup>
</p><p>In an epistle ascribed to one of the founders of Druzism, <a href="/wiki/Baha_al-Din_al-Muqtana" title="Baha al-Din al-Muqtana">Baha al-Din al-Muqtana</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[524]</a></sup> probably written sometime between AD 1027 and AD 1042, accused the Jews of <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">crucifying Jesus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_War_for_Palestine1_542-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_War_for_Palestine1-542">[525]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Bah.C3.A1.CA.BC.C3.AD_Faith"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­_Faith">BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith</span></h3>
<p>The teaching of the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith">BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith</a> consider Jesus to be a <a href="/wiki/Manifestation_of_God_(Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith)" title="Manifestation of God (BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith)">manifestation of God</a>, a BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ concept for prophets<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stockman_543-0"><a href="#cite_note-stockman-543">[526]</a></sup>âintermediaries between God and humanity, serving as messengers and reflecting God's qualities and attributes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manifestation_544-0"><a href="#cite_note-manifestation-544">[527]</a></sup> The BahÃ¡'Ã­ concept emphasizes the simultaneous qualities of humanity and divinity;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manifestation_544-1"><a href="#cite_note-manifestation-544">[527]</a></sup> thus, it is similar to the Christian concept of incarnation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stockman_543-1"><a href="#cite_note-stockman-543">[526]</a></sup> BahÃ¡'Ã­ thought accepts Jesus as the Son of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smith-jesus_545-0"><a href="#cite_note-Smith-jesus-545">[528]</a></sup> In BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ thought, Jesus was a perfect incarnation of God's attributes, but <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_literature" title="BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ literature">BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ teachings</a> reject the idea that "ineffable essence" of the Divinity was contained within a single human body because of their beliefs regarding "<a href="/wiki/Omnipresence" title="Omnipresence">omnipresence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Transcendence_(religion)#BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­_Faith" title="Transcendence (religion)">transcendence</a> of the essence of God".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stockman_543-2"><a href="#cite_note-stockman-543">[526]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27u%27ll%C3%A1h" title="BahÃ¡'u'llÃ¡h">BahÃ¡'u'llÃ¡h</a>, the founder of the BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith, wrote that since each manifestation of God has the same divine attributes, they can be seen as the spiritual "return" of all previous manifestations of God, and the appearance of each new manifestation of God inaugurates a religion that supersedes the former ones, a concept known as <a href="/wiki/Progressive_revelation_(Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD)" title="Progressive revelation (BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­)">progressive revelation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manifestation_544-2"><a href="#cite_note-manifestation-544">[527]</a></sup> BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­s believe that God's plan unfolds gradually through this process as mankind matures, and that some of the manifestations arrive in specific fulfillment of the missions of previous ones. Thus, BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­s believe that BahÃ¡'u'llÃ¡h is the promised return of Christ.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-psmith128_546-0"><a href="#cite_note-psmith128-546">[529]</a></sup> BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ teachings confirm many, but not all, aspects of Jesus as portrayed in the Gospels. BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­s believe in the virgin birth and in the Crucifixion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lepart118_547-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lepart118-547">[530]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cole_548-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cole-548">[531]</a></sup> but see the Resurrection and the miracles of Jesus as symbolic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smith-jesus_545-1"><a href="#cite_note-Smith-jesus-545">[528]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cole_548-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cole-548">[531]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other">Other</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Jesus" title="Criticism of Jesus">Criticism of Jesus</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Liberator_masthead,_1861_Jan_11.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1209" data-file-width="3378" decoding="async" height="104" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/The_Liberator_masthead%2C_1861_Jan_11.jpg/290px-The_Liberator_masthead%2C_1861_Jan_11.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/The_Liberator_masthead%2C_1861_Jan_11.jpg/435px-The_Liberator_masthead%2C_1861_Jan_11.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/The_Liberator_masthead%2C_1861_Jan_11.jpg/580px-The_Liberator_masthead%2C_1861_Jan_11.jpg 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Liberator_masthead,_1861_Jan_11.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jesus depicted as the liberator of Black slaves, on the masthead of the <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States" title="Abolitionism in the United States">Abolitionist</a> paper <i><a href="/wiki/The_Liberator_(newspaper)" title="The Liberator (newspaper)">The Liberator</a></i></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jesus_Image_on_a_Manichaean_Temple_Banner.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1176" data-file-width="1146" decoding="async" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Jesus_Image_on_a_Manichaean_Temple_Banner.jpg/220px-Jesus_Image_on_a_Manichaean_Temple_Banner.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Jesus_Image_on_a_Manichaean_Temple_Banner.jpg/330px-Jesus_Image_on_a_Manichaean_Temple_Banner.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Jesus_Image_on_a_Manichaean_Temple_Banner.jpg/440px-Jesus_Image_on_a_Manichaean_Temple_Banner.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jesus_Image_on_a_Manichaean_Temple_Banner.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Enthroned Jesus image on a <a href="/wiki/Manichaeism" title="Manichaeism">Manichaean</a> temple banner from <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â10th-century</span> <a href="/wiki/Qocho" title="Qocho">Qocho</a></div></div></div>
<p>In Christian Gnosticism (now a largely extinct religious movement),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[532]</a></sup> Jesus was sent from the divine realm and provided the secret knowledge (<a href="/wiki/Gnosis" title="Gnosis">gnosis</a>) necessary for salvation. Most Gnostics believed that Jesus was a human who became possessed by the spirit of "the Christ" at his baptism. This spirit left Jesus' body during the crucifixion, but was rejoined to him when he was raised from the dead. Some Gnostics, however, were <a href="/wiki/Docetism" title="Docetism">docetics</a>, believed that Jesus did not have a physical body, but only appeared to possess one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[533]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hindus</a> consider Jesus to be an <a href="/wiki/Avatar" title="Avatar">avatar</a> or a <a href="/wiki/Sadhu" title="Sadhu">sadhu</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[534]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Paramahansa_Yogananda" title="Paramahansa Yogananda">Paramahansa Yogananda</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Indian_people" title="Indian people">Indian</a> <a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">guru</a>, taught that Jesus was the reincarnation of <a href="/wiki/Elisha" title="Elisha">Elisha</a> and a student of <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a>, the reincarnation of <a href="/wiki/Elijah" title="Elijah">Elijah</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[535]</a></sup> Some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist">Buddhists</a>, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tenzin_Gyatso,_14th_Dalai_Lama" title="Tenzin Gyatso, 14th Dalai Lama">Tenzin Gyatso, the 14th Dalai Lama</a>, regard Jesus as a <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">bodhisattva</a> who dedicated his life to the welfare of people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[536]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_Age" title="New Age">New Age</a> movement entertains a wide variety of views on Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-other_views_554-0"><a href="#cite_note-other_views-554">[537]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theosophy_(Blavatskian)" title="Theosophy (Blavatskian)">Theosophists</a>, from whom many New Age teachings originated,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[538]</a></sup> refer to Jesus as the <a href="/wiki/Master_Jesus" title="Master Jesus">Master Jesus</a>, a spiritual <a href="/wiki/Reform" title="Reform">reformer</a>, and they believe that Christ, after <a href="/wiki/Reincarnation" title="Reincarnation">various incarnations</a>, occupied the body of Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[539]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Urantia_Book" title="The Urantia Book">The Urantia Book</a></i> teaches Jesus is one of more than 700,000 heavenly sons of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[540]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Scientology" title="Jesus in Scientology">Scientologists recognize</a> Jesus (along with other religious figures such as Zoroaster, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>, and Buddha) as part of their "religious heritage".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-other_views_554-1"><a href="#cite_note-other_views-554">[537]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[541]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antony_Theodore" title="Antony Theodore">Antony Theodore</a> in the book <i>Jesus Christ in Love</i> writes that there is an underlying oneness of Jesus' teachings with the messages contained in <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Talmud" title="Talmud">Talmud</a> and <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559"><a href="#cite_note-559">[542]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheist" title="Atheist">Atheists</a> reject Jesus' divinity, but have different views about him â from challenging <a href="/wiki/Mental_health_of_Jesus" title="Mental health of Jesus">his mental health</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[543]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[544]</a></sup> to emphasizing his "moral superiority" (<a href="/wiki/Richard_Dawkins" title="Richard Dawkins">Richard Dawkins</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-562"><a href="#cite_note-562">[545]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Artistic_depictions">Artistic depictions</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Depiction_of_Jesus" title="Depiction of Jesus">Depiction of Jesus</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Christ_Healing_the_Paralytic_-_Dura-Europos_circa_232.jpg"><img alt="An ancient wall painting depicting Jesus" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="1871" decoding="async" height="289" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Christ_Healing_the_Paralytic_-_Dura-Europos_circa_232.jpg/180px-Christ_Healing_the_Paralytic_-_Dura-Europos_circa_232.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Christ_Healing_the_Paralytic_-_Dura-Europos_circa_232.jpg/270px-Christ_Healing_the_Paralytic_-_Dura-Europos_circa_232.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Christ_Healing_the_Paralytic_-_Dura-Europos_circa_232.jpg/360px-Christ_Healing_the_Paralytic_-_Dura-Europos_circa_232.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Christ_Healing_the_Paralytic_-_Dura-Europos_circa_232.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jesus healing a paralytic in one of the first known images of Jesus from <a href="/wiki/Dura-Europos_church" title="Dura-Europos church">Dura Europos</a> in the 3rdÂ century<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563"><a href="#cite_note-563">[546]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Some of the earliest depictions of Jesus at the <a href="/wiki/Dura-Europos_church" title="Dura-Europos church">Dura-Europos church</a> are firmly dated to before 256.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[547]</a></sup> Thereafter, despite the lack of biblical references or historical records, a wide range of depictions of Jesus appeared during the last two millennia, often influenced by cultural settings, political circumstances and theological contexts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoulden200663â99_445-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoulden200663â99-445">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Erricker44_446-1"><a href="#cite_note-Erricker44-446">[432]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Perkinson30_461-1"><a href="#cite_note-Perkinson30-461">[446]</a></sup> As in other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Christian_art" title="Early Christian art">Early Christian art</a>, the earliest depictions date to the late 2nd or early 3rd century, and surviving images are found especially in the <a href="/wiki/Catacombs_of_Rome" title="Catacombs of Rome">Catacombs of Rome</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565"><a href="#cite_note-565">[548]</a></sup>
</p><p>The depiction of Christ in pictorial form was highly <a href="/wiki/Aniconism_in_Christianity" title="Aniconism in Christianity">controversial</a> in the early Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-phschaff_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-phschaff-566">[549]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-567"><a href="#cite_note-567">[r]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elvira36_568-0"><a href="#cite_note-Elvira36-568">[550]</a></sup> From the 5th century onward, flat painted icons became popular in the Eastern Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Icons_569-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Icons-569">[551]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Iconoclasm" title="Byzantine Iconoclasm">Byzantine Iconoclasm</a> acted as a barrier to developments in the East, but by the 9th century, art was permitted again.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoulden200663â99_445-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoulden200663â99-445">[431]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a> brought renewed <a href="/wiki/Aniconism_in_Christianity" title="Aniconism in Christianity">resistance to imagery</a>, but total prohibition was atypical, and Protestant objections to images have tended to reduce since the 16th century. Although large images are generally avoided, few Protestants now object to book illustrations depicting Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-570"><a href="#cite_note-570">[552]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[553]</a></sup> The use of depictions of Jesus is advocated by the leaders of denominations such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglicans" title="Anglicans">Anglicans</a> and Catholics<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RWilliams83_572-0"><a href="#cite_note-RWilliams83-572">[554]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[555]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-574"><a href="#cite_note-574">[556]</a></sup> and is a key element of the Eastern Orthodox tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoninger1999231_575-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoninger1999231-575">[557]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-576"><a href="#cite_note-576">[558]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Transfiguration_of_Jesus_in_Christian_art" title="Transfiguration of Jesus in Christian art">Transfiguration</a> was a major theme in Eastern Christian art, and every <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> monk who had trained in <a href="/wiki/Icon" title="Icon">icon</a> painting had to prove his craft by painting an icon depicting it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[559]</a></sup> Icons receive the external marks of veneration, such as kisses and prostration, and they are thought to be powerful channels of divine grace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Icons_569-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Icons-569">[551]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> brought forth a number of artists who focused on depictions of Jesus; <a href="/wiki/Fra_Angelico" title="Fra Angelico">Fra Angelico</a> and others followed <a href="/wiki/Giotto" title="Giotto">Giotto</a> in the systematic development of uncluttered images.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoulden200663â99_445-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoulden200663â99-445">[431]</a></sup>
</p><p>Before the Protestant Reformation, the <a href="/wiki/Crucifix" title="Crucifix">crucifix</a> was common in Western Christianity. It is a model of the cross with Jesus crucified on it. The crucifix became the central ornament of the altar in the 13th century, a use that has been nearly universal in Roman Catholic churches since then.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Crucifix_578-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Crucifix-578">[560]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jesus appears as an infant in a manger (feed trough) in Christmas creches, which depict the <a href="/wiki/Nativity_scene" title="Nativity scene">Nativity scene</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB16032015_579-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB16032015-579">[561]</a></sup> He is typically joined by Mary, Joseph, animals, shepherds, angels, and the <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Magi" title="Biblical Magi">Magi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB16032015_579-1"><a href="#cite_note-EB16032015-579">[561]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Francis_of_Assisi" title="Francis of Assisi">Francis of Assisi</a> (1181/82â1226) is credited with popularizing the creche, although he probably did not initiate it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB16032015_579-2"><a href="#cite_note-EB16032015-579">[561]</a></sup> The creche reached its height of popularity in the 17th and 18th centuries in southern Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB16032015_579-3"><a href="#cite_note-EB16032015-579">[561]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Associated_relics">Associated relics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Relics_associated_with_Jesus" title="Relics associated with Jesus">Relics associated with Jesus</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shroud_of_Turin_001.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="632" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Shroud_of_Turin_001.jpg/220px-Shroud_of_Turin_001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Shroud_of_Turin_001.jpg/330px-Shroud_of_Turin_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Shroud_of_Turin_001.jpg/440px-Shroud_of_Turin_001.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shroud_of_Turin_001.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Shroud_of_Turin" title="Shroud of Turin">Shroud of Turin</a>, Italy, is the best-known claimed relic of Jesus and one of the most studied artifacts in human history.</div></div></div>
<p>The total destruction that ensued with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(70)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (70)">siege of Jerusalem</a> by the Romans in AD 70 made the survival of items from 1st-century Judea very rare and almost no direct records survive about the history of Judaism from the last part of the 1st century through the 2nd century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevine200624â25_580-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevine200624â25-580">[562]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koester382_581-0"><a href="#cite_note-Koester382-581">[563]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[s]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Margaret_M._Mitchell" title="Margaret M. Mitchell">Margaret M. Mitchell</a> writes that although <a href="/wiki/Eusebius" title="Eusebius">Eusebius</a> reports (<i><a href="/wiki/Church_History_(Eusebius)" title="Church History (Eusebius)">Ecclesiastical History</a></i> III 5.3) that the early Christians left Jerusalem for <a href="/wiki/Pella,_Jordan" title="Pella, Jordan">Pella</a> just before Jerusalem was subjected to the final lockdown, we must accept that no first-hand Christian items from the early Jerusalem Church have reached us.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[565]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Joe_Nickell" title="Joe Nickell">Joe Nickell</a> writes, "as investigation after investigation has shown, not a single, reliably authenticated relic of Jesus exists."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[566]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[t]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, throughout the history of Christianity, a number of <a href="/wiki/Relic" title="Relic">relics</a> attributed to Jesus have been claimed, although doubt has been cast on them. The 16th-century Catholic theologian <a href="/wiki/Erasmus" title="Erasmus">Erasmus</a> wrote sarcastically about the proliferation of relics and the number of buildings that could have been constructed from the wood claimed to be from the <a href="/wiki/True_Cross" title="True Cross">cross used in the Crucifixion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDillenberger19995_589-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDillenberger19995-589">[569]</a></sup> Similarly, while experts debate whether Jesus was crucified with three nails or with four, at least thirty <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_nail" title="Holy nail">holy nails</a> continue to be venerated as relics across Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-590"><a href="#cite_note-590">[570]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some relics, such as purported remnants of the <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_thorns" title="Crown of thorns">crown of thorns</a> placed on the head of Jesus, receive only a modest number of <a href="/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage" title="Christian pilgrimage">pilgrims</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Shroud_of_Turin" title="Shroud of Turin">Shroud of Turin</a> (which is associated with an approved <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_devotion" title="Catholic devotion">Catholic devotion</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Face_of_Jesus" title="Holy Face of Jesus">Holy Face of Jesus</a>), has received millions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-591"><a href="#cite_note-591">[571]</a></sup> including <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">popes</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Paul_II" title="John Paul II">John Paul II</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Benedict XVI</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[572]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-593"><a href="#cite_note-593">[573]</a></sup>
</p>
