<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width reflist-lower-alpha" style="column-width: 30em;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/John_P._Meier" title="John P. Meier">John P. Meier</a> writes that Jesus' birth year is <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â7 or 6Â BC</span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeier1991407_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeier1991407-1">[1]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Karl_Rahner" title="Karl Rahner">Karl Rahner</a> states that the consensus among Christian scholars is <span title="circa">c.</span><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â4 BC</span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahner2004732_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahner2004732-2">[2]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/E._P._Sanders" title="E. P. Sanders">E.Â P. Sanders</a> also favors <span title="circa">c.</span><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â4 BC</span> and refers to the general consensus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199310â11_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199310â11-3">[3]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jack_Finegan" title="Jack Finegan">Jack Finegan</a> uses the study of early Christian traditions to support <span title="circa">c.</span><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â3 or 2Â BC</span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finegan_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-Finegan-4">[4]</a></sup> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/James_Dunn_(theologian)" title="James Dunn (theologian)">James Dunn</a> writes that the baptism and crucifixion of Jesus "command almost universal assent" and "rank so high on the 'almost impossible to doubt or deny' scale of historical facts" that they are often the starting points for the study of the historical Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunn2003339_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunn2003339-7">[6]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bart_Ehrman" title="Bart Ehrman">Bart Ehrman</a> states that the crucifixion of Jesus on the orders of Pontius Pilate is the most certain element about him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999101_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman1999101-8">[7]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_Dominic_Crossan" title="John Dominic Crossan">John Dominic Crossan</a> and Richard G. Watts state that the crucifixion of Jesus is as certain as any historical fact can be.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossanWatts199996_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossanWatts199996-9">[8]</a></sup> Paul R. Eddy and <a href="/wiki/Greg_Boyd_(theologian)" title="Greg Boyd (theologian)">Gregory A. Boyd</a> say that non-Christian confirmation of the crucifixion of Jesus is now "firmly established".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEddyBoyd2007173_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEddyBoyd2007173-10">[9]</a></sup> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Traditionally, Christians believe that Mary conceived her son miraculously by the agency of the Holy Spirit. Muslims believe that she conceived her son miraculously by the command of God. Joseph was from these perspectives the acting adoptive father.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Koine_Greek" title="Koine Greek">Greek</a>: <span lang="grc">á¼¸Î·ÏÎ¿á¿¦Ï</span>, <small><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Ancient_Greek" title="Romanization of Ancient Greek">romanized</a>:Â </small><span title="Ancient Greek-language romanization"><i lang="grc-Latn">IÄsoÃ»s</i></span>, likely from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hebrew" title="Hebrew">Hebrew</a>/<a href="/wiki/Aramaic" title="Aramaic">Aramaic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="he">×Öµ×©××Ö¼×¢Ö·</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Hebrew" title="Romanization of Hebrew">romanized</a>:Â </small><span title="Hebrew-language romanization"><i lang="he-Latn">YÄÅ¡Å«aÊ¿</i></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-exist-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-exist_22-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-exist_22-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-exist_22-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">In a 2011 review of the state of modern scholarship, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bart_Ehrman" title="Bart Ehrman">Bart Ehrman</a> wrote, "He certainly existed, as virtually every competent scholar of antiquity, Christian or non-Christian, agrees".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman2011[httpsarchiveorgdetailsforged_ehrm_2011_000_10544376pagen298_285]_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman2011[httpsarchiveorgdetailsforged_ehrm_2011_000_10544376pagen298_285]-15">[11]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Richard_A._Burridge" title="Richard A. Burridge">Richard A. Burridge</a> states: "There are those who argue that Jesus is a figment of the Church's imagination, that there never was a Jesus at all. I have to say that I do not know any respectable critical scholar who says that any more".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[12]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Robert_M._Price" title="Robert M. Price">Robert M. Price</a> does not believe that Jesus existed, but agrees that this perspective runs against the views of the majority of scholars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[13]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/James_Dunn_(theologian)" title="James Dunn (theologian)">James D. G. Dunn</a> calls the theories of Jesus' non-existence "a thoroughly dead thesis".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[14]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Michael_Grant_(author)" title="Michael Grant (author)">Michael Grant</a> (a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classicist" title="Classicist">classicist</a>) wrote in 1977, "In recent years, 'no serious scholar has ventured to postulate the non historicity of Jesus' or at any rate very few, and they have not succeeded in disposing of the much stronger, indeed very abundant, evidence to the contrary".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grant1977_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-Grant1977-19">[15]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Robert_E._Van_Voorst" title="Robert E. Van Voorst">Robert E. Van Voorst</a> states that biblical scholars and classical historians regard theories of non-existence of Jesus as effectively refuted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Voorst200016_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Voorst200016-20">[16]</a></sup> Writing on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Beast" title="The Daily Beast">The Daily Beast</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Candida_Moss" title="Candida Moss">Candida Moss</a> and Joel Baden state that "there is nigh universal consensus among biblical scholarsÂ â the authentic ones, at leastÂ â that Jesus was, in fact, a real guy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[17]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ehrman writes: "The notion that the Gospel accounts are not completely accurate but still important for the religious truths they try to convey is widely shared in the scholarly world, even though it's not so widely known or believed outside of it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[19]</a></sup><p>Sanders writes: "The earliest Christians did not write a narrative of Jesus' life, but rather made use of, and thus preserved, individual unitsâshort passages about his words and deeds. These units were later moved and arranged by authors and editors. ... Some material has been revised and some created by early Christians."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanders199357_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanders199357-25">[20]</a></sup>
</p></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-39">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Christian" title="Eastern Christian">Eastern Christian</a> churches celebrate Christmas on 25 December of the <a href="/wiki/Julian_calendar" title="Julian calendar">Julian calendar</a>, which currently corresponds to 7 January in the Gregorian calendar.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This article uses quotes from the <a href="/wiki/New_Revised_Standard_Version" title="New Revised Standard Version">New Revised Standard Version</a> of the Bible.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-96">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Powell writes: "[Paul] does cite words or instructions of Jesus in a few places,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[86]</a></sup> but for the most part he displays little interest in the details of Jesus' earthly life and ministry."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[87]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-141">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Compare <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+1%3A6%E2%80%9316&amp;version=NIV" rel="nofollow">Matthew 1:6â16</a></span> with <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke+3%3A23%E2%80%9331&amp;version=NIV" rel="nofollow">Luke 3:23â31</a></span>. See also <a href="/wiki/Genealogy_of_Jesus#Comparison_of_the_two_genealogies" title="Genealogy of Jesus">Genealogy of Jesus Â§Â Comparison of the two genealogies</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-143"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-143">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For an overview of such theories, see <a href="/wiki/Genealogy_of_Jesus#Explanations_for_divergence" title="Genealogy of Jesus">Genealogy of Jesus Â§Â Explanations for divergence</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-342"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-342">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Amy-Jill_Levine" title="Amy-Jill Levine">Amy-Jill Levine</a> writes: "There is a consensus of sorts on a basic outline of Jesus' life. Most scholars agree that Jesus was baptized by John, debated with fellow Jews on how best to live according to God's will, engaged in healings and exorcisms, taught in parables, gathered male and female followers in Galilee, went to Jerusalem, and was crucified by Roman soldiers during the governorship of Pontius Pilate"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[330]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-362"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-362">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tuckett writes: "All this does at least render highly implausible any far-fetched theories that even Jesus' very existence was a Christian invention. The fact that Jesus existed, that he was crucified under Pontius Pilate (for whatever reason) and that he had a band of followers who continued to support his cause, seems to be part of the bedrock of historical tradition. If nothing else, the non-Christian evidence can provide us with certainty on that score."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[349]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-378"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-378">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For example, John P. Meier states that Jesus' birth year is <i>c.</i> 7/6 BC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeier1991407_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeier1991407-1">[1]</a></sup> while Finegan favors <i>c.</i> 3/2 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finegan_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-Finegan-4">[4]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-455"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-455">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In the New Testament, Jesus is described as Jewish / Judean (<i><a href="/wiki/Ioudaios" title="Ioudaios">Ioudaios</a></i> as written in Koine Greek) on three occasions: by the Magi in <a href="/wiki/Matthew_2" title="Matthew 2">Matthew 2</a>, who referred to Jesus as "King of the Jews" (<i>basileus ton ioudaion</i>); by both the <a href="/wiki/Samaritan_woman_at_the_well" title="Samaritan woman at the well">Samaritan woman at the well</a> and by Jesus himself in <a href="/wiki/John_4" title="John 4">John 4</a>; and (in all four gospels) during the Passion, by the Romans, who also used the phrase "King of the Jews".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[440]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-466"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-466">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ehrman writes: "In simpler terms, the historical Jesus did not exist. Or if he did, he had virtually nothing to do with the founding of Christianity." further quoting as authoritative the fuller definition provided by <a href="/wiki/Earl_Doherty" title="Earl Doherty">Earl Doherty</a> in <i>Jesus: Neither God Nor Man</i>. Age of Reason, 2009, pp. viiâviii: it is "the theory that no historical Jesus worthy of the name existed, that Christianity began with a belief in a spiritual, mythical figure, that the Gospels are essentially allegory and fiction, and that no single identifiable person lay at the root of the Galilean preaching tradition."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman201212_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman201212-465">[450]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-491"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-491">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Following the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostolic_Age" title="Apostolic Age">Apostolic Age</a>, there was fierce and often politicized debate in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_centers_of_Christianity" title="Early centers of Christianity">early church</a> on many interrelated issues. <a href="/wiki/Christology" title="Christology">Christology</a> was a major focus of these debates, and was addressed at every one of the <a href="/wiki/First_seven_ecumenical_councils" title="First seven ecumenical councils">first seven ecumenical councils</a>. Some early beliefs viewed Jesus as ontologically subordinate to the Father (<a href="/wiki/Subordinationism" title="Subordinationism">Subordinationism</a>), and others considered him an aspect of the Father rather than a separate person (<a href="/wiki/Sabellianism" title="Sabellianism">Sabellianism</a>), both were condemned as heresies by the Catholic Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-11"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Antitrinitarianism_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005Antitrinitarianism-490">[474]</a></sup> The Church resolved the issues in ancient councils, which established the Holy Trinity, with Jesus both fully human and fully God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_51-12"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-51">[44]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-567"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-567">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Philip Schaff commenting on Irenaeus, wrote, 'This censure of images as a Gnostic peculiarity, and as a heathenish corruption, should be noted'. Footnote 300 on Contr. Her. .I.XXV.6. ANF</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-583"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-583">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flavius_Josephus" title="Flavius Josephus">Flavius Josephus</a> writing (about 5 years later, c. AD 75) in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Jewish_War" title="The Jewish War">The Jewish War</a></i> (Book VII 1.1) stated that Jerusalem had been flattened to the point that "there was left nothing to make those that came thither believe it had ever been inhabited."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[564]</a></sup> And once what was left of the ruins of Jerusalem had been turned into the Roman settlement of <a href="/wiki/Aelia_Capitolina" title="Aelia Capitolina">Aelia Capitolina</a>, no Jews were allowed to set foot in it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koester382_581-1"><a href="#cite_note-Koester382-581">[563]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-588"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-588">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Polarized conclusions regarding the Shroud of Turin remain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[567]</a></sup> According to former <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a></i> editor <a href="/wiki/Philip_Ball" title="Philip Ball">Philip Ball</a>, "it's fair to say that, despite the seemingly definitive tests in 1988, the status of the Shroud of Turin is murkier than ever. Not least, the nature of the image and how it was fixed on the cloth remain deeply puzzling".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-587"><a href="#cite_note-587">[568]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>

<li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1067248974">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBurridgeGould2004">Burridge, Richard A.; Gould, Graham (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/jesusnowthen0000burr/page/34" rel="nofollow"><i>Jesus Now and Then</i></a>. Wm. B. <li id="cite_note-120"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-120">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFReference-OED-synoptic"><span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a class="external text" href="https://oed.com/search?searchType=dictionary&amp;q=synoptic" rel="nofollow">"synoptic"</a></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> (OnlineÂ ed.). <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=synoptic&amp;rft.btitle=Oxford+English+Dictionary&amp;rft.edition=Online&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Foed.com%2Fsearch%3FsearchType%3Ddictionary%26q%3Dsynoptic&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJesus"></span>Â <span style="font-size:0.95em; font-size:95%; color:#555">(Subscription or <a class="external text" href="https://www.oed.com/public/login/loggingin#withyourlibrary" rel="nofollow">participating institution membership</a> required.)</span></span>

<li id="cite_note-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-142">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFrance1985"><a href="/wiki/R._T._France" title="R. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMillsBullard1998556-144"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMillsBullard1998556_144-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMillsBullard1998">Mills &amp; Bullard 1998</a>, p.Â 556.</span>

<li id="cite_note-marsh37-145"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-marsh37_145-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-marsh37_145-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-marsh37_145-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMarshMoyise,_Steve2006">Marsh, Clive; Moyise, Steve (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ecHpPzDLkhcC&amp;pg=PA37" rel="nofollow"><i>Jesus and the Gospels</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-298"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-298">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Matthew: "claiming to be king of the Jews". Mark: "king of the Jews". Luke: "subverting nation, opposing payment of taxes to Caesar, claiming to be Christ, a king" John: "breaking Jewish law, claiming to be the son of God".</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-327"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-327">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFrederick_F.1990">Frederick F., Bruce (1990). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=2lN0ibbLOHEC&amp;pg=PA210" rel="nofollow"><i>The Acts of the Apostles</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-328"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-328">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(American_Standard)/Acts#9:5" title="s:Bible (American Standard)/Acts">Acts 9:5</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-HarringtonActs-329"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-HarringtonActs_329-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJohnsonHarrington1992">Johnson, Luke T.; Harrington, Daniel J. (1992). <i>The Acts of the Apostles</i>. Liturgical Press. pp.Â 164â67. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8146-5807-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8146-5807-9"><bdi>978-0-8146-5807-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Acts+of+the+Apostles&amp;rft.pages=164-67&amp;rft.pub=Liturgical+Press&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8146-5807-9&amp;rft.aulast=Johnson&amp;rft.aufirst=Luke+T.&amp;rft.au=Harrington%2C+Daniel+J.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJesus"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-330"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-330">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFVan_den_Biesen1913">Van den Biesen, Christian (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="s:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Apocalypse"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/Apocalypse">"Apocalypse"Â </a></span>.  In Herbermann, Charles (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. New York: Robert Appleton Company.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Apocalypse&amp;rft.btitle=Catholic+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Robert+Appleton+Company&amp;rft.date=1913&amp;rft.aulast=Van+den+Biesen&amp;rft.aufirst=Christian&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJesus"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-331"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-331">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/12481c.htm" rel="nofollow">Catholic Encyclopedia: Proselyte</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170610204154/http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/12481c.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 10 June 2017 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>: "The English term 'proselyte' occurs only in the New Testament where it signifies a convert to the Jewish religion (<a class="external text" href="https://bible.usccb.org/bible/Matthew/23?15" rel="nofollow">Matthew 23:15</a>; <a class="external text" href="https://bible.usccb.org/bible/Acts/2?11" rel="nofollow">Acts 2:11</a>; <a class="external text" href="https://bible.usccb.org/bible/Acts/6?5" rel="nofollow">6:5</a>; etc.), though the same Greek word is commonly used in the <a href="/wiki/Septuagint" title="Septuagint">Septuagint</a> to designate a foreigner living in Palestine. Thus the term seems to have passed from an original local and chiefly political sense, in which it was used as early as 300 BC, to a technical and religious meaning in the Judaism of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostolic_Age" title="Apostolic Age">New Testament epoch</a>."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEEhrman201287â90-332"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEhrman201287â90_332-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFEhrman2012">Ehrman 2012</a>, pp.Â 87â90.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-333"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-333">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJaeger1961">Jaeger, Werner (1961). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kYfAUnFMhPMC&amp;pg=PA108" rel="nofollow"><i>Early Christianity and Greek Paideia</i></a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">26 February</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Early+Christianity+and+Greek+Paideia&amp;rft.pages=6%2C+108-09&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1961&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-674-22052-2&amp;rft.aulast=Jaeger&amp;rft.aufirst=Werner&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DkYfAUnFMhPMC%26pg%3DPA108&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJesus"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-334"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-334">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblica.com/bible/?osis=niv:Galatians%202:9" rel="nofollow">Galatians 2:9</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://www.biblica.com/bible/?osis=niv:Acts%201:13" rel="nofollow">Acts 1:13</a>; See <a href="/wiki/Historical_reliability_of_the_Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Historical reliability of the Acts of the Apostles">Historical reliability of the Acts of the Apostles</a> for details</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-335"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-335">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCross2005">Cross, F.L., ed. </li>
<li id="cite_note-336"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-336">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Cohen, Shaye J.D. (1988). <i>From the Maccabees to the Mishnah</i> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-664-25017-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-664-25017-1">978-0-664-25017-1</a> pp. 224â25</span>

<li id="cite_note-Ehrman120ce-338"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ehrman120ce_338-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBart_D._Ehrman1997">Bart D. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 May</span> 2018</span>. <q>The New Testament contains twenty-seven books, written in Greek, by fifteen or sixteen different authors, who were addressing other Christian individuals or communities between the years 50 and 120 C.E. (see box 1.4). As we will see, it is difficult to know whether any of these books was written by Jesus' own disciples.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+New+Testament%3A+A+Historical+Introduction+to+the+Early+Christian+Writings&amp;rft.pages=8&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-508481-8&amp;rft.au=Bart+D.+Ehrman&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DxpoNAQAAMAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJesus"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunn2003313â15-450"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunn2003313â15_450-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDunn2003">Dunn 2003</a>, pp.Â 313â15.</span>

<li id="cite_note-Allen_C._Myers-451"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Allen_C._Myers_451-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFAllen_C._Myers1987">Allen C. Myers, ed. (1987). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/eerdmansbibledic00myer/page/72" rel="nofollow">"Aramaic"</a>. <i>The Eerdmans Bible Dictionary</i>. Grand Rapids, Michigan: William B. Eerdmans. p.Â <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/eerdmansbibledic00myer/page/72" rel="nofollow">72</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8028-2402-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8028-2402-8"><bdi>978-0-8028-2402-8</bdi></a>. <q>It is generally agreed that Aramaic was the common language of Israel in the first century AD. Jesus and his disciples spoke the Galilean dialect, which was distinguished from that of Jerusalem (Matt. 26:73).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Aramaic&amp;rft.btitle=The+Eerdmans+Bible+Dictionary&amp;rft.place=Grand+Rapids%2C+Michigan&amp;rft.pages=72&amp;rft.pub=William+B.+Eerdmans&amp;rft.date=1987&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8028-2402-8&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Feerdmansbibledic00myer%2Fpage%2F72&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJesus"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Encyclopedia-452"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Encyclopedia_452-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/32043/Aramaic-language" rel="nofollow">"Aramaic language"</a>. <i>EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica</i>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150427072726/https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/32043/Aramaic-language" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 27 April 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-527"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-527">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://corpus.quran.com/translation.jsp?chapter=3&amp;verse=54" rel="nofollow">"The Quranic Arabic Corpus â Translation"</a>. Corpus.quran.com. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160418170132/http://corpus.quran.com/translation.jsp?chapter=3&amp;verse=54" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 18 April 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 May</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Quranic+Arabic+Corpus+%E2%80%93+Translation&amp;rft.pub=Corpus.quran.com&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fcorpus.quran.com%2Ftranslation.jsp%3Fchapter%3D3%26verse%3D54&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJesus"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-cite_quran|4|157|style=ref-528"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-cite_quran|4|157|style=ref_528-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>Â <a class="external text" href="https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2002.02.0006%3Asura%3D4%3Averse%3D157" rel="nofollow">4:157</a>: "<i>And because of their saying: We slew the Messiah Jesus son of Mary, Allahâs messenger â They slew him not nor crucified, but it appeared so unto them</i>" (<a class="external text" href="https://quran-archive.org/explorer/marmaduke-pickthall/1930?page=119#top" rel="nofollow">4:157</a>) by <a href="/wiki/Marmaduke_Pickthall" title="Marmaduke Pickthall">Marmaduke Pickthall</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-529"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-529">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFRobinson2005">Robinson 2005</a>; <a href="#CITEREFLawson2009">Lawson 2009</a>. The substitution theory was criticized and rejected by the Sunni Quran commentator <a href="/wiki/Fakhr_al-Din_al-Razi" title="Fakhr al-Din al-Razi">Fakhr al-Din al-Razi</a> (1150â1210); see <a href="#CITEREFLawson2009">Lawson 2009</a>, pp.Â 156â162. According to <a href="/wiki/Abu_Mansur_al-Baghdadi" title="Abu Mansur al-Baghdadi">Abu Mansur al-Baghdadi</a> (d. 1037), the substitution theory was also applied to the death of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ali_ibn_Abi_Talib" title="Ali ibn Abi Talib">Ali ibn Abi Talib</a> by the semi-legendary 7th-century figure <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abdullah_ibn_Saba%27" title="Abdullah ibn Saba'">Abdallah ibn Saba'</a>; see <a href="#CITEREFDe_Smet2016">De Smet 2016</a>, pp.Â 98â99.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-530"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-530">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">On the writings attributed to alâMufaddal ibn Umar alâJu'fi, see <a href="#CITEREFDe_Smet2016">De Smet 2016</a>, p.Â 93. On the Brethren of Purity, see <a href="#CITEREFRobinson1991">Robinson 1991</a>, pp.Â 55â57, <a href="#CITEREFLawson2009">Lawson 2009</a>, pp.Â 129â133 and especially <a href="#CITEREFDe_Smet2016">De Smet 2016</a>, pp.Â 100â101. On the Isma'ili philosophers (who include <a href="/wiki/Abu_Hatim_Ahmad_ibn_Hamdan_al-Razi" title="Abu Hatim Ahmad ibn Hamdan al-Razi">Abu Hatim al-Razi</a>, Abu Tammam, <a href="/wiki/Ja%27far_ibn_Mansur_al-Yaman" title="Ja'far ibn Mansur al-Yaman">Ja'far ibn Mansur al-Yaman</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abu_Yaqub_al-Sijistani" title="Abu Yaqub al-Sijistani">Abu Yaqub al-Sijistani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ibrahim_ibn_al-Husayn_al-Hamidi" title="Ibrahim ibn al-Husayn al-Hamidi">Ibrahim al-Hamidi</a>), see <a href="#CITEREFLawson2009">Lawson 2009</a>, pp.Â 123â129 and especially <a href="#CITEREFDe_Smet2016">De Smet 2016</a>, pp.Â 101â107. On al-Ghazali, see <a href="#CITEREFLawson2009">Lawson 2009</a>, pp.Â 117â118. This type of interpretation of Quran 4:157â159 was specifically rejected by the Sunni Quran commentator al-<a href="/wiki/Qadi_Baydawi" title="Qadi Baydawi">Baydawi</a> (d. 1319); see <a href="#CITEREFLawson2009">Lawson 2009</a>, p.Â 155.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Khalidi-531"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Khalidi_531-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKhalidi2001">Khalidi, Tarif (2001). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/muslimjesussayin00/page/12" rel="nofollow"><i>The Muslim Jesus: Sayings and Stories in Islamic Literature</i></a>. </li>

<li id="cite_note-manifestation-544"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-manifestation_544-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-manifestation_544-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-manifestation_544-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFCole1982">Cole, Juan (1982). <a class="external text" href="http://bahai-library.com/cole_concept_manifestation" rel="nofollow">"The Concept of Manifestation in the BahaÊ¼i Writings"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_studies#Journals" title="BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ studies">Ãtudes BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Studies</a></i>. <b>9</b>: 1â38. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190517105145/http://bahai-library.com/cole_concept_manifestation" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 17 May 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. <div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></div><div aria-labelledby="Sermon_on_the_Mount" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Sermon_on_the_Mount" title="Template:Sermon on the Mount"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Sermon_on_the_Mount" title="Template talk:Sermon on the Mount"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Sermon_on_the_Mount&amp;action=edit"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Sermon_on_the_Mount" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Mount" title="Sermon on the Mount">Sermon on the Mount</a></div></th></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div id="*_Sermon_on_the_Plain">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Plain" title="Sermon on the Plain">Sermon on the Plain</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Attributed to</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Jesus</a> (<a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Matthew</a> <a href="/wiki/Matthew_5" title="Matthew 5">5, </a><a href="/wiki/Matthew_6" title="Matthew 6">6, </a><a href="/wiki/Matthew_7" title="Matthew 7">and 7</a>)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Teachings</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Beatitudes" title="Beatitudes">Beatitudes</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Salt_and_light" title="Salt and light">Salt and light</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/City_upon_a_Hill" title="City upon a Hill">City upon a Hill</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Lamp_under_a_bushel" title="Lamp under a bushel">Lamp under a bushel</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Light_of_the_World" title="Light of the World">Light of the World</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Turning_the_other_cheek" title="Turning the other cheek">Turning the other cheek</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Matthew_5:44" title="Matthew 5:44">Love your enemies</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Lord%27s_Prayer" title="Lord's Prayer">Lord's Prayer</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/The_Birds_of_the_Air" title="The Birds of the Air">The Birds of the Air</a></li>

<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></div><div aria-labelledby="Life_of_Jesus_in_art" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="3" scope="col" style="background-color:#FFFF66"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Life_of_Jesus_in_Christian_art" title="Template:Life of Jesus in Christian art"><abbr style="background-color:#FFFF66;;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Life_of_Jesus_in_Christian_art" title="Template talk:Life of Jesus in Christian art"><abbr style="background-color:#FFFF66;;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Life_of_Jesus_in_Christian_art&amp;action=edit"><abbr style="background-color:#FFFF66;;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Life_of_Jesus_in_art" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Life_of_Christ_in_art" title="Life of Christ in art">Life of Jesus in art</a></div></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="background-color:#FFFF66;width:1%">Topics</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
